summary_llm:
The play opens on Christmas Eve in the Helmer household. Nora Helmer, in high spirits, returns home with Christmas parcels. Her husband, Torvald Helmer, a newly appointed bank manager, playfully scolds her for being a "spendthrift" and reminds her of his strict stance against debt and borrowing. He gives her money for Christmas, and she shows him the children's presents. Nora hints at wanting money for herself, which Torvald dismisses as her usual extravagance, though he admits she saves what she can. He also notices her looking uneasy and teases her about eating forbidden macaroons. Torvald expresses his delight at their improved financial situation and his new position, which will bring a large salary. He mentions that Doctor Rank, a close family friend, will be joining them for dinner.

A visitor arrives, Mrs. Linde, an old school friend of Nora's. Nora is overjoyed but notes how much Christine (Mrs. Linde) has changed. Christine reveals she is a widow, childless, and has been struggling financially, working tirelessly for years to support her bedridden mother and younger brothers, who are now independent. She feels her life is "unspeakably empty" and has come to town seeking regular office work. Nora, in turn, excitedly shares her good fortune, revealing Torvald's new bank manager position. She then confides a secret to Christine: it was she, not her father, who obtained the money (two hundred and fifty pounds) for Torvald's life-saving trip to Italy years ago when he was gravely ill. She explains that Torvald's pride would have been hurt if he knew, and her father was too ill to sign the bond. She has been secretly paying off the debt through various means, including copying work, and has found it a great burden. She hopes to be free of it soon.

Just then, Krogstad, a lawyer who works at Torvald's bank, arrives to speak with Torvald. Mrs. Linde is visibly startled, recognizing him from her past. Doctor Rank, who was with Torvald, emerges from the study and describes Krogstad as a man with a "diseased moral character" who was guilty of an "indiscretion" (forgery) in the past. Nora, realizing Krogstad's connection to her secret, offers Mrs. Linde a position at the bank through Torvald's influence.

Krogstad confronts Nora, revealing he knows about her loan and the forgery of her father's signature on the bond, which he possesses. He points out that her father's signature was dated three days after his death, implying Nora forged the date. Nora admits she forged her father's signature because he was too ill to sign and she couldn't tell him about Torvald's life-threatening condition. Krogstad threatens to expose her if Torvald dismisses him from the bank, stating that her "one false step" is similar to his own "indiscretion" that ruined his reputation. He wants to keep his job and regain his respectability for his sons' sake. Nora dismisses his threats, believing her motives (love for her husband) justify her actions and that her husband would pay off the debt. However, Krogstad warns her that if he loses his position, she will lose hers with him. After Krogstad leaves, Nora is deeply troubled, whispering that it's "impossible" and she did it "for love's sake." Torvald returns, and Nora lies about Krogstad's visit. Torvald reveals he has the authority to make changes at the bank and plans to dismiss Krogstad, whom he despises for his moral failings and overly familiar manner. He tells Nora that such a "guilty man" poisons his home with lies, and that a "deceitful mother" infects her children. Nora is horrified by this statement and tries to dissuade him from dismissing Krogstad, but Torvald sends the dismissal letter anyway. Nora is terrified, realizing the letter's implications. Torvald, unaware of her secret, assures her he is man enough to take everything upon himself if anything should happen.

Act II opens with Nora's increasing anxiety. The Christmas tree is dishevelled, reflecting her inner turmoil. She checks the letterbox, hoping Krogstad's letter isn't there. She talks to the Nurse, asking if children forget their mothers if they go away, hinting at desperate thoughts. Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her Tarantella dress for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. Nora reveals to Christine that Doctor Rank is suffering from a dangerous, hereditary spinal disease, a consequence of his father's excesses.

Doctor Rank then visits, and after some conversation, confesses his love for Nora, stating he would gladly give his life for her. Nora is shocked and distressed by his confession, as she had considered asking him for a large sum of money to pay off Krogstad, but now realizes she cannot exploit his feelings. Rank tells her he will send her a card with a black cross on it when his final decline begins, indicating he will shut himself away to die and does not want Torvald to see him in his sickroom.

Krogstad returns, having received his dismissal letter. He confirms that Torvald knows nothing of Nora's forgery. He tells Nora he will not expose her to the law, but demands to be reinstated at the bank in a higher position, as Torvald's "right hand." He then drops a letter into the Helmers' letterbox, which reveals Nora's secret to Torvald. Nora is frantic, knowing Torvald will soon read it. She desperately tries to distract Torvald from checking the letterbox, begging him to help her practice her Tarantella dance and promising him she will only think of him. She insists he must not open any letters until after the ball. Mrs. Linde, seeing the letter in the box, realizes the full extent of Nora's predicament and offers to speak to Krogstad, revealing that they have a past relationship and she believes she can influence him. She leaves to find Krogstad, while Nora continues her desperate dance, feeling her life depends on it.

In Act III, Mrs. Linde waits for Krogstad at the Helmers' house after the ball. She reveals that she broke off their relationship years ago to marry a wealthier man and support her family, but now that her obligations are fulfilled and she is a widow, she feels her life is empty. She proposes to Krogstad that they reunite, offering to care for him and his children, and to work together. Krogstad is overjoyed and wants to retrieve his letter from Torvald's letterbox to spare Nora. However, Mrs. Linde stops him, believing that the "unhappy secret must be disclosed" to force a "complete understanding" between Nora and Torvald, as their marriage cannot continue with "concealment and falsehood." Krogstad agrees to leave the letter.

Torvald and Nora return from the ball. Torvald is pleased with Nora's dancing, but also controlling and possessive. Doctor Rank makes a brief, final visit. He confirms his illness has progressed to "absolute certainty" and says he will be "invisible" at the next ball, implying his death. He leaves two cards with black crosses on them in the letterbox. After Rank leaves, Torvald checks the letterbox, finds Rank's cards, and understands his friend's impending death. He then finds Krogstad's letter.

Reading Krogstad's letter, Torvald is enraged. He calls Nora a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father's lack of principle for her actions and declares she has destroyed his happiness and ruined his future, fearing public scandal and suspicion of his own involvement. He states that for the sake of appearances, Nora must remain in the house, but he will not allow her to raise the children.

Just then, the maid brings another letter for Nora. Torvald seizes it and reads it. It is from Krogstad, stating that a "happy change in his life" has occurred, and he is returning Nora's bond, effectively retracting his threat. Torvald is overcome with relief, shouting that they are both "saved!" He immediately tears up the bond and both letters, burning them in the stove, and declares the whole affair a bad dream. He "forgives" Nora, calling her his "frightened little singing-bird" and attributing her actions to "womanly helplessness" and lack of understanding. He asserts that he has given her "a new life" and that she has become "both wife and child" to him.

Nora, however, has undergone a profound change. She calmly changes into her everyday dress and asks Torvald to sit down for a serious conversation, the first they have ever had in eight years of marriage. She tells him she has never been happy, only "merry," and that their home has been a "playroom" where she was his "doll-wife," just as she was her father's "doll-child." She accuses him and her father of committing a "great sin" against her by preventing her from making anything of her life. She declares she is no longer a suitable wife for him and must leave to educate herself and understand the world and her own identity.

Torvald is shocked and tries to forbid her, reminding her of her "most sacred duties" as a wife and mother. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself. She no longer believes that she is primarily a wife and mother, but a "reasonable human being" who must think for herself. She questions the laws and religious principles that would condemn her for saving her father and husband. She reveals that she had hoped for a "wonderful thing" when Krogstad's letter came: that Torvald would bravely take all the blame upon himself. When he instead reacted with anger and fear for his own reputation, she realized he was not the man she thought he was, and she no longer loves him. She states that no man would sacrifice his honor for love, but "hundreds of thousands of women have."

Nora concludes that she cannot live with him as she is now, nor can she live with a "strange man." She returns her wedding ring, asks for his, and declares herself free from all obligations to him, and him from hers. She states she will not see the children, believing they are in better hands. She refuses any contact or help from Torvald, as he is a "stranger" to her. She leaves the house, stating that for their life together to be a "real wedlock," both would have to be so changed that she no longer believes in "wonderful things happening." Torvald is left alone, calling her name, as the sound of a door shutting is heard from below.

Alice, growing tired of sitting idly by her sister on a riverbank, notices a White Rabbit with pink eyes run by, muttering "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" The Rabbit then takes a watch from its waistcoat-pocket and hurries on, sparking Alice's curiosity. She follows it down a large rabbit-hole, falling into a very deep well lined with cupboards and bookshelves. During her slow descent, she places an empty "ORANGE MARMALADE" jar into a cupboard. She muses about her location, her cat Dinah, and dozes off.

She lands unhurt on a pile of sticks and leaves and sees the White Rabbit again, still hurrying. She follows it into a long, low hall with many locked doors. On a glass table, she finds a tiny golden key, which fits a small door about fifteen inches high behind a curtain. Through this door, she sees a beautiful garden but cannot fit. She wishes she could shrink. She then finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After checking it's not poison, she drinks the contents, which taste like a mixture of various foods, and shrinks to ten inches tall. However, she realizes she left the key on the table and cannot reach it.

Frustrated, Alice scolds herself. She then finds a small cake under the table marked "EAT ME." She eats it, hoping to change size, and after eating the whole cake, she begins to grow. She grows so large that her head hits the roof of the hall, making her over nine feet tall. She manages to grab the key but can only look into the garden with one eye while lying down. Overwhelmed, she cries a pool of tears around her.

The White Rabbit returns, dressed splendidly, looking for his fan and gloves. Alice tries to ask for help, but the Rabbit, startled, drops his items and flees. Alice picks up the fan and gloves and, fanning herself, realizes she is shrinking again. She quickly drops the fan, stopping her rapid decrease in size, and is now about two feet high. However, the door is still locked, and the key is on the unreachable table. Suddenly, she slips and falls into the pool of tears she had wept, now swimming in salt water.

She encounters a Mouse in the pool and attempts to speak to it, first in a formal style, then in French. The Mouse is terrified by the mention of "cat" (chatte). Alice apologizes but then describes her own cat, Dinah, and her mouse-catching skills, further offending the Mouse. She then tries to talk about dogs, which also offends the Mouse. She calls it back, promising not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse agrees to tell its history once they reach shore. Other creatures, including a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, and an Eaglet, have also fallen into the pool, and they all swim to the bank.

On the bank, the wet creatures discuss how to get dry. The Mouse, taking charge, begins to recite a "dry" history lesson about William the Conqueror, but it doesn't help them dry. The Dodo proposes a "Caucus-race," which involves running in a circle with no clear start or end, until everyone is dry. After about half an hour, the Dodo declares everyone has won and must have prizes. Alice, designated as the prize-giver, distributes comfits from her pocket. For her own prize, she offers a thimble, which the Dodo solemnly presents back to her.

The Mouse then begins to tell its "long and a sad tale," which Alice misinterprets as referring to the literal length of its tail. The Mouse recites a poem about a trial between Fury and a mouse, but Alice's preoccupation with the tail offends the Mouse, who accuses her of not paying attention and confusing words. The Mouse, insulted, walks away. Alice, trying to call it back, mentions her cat Dinah's ability to fetch things and catch birds. This causes all the birds present to flee in fear, leaving Alice alone and regretful.

The White Rabbit reappears, still searching for his fan and gloves and muttering about the Duchess. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, Mary Ann, and orders her to fetch them from his house. Alice, frightened, goes to the Rabbit's house. Inside, she finds a bottle and drinks from it, hoping to grow to her normal size. Instead, she grows so large that she fills the house, with one arm out a window and one foot up the chimney. The Rabbit and other creatures (including Pat and Bill the Lizard) try to get her out, first by attempting to open the door, then by trying to remove her arm from the window, and finally by sending Bill down the chimney. Alice kicks Bill out of the chimney. The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set Dinah on them, causing a silence. They then throw pebbles at the window, which turn into little cakes. Alice eats one, shrinks, and escapes the house, running into a wood.

In the wood, Alice encounters an enormous puppy, which she plays with using a stick before escaping. She realizes she needs to grow to her proper size and finds a large mushroom. On top of it, a large blue Caterpillar is smoking a hookah. The Caterpillar repeatedly asks Alice "Who are _you_?", to which Alice replies she doesn't know, having changed so many times. She tries to recite a poem, "You are old, Father William," but it comes out wrong. The Caterpillar, exactly three inches high, is offended when Alice says three inches is a "wretched height." The Caterpillar then crawls away, telling Alice that one side of the mushroom will make her grow taller and the other shorter. Alice breaks off a piece from each side. She nibbles one piece and shrinks rapidly, her chin hitting her foot. She then eats from the other piece, and her neck grows immensely long, rising above the treetops. A Pigeon mistakes her for a serpent, complaining about serpents eating eggs. Alice eventually manages to return to her normal height by carefully eating from both mushroom pieces. She then sees a small house and shrinks herself to nine inches tall before approaching it.

At the house, Alice observes a Fish-Footman and a Frog-Footman. The Fish-Footman delivers an invitation from the Queen to the Duchess to play croquet. Alice tries to enter but the Frog-Footman gives nonsensical reasons why knocking is useless. Alice, frustrated, opens the door and enters a smoky kitchen. Inside, the Duchess is nursing a constantly sneezing and howling baby, while a Cook throws kitchenware at them. A grinning Cheshire Cat sits by the fire. Alice asks the Duchess why her cat grins, learning it's a Cheshire cat. The Duchess sings a violent lullaby to the baby, shaking it with each line. She then flings the baby at Alice, telling her to nurse it, and leaves for the croquet game. Alice struggles to hold the oddly shaped baby, which she realizes is turning into a pig. She sets the pig down, and it trots into the wood.

Alice then encounters the Cheshire Cat again. She asks for directions, and the Cat tells her that a Hatter and a March Hare live nearby, both of whom are mad. The Cat explains that everyone there is mad, including Alice. The Cat vanishes and reappears several times, leaving only its grin behind at one point. Alice proceeds to the March Hare's house, shrinking herself slightly before entering.

She finds the March Hare and the Hatter having a perpetual tea-party with a sleeping Dormouse, whom they use as a cushion. They tell Alice there's "No room!" but she sits down anyway. They offer her wine, but there is none. The Hatter makes a personal remark about her hair, then asks the riddle "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" which he and the March Hare admit they don't know the answer to. The Hatter checks his watch, which tells the day of the month but not the time, and complains about butter in its works. He explains that he and "Time" had a quarrel, so it's always six o'clock (tea-time) for them, which is why they keep moving around the table for clean cups. The Dormouse tells a story about three sisters who lived in a "treacle-well" and drew "treacle" and things beginning with "M." Alice finds the conversation increasingly nonsensical and rude. Disgusted, she leaves, vowing never to return. She then finds a door in a tree that leads back to the long hall. Using the golden key and the mushroom, she finally enters the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice sees three card-shaped gardeners painting white roses red, fearing the Queen of Hearts will behead them for planting the wrong color. The Queen arrives with a grand procession of card-soldiers, courtiers, royal children, and the White Rabbit, followed by the Knave of Hearts and the King and Queen of Hearts. The Queen, upon seeing Alice standing, demands to know her name and who the prostrate gardeners are. Alice, feeling bold, says it's "no business of _mine_." The Queen furiously screams "Off with her head!" but Alice dismisses it as "Nonsense!" The King intervenes. The Queen orders the gardeners' heads off, but Alice hides them in a flower-pot.

The Queen invites Alice to play croquet. The game is chaotic: the ground is uneven, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are soldiers who keep moving. The Queen constantly shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" Alice sees the Cheshire Cat's grin appear in the air. She complains to the Cat about the unfair game. The King orders the Cat's head removed, but the executioner, King, and Queen argue about how to behead a head without a body. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is in prison. The Cat's head fades away as the executioner goes to fetch the Duchess.

The Duchess, now in a pleasant mood, links arms with Alice, offering convoluted morals for everything. The Queen reappears and, with a threat of execution, makes the Duchess vanish. The Queen continues ordering executions during the croquet game, until only she, the King, and Alice remain free. The Queen then sends Alice and the Gryphon to hear the Mock Turtle's story. The Gryphon reveals that the Queen never actually executes anyone.

They find the Mock Turtle, who is sighing and appears sad. He tells Alice his history, beginning with "Once, I was a real Turtle." He describes going to school in the sea, learning "Reeling and Writhing," and "Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision," as well as "Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils." He explains that lessons "lessen" each day. The Gryphon then asks him to describe the "Lobster Quadrille," a dance involving lobsters as partners, throwing them out to sea, and turning somersaults. The Mock Turtle sings a song about a whiting and a snail. The Gryphon explains that whitings have their tails in their mouths because they were thrown out to sea for dancing with lobsters, and that "whiting" also refers to what makes boots shiny, which are made of "Soles and eels."

The Gryphon then asks Alice to tell her adventures. She recounts her experiences, including her incorrect recitation of "You are old, Father William." The Mock Turtle and Gryphon then make Alice recite "'_’Tis the voice of the sluggard_,'" which she also gets wrong, singing about a lobster. She is interrupted as a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard.

Alice and the Gryphon hurry to the trial, where the King and Queen of Hearts are on their throne. The Knave of Hearts is in chains, accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The White Rabbit acts as Herald. Alice observes the King as judge and twelve creatures as jurors, who are busy writing on slates. Alice takes away Bill the Lizard's squeaking pencil. The White Rabbit reads the accusation in verse. The Hatter is called as the first witness, giving nervous and nonsensical testimony about tea and dates, which confuse the court. Alice begins to grow again, causing the Dormouse to complain and move. The King threatens the Hatter with execution. The Hatter is dismissed, and the Queen orders his head off, but he escapes. The Duchess's Cook is the next witness but refuses to cooperate, only saying tarts are made of "Pepper, mostly." The Dormouse interjects "Treacle," causing the Queen to order its suppression and removal. During the confusion, the Cook disappears. Finally, the White Rabbit calls Alice as the next witness.

Alice, forgetting her size, jumps up and knocks over the jury-box, scattering the jurymen. She quickly puts them back, including Bill the Lizard, who she initially placed upside down. The King asks Alice what she knows about the stolen tarts, and she replies "Nothing." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit corrects him, saying he meant "unimportant." The King then reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Alice, now very large, refuses to leave, pointing out the King just invented the rule. The King tries to get the jury to consider their verdict, but the White Rabbit produces a new piece of evidence: a letter, which turns out to be a set of nonsensical verses, found on the Knave. The King tries to interpret the verses as proof of the Knave's guilt, making strained connections to swimming and "fits." Alice loudly declares there's no meaning in the verses. The Queen, furious, demands "Sentence first—verdict afterwards." Alice calls this "Stuff and nonsense!" The Queen screams "Off with her head!"

At this, Alice, now grown to her full size, declares, "Who cares for you? You’re nothing but a pack of cards!" The entire pack of cards flies up and then down upon her. Alice screams and tries to bat them away, only to find herself lying on the riverbank, her head in her sister's lap. Her sister wakes her, and Alice recounts her "curious dream." Her sister, after hearing the story, imagines Alice's dream herself, with all the strange creatures and events, before picturing Alice as a grown woman, sharing these wonderful tales with other children.

The plot of the provided text, "Anna Karenina," unfolds across eight parts, detailing the intertwined lives and emotional struggles of several characters, primarily focusing on the Oblonsky and Levin families, and the developing relationship between Anna Karenina and Count Vronsky.

**PART ONE**

The story begins in the Oblonskys' house, where chaos reigns after Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly) discovers her husband, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva), has been having an affair with their French governess. Dolly announces she can no longer live with him, causing distress throughout the household. Stiva, while regretting his lack of discretion, does not truly repent his infidelity. His valet, Matvey, informs him that his sister, Anna Arkadyevna Karenina, is arriving from Petersburg, hinting that she might help reconcile the couple. Dolly, however, tells Matvey she is leaving. The nurse, Matrona Philimonovna, urges Stiva to beg Dolly's forgiveness for the children's sake.

Stiva, despite his inner turmoil, maintains a cheerful exterior. He attends to some office work and a petitioner, then decides to confront Dolly. He finds her distraught, sorting her belongings, contemplating leaving but unable to due to her love for him and the practicalities of caring for their five children. Stiva's attempts to apologize are met with Dolly's fury and disgust, as she calls him "loathsome" and a "stranger" after his affair with the children's governess. A child's cry briefly softens Dolly, but she eventually threatens to expose Stiva as a "scoundrel" and leaves, slamming the door. Stiva is annoyed by her "vulgar" outburst.

Meanwhile, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, an old friend of Stiva's, arrives in Moscow with the intention of proposing to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister. Levin, a country gentleman, is deeply in love with Kitty but considers himself unworthy due to his lack of a conventional career and his perceived unattractiveness. He had previously left Moscow in despair but returned with a firm resolve to propose. He visits Stiva at his office, where Stiva, despite his own domestic troubles, is charming and efficient. Stiva tells Levin that Kitty is at the Zoological Gardens.

Levin, filled with excitement and dread, goes to the skating rink and sees Kitty. He is captivated by her beauty and grace. They skate together, and Kitty expresses confidence in him. Levin, in a moment of panic, blurts out that his staying depends on her, which causes her to withdraw. He is distraught. Stiva then arrives and invites Levin to dinner.

At the restaurant, Stiva reveals that Count Vronsky, a wealthy and charming Petersburg officer, is also a suitor for Kitty and is favored by her mother. Levin is angered by this news, feeling his love is profaned. Stiva then asks Levin for advice on his own affair, describing his mistress as a "sweet, gentle loving creature." Levin expresses disgust for "fallen women." Stiva, in turn, criticizes Levin's "all of a piece" nature. Levin leaves, determined to propose to Kitty that evening.

Kitty, preparing for the evening, feels a mix of pleasure at Levin's love and dread at having to refuse him, as she believes she loves Vronsky. When Levin arrives early and proposes, Kitty, after a moment of ecstasy, remembers Vronsky and hastily refuses Levin. The princess enters, relieved by Kitty's refusal. Countess Nordston, a friend of Kitty's, teases Levin. Vronsky arrives, and Kitty's radiant eyes confirm to Levin that she loves Vronsky. Levin, heartbroken, leaves the ball, his last impression being Kitty's happy face as she talks to Vronsky.

Kitty, despite her happiness, feels remorse over Levin's suffering. Downstairs, the prince furiously scolds the princess for pushing Kitty towards Vronsky, whom he calls a "peacock," and praises Levin. The princess, disturbed, also prays.

Vronsky, unaware of the parents' conversation, feels a strong bond with Kitty and believes she loves him. He goes home, content. The next morning, at the railway station, Vronsky meets Stiva, who is there to meet his sister, Anna Karenina. Stiva hints at Levin's proposal and Kitty's rejection. The train arrives, and Vronsky is struck by Anna's "caressing and soft" expression and "shining gray eyes." He introduces himself. Anna, with a decisive gesture, embraces Stiva. Vronsky's mother, Countess Vronskaya, tells him Anna is "very sweet" and that he is "in perfect love." Anna gives Vronsky her hand, and he is delighted. As they leave, a man is crushed by a train. Vronsky generously gives 200 roubles to the widow. Anna, visibly agitated, calls the accident an "omen of evil" and asks about Vronsky's acquaintance with him and Kitty.

Anna spends the day at Dolly's, successfully reconciling her and Stiva. She tells Dolly she is leaving Moscow early because Kitty is jealous of her. Dolly expresses concern about Kitty marrying Vronsky if he could be so easily swayed by Anna. Anna blushes, then admits she is leaving to avoid Vronsky. Stiva arrives, and Anna leaves for Petersburg, feeling a mixture of relief and dread. On the train, she is tormented by a sense of shame and a nervous tension, experiencing hallucinations. At a station, she encounters Vronsky, who declares his love, saying he came "to be where you are." She tells him his words are "wrong" and asks him to forget them, but feels they have been brought "fearfully closer." She arrives in Petersburg, where her husband, Alexey Alexandrovitch, meets her with a "sarcastic smile" and a "consciousness of hypocrisy." She dismisses her intense feelings for Vronsky as a "trivial incident."

**PART TWO**

Levin, back in the country, still suffers from his rejection, but time and work help. He has kept his resolution of purity and visited his ailing brother Nikolay, persuading him to go abroad. Spring arrives, filling Levin with plans for his farm. He is frustrated by the slovenliness of his laborers but finds joy in working alongside them, even mowing himself.

Stiva visits Levin, ostensibly for shooting and to sell his forest. He reveals Kitty is very ill and has been sent abroad. Levin is shocked but also feels a sense of satisfaction that she is suffering. He is further angered when Stiva sells his forest to a merchant, Ryabinin, for a low price, which Levin attributes to Stiva's city ignorance and the merchant's cunning. Levin confronts Stiva about his aristocratic values and his own rejection by Kitty, declaring her a "painful and humiliating reminiscence."

During a shooting expedition, Stiva tells Levin that Kitty is "very ill" and "may not live." Levin is deeply affected but tries to dismiss it. He is pleased by his successful shooting.

Alexey Alexandrovitch and Anna continue to live as strangers. He is helpless against her "amused perplexity" regarding his suspicions. Vronsky's passion for Anna is fulfilled. She feels sinful and humiliated, sinking to his feet, begging forgiveness. Vronsky feels like a "murderer" of their initial love. Anna declares, "All is over; I have nothing but you." She is haunted by a dream of both men being her husbands.

Levin, after Nikolay's death, is consumed by questions of life and death, finding no answers in science or philosophy. He considers suicide but continues to live, finding solace in his work and family life. He is exasperated by his brother Nikolay's irritable and self-deceiving behavior and his distorted views on communism. Nikolay dies, leaving Levin with a profound sense of the "insoluble enigma" of death.

Kitty, at the German watering-place, is ill and ashamed after her refusal of Levin and Vronsky's betrayal. She confides in Dolly, who has come to visit. Kitty expresses disgust with her own "loathsome thoughts" and the artificiality of society. She finds solace in a new friendship with Varenka, a philanthropic Russian girl, and becomes fascinated by Madame Stahl, a highly religious invalid. Kitty attempts to emulate Varenka's life of service, but her father, Prince Shtcherbatsky, returns and, with his cynical humor, shatters her idealized view of Madame Stahl, revealing her as a vain woman with short legs. Kitty realizes her attempts at self-improvement were "sham."

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's confession of infidelity, is initially furious and decides on a divorce. However, his feelings of pity for Anna during her illness, and the "joy of forgiveness," lead him to a spiritual transformation. He forgives Anna and Vronsky, and feels a peculiar tenderness for the newborn baby, who is not his. He becomes deeply involved in Seryozha's education and philanthropic work. Countess Lidia Ivanovna, a friend of Alexey Alexandrovitch, supports his new spiritual path and takes over the management of his household. She tells Seryozha his mother is dead.

Vronsky, after shooting himself in despair over Anna's illness and Alexey Alexandrovitch's magnanimity, recovers. He feels his shame is "washed away" and decides to accept an appointment in Tashkend, renouncing Anna. However, Betsy informs him that Alexey Alexandrovitch has agreed to a divorce. Vronsky, forgetting his resolutions, rushes to Anna. They reconcile, and Anna declares, "Yes, you have conquered me, and I am yours." She is concerned about Seryozha and refuses to consider a divorce if it means losing her son. Vronsky, sacrificing his ambition, declines the Tashkend appointment and retires from the army. Anna and Vronsky go abroad without a divorce, having abandoned the idea.

**PART THREE**

Sergey Ivanovitch visits Levin in the country. Levin is uncomfortable with his brother's idealized view of peasant life and his own inability to reconcile his intellectual pursuits with practical farming. Levin is consumed by his new system of agriculture, based on understanding the laborer's character. He is frustrated by the peasants' resistance to new methods.

Levin is delighted when Kitty, now his wife, insists on accompanying him to his dying brother Nikolay's bedside, despite his initial objections. Kitty, with her practical and compassionate nature, takes charge of Nikolay's care, bringing order and comfort to his sickroom, much to Levin's astonishment and relief. Nikolay dies, and Levin, witnessing his wife's strength and love, finds solace and a new understanding of life and death. He realizes that love saves him from despair and that Kitty is pregnant.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, now alone with Seryozha, struggles with his new life. He is overwhelmed by domestic details and the contempt he perceives from others. Countess Lidia Ivanovna becomes his confidante, offering spiritual guidance and taking over his household. She reinforces his belief in a new, mystical form of Christianity and his "delusion of salvation." She intercepts a letter from Anna asking to see Seryozha, telling Anna there will be "no answer" to avoid causing Alexey Alexandrovitch further pain.

Anna and Vronsky, living in Italy, are initially happy. Vronsky pursues painting, and Mihailov, a talented Russian artist, paints Anna's portrait, which is greatly admired. However, Vronsky's interest in art wanes, and he realizes his life with Anna is becoming tedious. They decide to return to Russia.

**PART FOUR**

Levin and Kitty are married. Their honeymoon is a period of unexpected quarrels and adjustments, as Levin realizes married life is far from his idealized dreams. He is frustrated by Kitty's focus on domestic details and her occasional jealousy. However, they reconcile, finding deeper happiness. Levin continues his work on his book about agriculture, now seeing it as a necessary balance to his happy personal life. He develops a theory that Russian agriculture suffers from imported Western civilization and that the Russian laborer has a unique relationship to the land.

Anna and Vronsky return to Petersburg. Vronsky tries to re-enter society with Anna, but quickly realizes that while society is open to him, it is closed to her due to their irregular position. His cousin Betsy and sister-in-law Varya refuse to fully embrace Anna. Anna, meanwhile, is tormented by the separation from Seryozha. She tries to see him but is thwarted by Countess Lidia Ivanovna. On Seryozha's birthday, Anna secretly visits him, finding him grown and changed. Their reunion is deeply emotional, but she is forced to leave when Alexey Alexandrovitch arrives. She is overwhelmed by guilt and despair.

Vronsky is increasingly frustrated by Anna's jealousy and the indefiniteness of their position. He proposes they get a divorce and marry, but Anna is reluctant to leave Seryozha. She fears losing his love and feels trapped. She experiences a recurring nightmare of a peasant muttering French words. She tells Vronsky she is pregnant and believes she will die in childbirth.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after his spiritual transformation, is initially willing to grant Anna a divorce but is swayed by Countess Lidia Ivanovna's arguments against it, particularly regarding Seryozha's welfare. He refuses the divorce, insisting on maintaining the "external forms of propriety." He is increasingly absorbed in his official duties and his new, mystical religious beliefs.

**PART FIVE**

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow, awaiting the birth of their child. Kitty is calm and happy, embracing her new feeling of motherhood. Levin, however, is restless and bored in the city, finding his intellectual pursuits stifled. He is still troubled by his lack of faith and his past. He meets Vronsky at Princess Marya Borissovna's, but Kitty handles the encounter with composure, much to Levin's relief.

Levin confesses his past promiscuity and unbelief to Kitty, giving her his diary. His unbelief does not bother her, but his past makes her weep. She forgives him, and he feels even more unworthy but cherishes his happiness.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, struggling with debts, seeks a new lucrative government appointment in Petersburg. He also tries to persuade Alexey Alexandrovitch to grant Anna a divorce. Alexey Alexandrovitch, influenced by Countess Lidia Ivanovna and a clairvoyant named Landau (now Count Bezzubov), refuses the divorce, citing religious scruples and the welfare of Seryozha. He believes Anna's actions are a "crime" and she deserves to suffer.

Anna and Vronsky are in Moscow, waiting for the divorce. Anna is increasingly irritable and jealous, feeling Vronsky's love is waning. She blames him for her misery and separation from Seryozha. She threatens to die and reveals her recurring nightmare. Vronsky, frustrated by her accusations, agrees to go to the country with her.

**PART SIX**

Dolly and her children spend the summer at Levin's estate, Pokrovskoe, along with the old princess and Varenka. Levin is initially overwhelmed by the "Shtcherbatsky element" but finds joy in his family life and farming. Kitty, now pregnant, is happy and enjoys her domestic role.

Sergey Ivanovitch, having failed with his book, becomes engrossed in the Slavonic question and the Servian War, seeing it as a manifestation of public opinion. He visits Levin, bringing Katavasov with him. They discuss the war, and Levin argues against it, believing it is not the "will of the people."

Levin, Stiva, and Vassenka Veslovsky go shooting. Vassenka's ineptitude and flirtation with Kitty infuriate Levin, triggering his jealousy. He confronts Kitty, who, though hurt, understands his love. Levin, feeling ashamed of his outburst, sends Veslovsky away.

Dolly visits Anna and Vronsky at Vozdvizhenskoe. She is impressed by their luxurious lifestyle but feels uncomfortable with their irregular situation. Vronsky confides in Dolly, expressing his desire for a divorce to legitimize his daughter (Anna's child) and future children, and to pursue his public duties without the "falsity" of their current life. He asks Dolly to persuade Anna to write to Alexey Alexandrovitch for a divorce.

Anna tells Dolly she has chosen not to have more children, a decision Dolly finds shocking. Anna expresses her despair at her "unnatural" position and her inability to live without Vronsky's love, but also her fear of his waning affection. She feels trapped and miserable. Dolly, saddened by Anna's plight, resolves to return home to her own family.

**PART SEVEN**

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow, still awaiting the birth of their child. Kitty is calm and happy, but Levin is restless and bored. He meets Vronsky at a social gathering, and they exchange polite words, with Levin feeling no hostility. Levin, however, is still troubled by his own lack of faith and the meaninglessness of life.

Kitty goes into labor. Levin experiences intense terror and helplessness, praying to God despite his unbelief. He is overwhelmed by Kitty's suffering but also by her strength and love. Their son, Mitya, is born. Levin feels a profound, almost physical, joy and a new sense of love and apprehension for his child. He realizes that love and life are intertwined with suffering and death, and that his faith, though not intellectual, is real.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, still pursuing his lucrative appointment, visits Alexey Alexandrovitch in Petersburg to press for Anna's divorce. Alexey Alexandrovitch, influenced by Countess Lidia Ivanovna and Landau, refuses the divorce. He believes Anna's actions are a sin and that he is acting according to Christian principles by not granting it. He has become an ardent adherent of a new mystical interpretation of Christianity.

Anna and Vronsky, now in Moscow, are increasingly estranged. Anna's jealousy and Vronsky's growing weariness lead to constant quarrels. Anna feels his love is waning and that he despises her. She is tormented by the thought of losing him and her son, Seryozha. She decides that death is the only escape from her misery and the only way to punish Vronsky and regain his love. She goes to the railway station, remembering the man crushed by the train when she first met Vronsky. In a moment of despair, she throws herself under an approaching train. The light in her eyes flickers and is "quenched forever."

**PART EIGHT**

Two months after Anna's death, Sergey Ivanovitch's book, "Sketch of a Survey of the Principles and Forms of Government in Europe and Russia," is published but receives little attention. A critical article, written by a young invalid whom Sergey Ivanovitch had once corrected, ridicules his work. Sergey Ivanovitch is disappointed but soon becomes engrossed in the Slavonic question and the Servian War, finding a new purpose in expressing "public opinion."

Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov travel to Levin's country estate. On the train, they observe volunteers going to Servia. Sergey Ivanovitch meets Vronsky at a station. Vronsky, aged and worn by suffering, is also going to Servia, having taken a squadron at his own expense. He tells Sergey Ivanovitch that life is "worth nothing" to him and he is glad to have something to "give my life for." He is haunted by the memory of Anna's death.

Levin, at home, is still struggling with his newfound faith. He is drawn into an argument with Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov about the Servian War and the "will of the people." Levin argues that war is wrong and that the people do not truly understand or support it. A storm breaks, and Levin, fearing for Kitty and Mitya, is relieved to find them safe. He reflects on his love for his family and his faith, which, though not intellectual, gives his life meaning.

Levin attends the provincial elections with Sergey Ivanovitch. He is bored by the political maneuvering and the "nonsense" of the proceedings. Vronsky is also present, having come to support Nevyedovsky, the new liberal candidate for marshal of the province. Levin and Vronsky meet, and Levin, trying to be friendly, makes a clumsy remark about justices of the peace. Nevyedovsky is elected, and Vronsky celebrates his success, finding a new interest in public life.

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow, where Kitty is expecting their second child. Levin is still wrestling with his spiritual doubts and the practicalities of his estate. He is also troubled by his financial situation. Kitty, however, is calm and happy, embracing her role as a mother. She is not afraid of childbirth.

The text concludes with Levin's deep internal monologue. He has found a profound, non-rational faith that gives his life meaning and purpose. He acknowledges his imperfections and the ongoing struggles of life but feels a "positive meaning of goodness" in every moment. He is at peace, despite the insoluble questions of life and death, because he has found God through his heart and love.

The story begins on a hot July evening with a young man named Raskolnikov leaving his garret in S. Place. He is deeply in debt to his landlady and avoids meeting her, feeling irritable and isolated due to his poverty and hypochondria. He is contemplating "a thing like that," which he initially dismisses as a fantasy but now sees as a serious endeavor. He is concerned about his worn-out hat making him too noticeable.

He walks to a large house for a "rehearsal" of his project, noting that a German clerk is moving out, leaving only an old woman on the fourth floor. He rings the bell of the old woman, Alyona Ivanovna, a sixty-year-old pawnbroker. He introduces himself as a student and offers an old silver watch to pawn. Alyona Ivanovna, who is suspicious and calculates a meager sum, reminds him his previous pledge is due. He accepts the money, but before leaving, he casually asks if her sister is always with her. She questions his business. Raskolnikov leaves in a state of agitation, feeling intense repulsion for the "atrocious thing" he is planning. He enters a tavern, drinks beer, and briefly feels better, dismissing his dark thoughts.

In the tavern, a drunk, retired government clerk named Marmeladov approaches Raskolnikov. Marmeladov delivers a long, solemn monologue about his extreme poverty, his alcoholism, and the suffering of his family. He reveals that his daughter, Sonia, has been forced into prostitution to support them, and his wife, Katerina Ivanovna, a proud and sickly woman, has been reduced to despair. Marmeladov confesses to stealing his wife's money, including Sonia's earnings, to drink. He recounts how Sonia silently placed 30 roubles on the table, and Katerina Ivanovna knelt and kissed her feet. He asks Raskolnikov to accompany him home.

At Marmeladov's squalid lodging in Kozel’s house, Katerina Ivanovna, emaciated and coughing, screams at her husband for drinking away their money and selling his clothes. She drags him by the hair, while he calls it a "consolation." The terrified children cry. Katerina Ivanovna then turns on Raskolnikov, accusing him of drinking with her husband. As he leaves, Raskolnikov secretly places some coppers on the window, then regrets it, but dismisses the thought. He reflects on Sonia's sacrifice and the nature of humanity.

The next day, Raskolnikov wakes late in his tiny, dirty room. His landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, is threatening to complain to the police about his unpaid rent. Nastasya, the servant, brings him a letter from his mother, Pulcheria Alexandrovna. The letter informs him that his sister, Dounia, has been working as a governess for the Svidrigaïlovs, where Mr. Svidrigaïlov made "infamous proposals" to her. Dounia was unjustly accused by Mr. Svidrigaïlov's wife, Marfa Petrovna, but later cleared by Mr. Svidrigaïlov himself, who provided proof of her innocence. Dounia is now engaged to Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, forty-five-year-old counsellor, who expects a submissive wife. Dounia and their mother are coming to Petersburg, and Luzhin has offered to pay some expenses. His mother hopes Luzhin will help Raskolnikov with his career.

Raskolnikov is enraged by the letter, seeing Dounia's marriage as a sacrifice for his sake. He vows to prevent it, but questions his ability to do so, realizing he is a burden. He recalls Marmeladov's despairing question about having "nowhere to turn." His "plan" to kill the old pawnbroker resurfaces as a menacing reality. He then encounters a young, drunk girl on a boulevard and attempts to protect her from a gentleman (Svidrigaïlov), giving a policeman money to take her home. However, he quickly retracts, telling the policeman to let them be, questioning his right to interfere. He then remembers he was going to see his old university comrade, Razumihin, for work.

He decides against visiting Razumihin, thinking he will go "after It," after his plan is executed. He wanders aimlessly, feeling feverish, and falls asleep in a park. He has a vivid nightmare of a peasant, Mikolka, brutally beating and killing an old mare. He wakes in terror, realizing the dream's connection to his own murderous intent. He feels he cannot commit the act and experiences a moment of relief and freedom. However, on his way home, he overhears Lizaveta, the pawnbroker's sister, arranging to be away the next day at seven o'clock, leaving Alyona Ivanovna alone. This "chance" encounter solidifies his resolve.

The next morning, Raskolnikov, still feverish, prepares for the murder. He makes a noose for the axe and retrieves a fake pledge. He attempts to steal an axe from his landlady's kitchen but finds Nastasya there. He then finds an axe in the porter's room and hides it. He arrives at Alyona Ivanovna's flat at seven o'clock. She opens the door, and he enters, presenting the fake pledge. While she is distracted trying to untie it, he strikes her head with the axe, killing her. He then finds her keys and discovers a strong-box full of gold and jewels. As he is collecting the valuables, Lizaveta unexpectedly enters. In a panic, he kills her too with the axe. Overwhelmed by fear and loathing, he washes the axe and his hands. He realizes the outer door was left open. He hears two men (Koch and a young man) knocking and shouting at the old woman's door, realizing someone is inside. He hides in an empty flat on the second floor while they go upstairs, then slips away unseen. He returns to his room, exhausted.

Raskolnikov wakes up in a fever, realizing he left the stolen items in his pockets. He hides them in a hole in his wall. He is summoned to the police office for an IOU debt to his landlady. He is terrified, thinking it's about the murder, but feels immense relief when he realizes it's only the debt. He argues with the assistant superintendent, Ilya Petrovitch, and explains his IOU. He faints during a discussion about the murder, overhearing that the painter Nikolay has been accused. He leaves the police station, convinced they suspect him.

He frantically hides the stolen items under a stone in a deserted courtyard. He then visits Razumihin, who is concerned about his illness and offers him translation work. Raskolnikov refuses, saying he wants no one's help. On the Nikolaevsky Bridge, he throws a 20-copeck coin he received from a charitable woman into the Neva, feeling he has "cut himself off from everyone." He returns home and is woken by the sounds of Ilya Petrovitch beating his landlady. Nastasya tells him he is imagining it, that it's "the blood crying in your ears." He falls unconscious.

He wakes up to Razumihin, Zossimov (a doctor), and a messenger delivering 35 roubles from his mother. Razumihin reveals he has paid off Raskolnikov's IOU and bought him new clothes. He tells Raskolnikov that in his delirium, he raved about "earrings and chains" and his sock. Raskolnikov is alarmed. Later, he goes to a restaurant, reads newspaper accounts of the murder, and then confronts Zametov, the head clerk. He subtly implies his guilt, describing how he would hide stolen items, and then whispers, "And what if it was I who murdered the old woman and Lizaveta?" Zametov is terrified. Raskolnikov pays with the money from his mother, showing it to Zametov. He then encounters Razumihin, who is furious about his disappearance. Raskolnikov tells Razumihin he wants to be alone.

Raskolnikov then finds himself at the murder scene, now being redecorated. He rings the bell repeatedly, feeling the terror return. He tells the workmen he is looking for a flat and asks about the blood. He gives his name and address to the porter and others. The porter, prompted by a man in a long coat, flings Raskolnikov into the street. He then witnesses Marmeladov being run over and killed. He identifies Marmeladov and insists he be taken to his lodging, giving Katerina Ivanovna 20 roubles for the funeral. Sonia arrives, dressed in her gaudy attire, and Katerina Ivanovna, in despair, hands her children over to Sonia before dying. Svidrigaïlov appears and tells Raskolnikov he heard everything from next door and will provide for the children and Sonia, using the 10,000 roubles he had intended for Dounia.

Raskolnikov enters a period of mental fog. He meets Svidrigaïlov again, who confirms he overheard Raskolnikov's confession to Sonia. Svidrigaïlov, who has also seen ghosts of his deceased wife, Marfa Petrovna, reveals his cynical philosophy of life, his past depravity, and his intention to marry a sixteen-year-old girl. He offers Dounia 10,000 roubles (and reveals Marfa Petrovna left her 3,000 roubles in her will) to break off her engagement to Luzhin. Raskolnikov is disgusted but recognizes Svidrigaïlov's power.

Dounia and Pulcheria Alexandrovna break off the engagement with Luzhin after he insults Raskolnikov and attempts to frame Sonia for theft. Lebeziatnikov exposes Luzhin's scheme, revealing he saw Luzhin plant the 100-rouble note on Sonia. Luzhin leaves, filled with hatred. Katerina Ivanovna, driven to madness by her misfortunes, takes her children into the street to beg, but collapses and dies from consumption. Svidrigaïlov arranges her funeral and places the children in an orphanage, settling 1,500 roubles on each. He tells Raskolnikov he is doing this with the money he intended for Dounia, repeating Raskolnikov's own cynical words about "lice" and "humanity."

Raskolnikov, realizing Svidrigaïlov overheard his confession, confronts him. Svidrigaïlov confirms he heard everything from his adjoining room. Svidrigaïlov, after a final, disturbing conversation with Raskolnikov, gives his fiancée 15,000 roubles and then commits suicide by shooting himself in the head in front of a soldier.

Raskolnikov, after a final, tormented conversation with his mother and sister, where he struggles to express his love and his burden, tells them he must leave. He gives Dounia a portrait of his deceased fiancée. He then goes to Sonia, who has been waiting for him. He confesses to her that he is the murderer of Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta. He explains his theory of "extraordinary" men having the right to transgress moral laws, and his desire to prove himself a "man" rather than a "louse." Sonia, horrified but compassionate, urges him to confess publicly, to "suffer and expiate your sin." He resists, saying he is not a "louse" and will fight them. Sonia offers him her cypress wood cross.

He goes to the police station. On the way, he sees Sonia following him. He bows down in the Hay Market, kissing the earth, but the words "I am a murderer" die on his lips due to the mocking crowd. He enters the police office and, finding Ilya Petrovitch, confesses to killing the old pawnbroker and her sister Lizaveta with an axe.

In the Epilogue, Raskolnikov is confined in a Siberian prison. His trial was straightforward due to his clear confession. The court attributes his crime to "temporary mental derangement" and "homicidal mania" because he made no use of the stolen money and trinkets, which were found under a stone. He is sentenced to eight years of penal servitude. Razumihin and Dounia marry, planning to move to Siberia in five years. Raskolnikov's mother dies of brain fever, having suspected her son's terrible fate. Sonia follows Raskolnikov to Siberia, visiting him regularly. The other convicts dislike Raskolnikov, calling him an "infidel," but they love Sonia. Raskolnikov remains sullen and unrepentant, still believing his crime was a "blunder" rather than a moral failing. He has a dream of a global plague that makes everyone mad. After a long illness, he recovers. One day, at work on the river bank, he sees Sonia. He is suddenly overcome with emotion, falls at her feet, and weeps. He realizes he loves her and that a new life is beginning for him. He feels a profound change, a "resurrection into a new life," and that "life had stepped into the place of theory." He has Sonia's New Testament under his pillow, and though he hasn't opened it, he wonders if her convictions and aspirations can now be his. The story ends with the beginning of his gradual renewal and regeneration.

Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer officially known as von Aschenbach after his fiftieth birthday, takes a long walk in Munich one spring afternoon in 19--. Overwrought from his demanding work, he is unable to find rest and hopes that fresh air will rejuvenate him. While waiting for a tram at the North Cemetery, he notices an unusually dressed, red-haired man whose appearance sparks in him a sudden, intense desire for travel, a "youthful longing after far-off places," which he recognizes as an urge to escape the "steady drudgery" of his work. Despite his previous disinterest in extensive travel and his current artistic discontent, he decides to take a three-to-four-week trip to a pleasant southern resort.

The narrative then delves into Aschenbach's background, detailing his disciplined life as an artist. Born in Silesia to a family of public servants, with a more sensuous strain from his Bohemian mother, he achieved early fame despite a frail constitution. He was known for his rigorous dedication to his craft, building his epic works "layer by layer." His art often explored a "new hero-type" characterized by "intellectual and youthful masculinity" that gracefully confronts adversity. After a youthful period of skepticism, he embraced dignity and a "reborn ingenuousness," which coincided with a heightened appreciation for beauty in his work. He was knighted on his fiftieth birthday and settled in Munich. His marriage ended with his wife's death, leaving him with a married daughter but no son. His face, marked by his art, reflected a life of "imaginary and spiritual adventures."

About two weeks after his walk in Munich, Aschenbach departs. He travels by night train to Trieste, then by ship to Pola, seeking something foreign. However, he finds the Adriatic island he chose dissatisfying due to the weather and atmosphere, realizing his true destination is Venice. He quickly arranges passage on an old, decrepit Italian ship. On board, he encounters a dirty, hunchbacked sailor and a circus-director-like ticket seller. He also observes a group of young clerks, one of whom, a boisterous "youth" in fashionable attire, Aschenbach realizes with "horror" is an old man disguised with paint, a wig, and false teeth. This encounter leaves him feeling a "dream-like estrangement."

The ship sails through grey, damp weather, and Aschenbach falls asleep. At noon, he eats a poor meal, then returns to the deck, hoping for brighter skies over Venice, but the weather remains dreary. As they approach Venice, he reflects on the city's poetic allure. The ship waits for a health department barque. During this delay, he again observes the disguised old man, now painfully drunk, swaying and making suggestive gestures, his false teeth falling out. Aschenbach feels a "numbness" and a sense of the world distorting into the grotesque.

Upon arrival, Aschenbach requests a gondola to take him to the steamer dock for the Lido. The same old man from the ship attempts a drunken farewell. Aschenbach boards a black gondola, feeling a "shudder" and associating the craft with death. The gondolier, a brutal-looking man, rows him towards the open sea instead of the requested steamer dock, insisting Aschenbach is going to the Lido. Aschenbach, feeling the gondolier's insolence and his own inertia, yields. After a brief encounter with musical brigands, they arrive at the Lido dock. Aschenbach goes to get change to pay the gondolier, but when he returns, the gondola and gondolier have vanished. An old man at the dock informs him the gondolier was unlicensed. Aschenbach proceeds to his beach hotel.

In his hotel room, Aschenbach reflects on how loneliness magnifies strange experiences. He has tea on the terrace and later, in the lobby, observes other guests. He is particularly struck by a Polish family, especially a fourteen-year-old boy named Tadzio, whose "absolutely beautiful" face, with honey-colored hair and "godlike seriousness," reminds him of Greek sculpture. He notes the boy's pampered appearance contrasts sharply with his sisters' severe attire. Aschenbach, as an artist, feels a deep sympathy for this aristocratic beauty. Tadzio's eyes meet Aschenbach's before the family enters the dining room. Aschenbach dines, regretting the distance from their table, and spends the night dreaming.

The next day, the weather remains poor, and Aschenbach feels depressed, considering leaving Venice due to its unhealthy effect on him. At breakfast, he sees Tadzio, whose entrance is marked by "extraordinary charm" and "godlike beauty." Aschenbach goes to the beach and decides to stay, finding solace in the view. He observes Tadzio playing, noting his disdain for a Russian family. He deduces the boy's name is Tadzio. He watches Tadzio swim, emerging from the sea like a "frail god," which evokes a "sense of myth" in Aschenbach. He feels a "paternal affection" for the boy. Later, in the lift, Aschenbach sees Tadzio up close and notices his "jagged and pale" teeth, concluding he is "very frail" and "sickly," and "will not grow old," a thought that brings him a peculiar "gratification."

That afternoon, Aschenbach visits Venice, but the sultry, odorous air and crowds depress him, causing physical discomfort. He decides he must leave, planning to go to another watering place. He returns to the hotel, announces his departure, settles his accounts, and prepares his luggage. The next morning, he regrets his hasty decision as the air feels fresher. At breakfast, hotel staff pressure him to leave quickly, but he insists on finishing his meal. Tadzio passes him, their eyes meeting. Aschenbach silently bids Tadzio farewell. On the steamboat, he experiences intense regret and realizes how deeply attached he is to Venice, feeling it would be "insufferable" never to see it again.

At the station, he learns his trunk has been mistakenly sent to Como. This error, to his "adventurous delight," provides an excuse to return to the Lido. He arranges for his ticket to be redeemed and his trunk recovered, and within minutes, he is back on the Grand Canal, returning to the hotel. He finds this turn of events comically dreamlike and a stroke of fate. Back in his room, he sees Tadzio returning from the sea and realizes Tadzio was the true reason it was so hard to leave. He accepts this realization with a "spontaneous act of welcome."

Days turn into weeks. Aschenbach, now settled indefinitely, is enchanted by the relaxed pace of life and the constant presence of Tadzio. He rises early to watch Tadzio on the beach, observing his every movement and finding "godlike sculpture" in his form. He connects Tadzio's beauty to ancient Greek philosophy, particularly the Socratic dialogue on Eros and beauty as the path to the spiritual. Inspired, he writes a short, acclaimed prose piece, finding "Eros in the word." He attempts to approach Tadzio on the beach but is overcome by breathlessness and fear, passing him with bowed head. He recognizes his "intoxication" is too precious to abandon.

He sends for more money, his only concern being Tadzio's departure. He spends his days in a state of happy unrest, waking at dawn to watch the sunrise, which he interprets as the rising of Eros. He sees Tadzio in the park and imagines him as Hyacinth, loved by gods. He notes the unspoken familiarity between them, with Tadzio sometimes walking unnecessarily close to his table on the beach, and their glances meeting with serious intensity. One evening, Tadzio smiles at Aschenbach, a "deep, fascinated, magnetic smile" like Narcissus. Overwhelmed, Aschenbach retreats to the dark park and whispers, "I love you!"

In his fourth week, Aschenbach notices fewer guests and a strange, sickly smell in Venice. He learns from the hotel barber about "the plague," though the barber is evasive. In Venice, he confirms the smell and sees municipal warnings about gastric diseases, realizing the authorities are covering up a serious epidemic. He reads newspapers, finding official denials and vague statistics. He feels a "dark contentment" that the city's "wicked secret" aligns with his own hidden passion, and he fears Tadzio leaving more than the plague.

He begins to stalk Tadzio, following him through the city's labyrinthine streets, even secretly pursuing him in a gondola. He returns late one evening and, in a state of "utter drunkenness," lays his head against Tadzio's room door. He has moments of lucidity, questioning his actions, but rationalizes his infatuation as a form of artistic heroism. He learns the full truth about the Indian cholera epidemic from an English travel clerk: it is widespread, highly fatal, and the Venetian authorities are suppressing the information to protect tourism, leading to social decay and a rise in crime.

The Englishman advises him to leave immediately, but Aschenbach, intoxicated by his "possession of the truth" and valuing the "advantages of chaos" over prudence, decides to remain silent and stay in Venice. That night, he has a "frightful dream" of a Bacchic orgy, a frenzied, lewd experience where he is drawn into the "unchastity and fury of decay," belonging to a "foreign god." He awakens shattered, no longer caring about appearances. Guests flee, but Tadzio's family remains. Aschenbach, in his infatuation, sees the "atrocious" possibilities in the plague-ridden city, with "laws of morality dropped away."

He attempts to rejuvenate his appearance to please Tadzio, visiting the barber to have his hair dyed black, curled, and his skin treated with cosmetics to make him look younger. The barber remarks, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly." Aschenbach, now made up, feels "happy as in a dream." He continues to track Tadzio through the diseased city, getting lost and exhausted. Tadzio, aware of Aschenbach's pursuit, occasionally looks back, confirming he is being followed but "did not betray him."

One afternoon, Aschenbach loses sight of Tadzio. Exhausted and feverish, he buys and eats overly ripe strawberries. He sits on steps in a deserted square, recalling his earlier plans to flee. In a semi-slumber, he has a final internal monologue, a distorted philosophical reflection on beauty, Eros, and the artist's perilous path through the senses to the spiritual. He concludes that poets are necessarily "lascivious" and "adventurers in emotion," their mastery a "farce," and that form and openness, while yielding beauty, also lead to "intoxication and to desire," and ultimately to the "precipice." He ends by saying, "And now I am going, Phaedrus. You stay here; and when you no longer see me, then you go too."

A few days later, Aschenbach feels unwell, experiencing vertigo and a sense of bafflement. He learns the Polish family is leaving after lunch. He goes to the beach, which now looks autumnal and abandoned. Tadzio and his few remaining companions are playing unsupervised. Tadzio is forced into a wrestling match by Jaschu, who then presses Tadzio's face into the sand, nearly strangling him. Aschenbach, enraged, is about to intervene when Jaschu releases Tadzio. Tadzio, pale and disheveled, slowly walks away from his companions towards the sea. He stands on a sand-bank, facing the open sea, then turns and looks over his shoulder towards the shore. Aschenbach, watching, sees Tadzio's "pale and lovely lure" smiling and nodding to him, signaling him to "come out," guiding him towards "egregious promises." Aschenbach, "as often before," stands up to follow him.

Minutes later, Aschenbach collapses in his chair. He is brought to his room. On the same day, the world receives news of his death.

The story begins by introducing a gentleman from a village in La Mancha, nearing fifty years old, of hardy build, who lives with a housekeeper, a niece, and a lad. He spends most of his time reading books of chivalry with such passion that he neglects his estate and sells land to acquire more books. He particularly enjoys the works of Feliciano de Silva. Through excessive reading, he loses his wits, believing the fantastical events in these books to be true. He argues with his village curate and barber about the merits of famous knights.

Driven by his madness, he decides to become a knight-errant. He cleans his great-grandfather's rusty armor, improvises a helmet from pasteboard (which he tests and breaks, then reinforces), and spends four days naming his old horse, Rocinante. He then names himself Don Quixote of La Mancha, following the example of Amadis of Gaul. Finally, he chooses a lady to be the object of his devotion, a local farm-girl named Aldonza Lorenzo, whom he renames Dulcinea del Toboso.

Don Quixote embarks on his first sally one morning. He soon realizes he has not been formally dubbed a knight. He resolves to be knighted by the first person he encounters. He mistakes an inn for a castle, two young women at the door for fair maidens, and a swineherd's horn for a dwarf's trumpet. The innkeeper, amused by Don Quixote's appearance and speech, plays along, calling himself a "Castellan." Don Quixote refuses to remove his helmet, which is tied on, and is fed by one of the girls. He believes the stockfish served is trout and the sowgelder's pipe is castle music. Still, he is distressed by not being knighted.

That night, Don Quixote kneels before the innkeeper, demanding to be dubbed a knight. The innkeeper, still playing along, recounts his own fabricated past as a knight-errant and agrees to the ceremony, claiming there is no chapel but the courtyard will suffice. He advises Don Quixote to carry money, clean shirts, and ointment. Don Quixote places his armor by a well. When a carrier tries to move the armor to water his mules, Don Quixote strikes him with his lance, leaving him senseless. Another carrier suffers the same fate. Other carriers stone Don Quixote, but he defends his armor. The innkeeper intervenes, explaining Don Quixote is mad. To end the commotion, the innkeeper performs a burlesque knighting ceremony, using his account-book as a prayer book and giving Don Quixote a blow to the neck and a slap on the shoulder. The two girls gird on his sword and spur, and Don Quixote renames them Doña Tolosa and Doña Molinera. Don Quixote, now a knight, departs at dawn without paying.

Recalling the innkeeper's advice, Don Quixote decides to return home for money and a squire. On the way, he hears cries and finds a farmer flogging a boy named Andres. Don Quixote, believing the farmer to be a "discourteous knight," orders him to pay Andres his wages. The farmer, terrified, agrees. Don Quixote leaves, satisfied. However, the farmer immediately flogs Andres again, mocking Don Quixote. Andres vows to seek Don Quixote's help. Unaware of this, Don Quixote congratulates himself. He then encounters a group of Toledo traders and demands they confess Dulcinea's unparalleled beauty. When one trader makes a jest, Don Quixote charges, but Rocinante stumbles, throwing him to the ground. A muleteer beats him severely with his own lance, leaving him battered.

A peasant from his village, Pedro Alonso, finds the injured Don Quixote, who, in his delirium, mistakes the peasant for the Marquis of Mantua and recites ballads. The peasant recognizes him and helps him onto his ass, leading him home. At Don Quixote's house, the curate, barber, housekeeper, and niece are discussing his disappearance and blaming his books. Don Quixote, still delusional, claims his injuries are from fighting giants. The curate resolves to burn Don Quixote's books.

The curate and barber proceed to Don Quixote's library. They burn many books of chivalry, sparing only a few, such as "Amadis of Gaul," "Palmerin of England," and "Tirante el Blanco," for various reasons. Don Quixote's shouts interrupt their task. He is found raving about a tourney. They force him back to bed. That night, the housekeeper burns the remaining books. The curate and barber then wall up the room, telling Don Quixote that a magician, Friston, carried the books and room away. Don Quixote believes this, thinking Friston is his enemy who seeks to thwart his glory.

Don Quixote remains home for fifteen days, then persuades a farm laborer, Sancho Panza, to become his squire, promising him the governorship of an island. They prepare for a new sally, with Sancho bringing his ass, Dapple. They depart secretly. Sancho expresses his eagerness to become a governor.

They encounter windmills, which Don Quixote believes are giants. Despite Sancho's protests, Don Quixote charges, breaking his lance and falling. He blames Friston for transforming the giants. He then makes a new lance from an oak branch. He instructs Sancho not to intervene in fights with knights. They next encounter two Benedictine friars and a coach with a lady. Don Quixote believes the friars are magicians abducting a princess. He attacks, unhorsing one friar. Sancho attempts to strip the fallen friar, but the friars' muleteers beat Sancho severely. Don Quixote declares the lady free and commands her to go to El Toboso to present herself to Dulcinea. A Biscayan squire challenges Don Quixote. They fight, and Don Quixote is wounded in the ear and helmet. He defeats the Biscayan, making him promise to go to Dulcinea.

The narrator explains he found the rest of the story in Arabic. The battle concludes with Don Quixote severely wounding the Biscayan, who yields. Sancho, recovered, asks for his island. Don Quixote says it was a "cross-roads" adventure, not an island one, but promises future rewards. Sancho expresses fear of the Holy Brotherhood. Don Quixote mentions his Balsam of Fierabras, a miraculous cure. Sancho wants the recipe. Don Quixote, seeing his broken helmet, swears an oath not to eat at a tablecloth or embrace his wife until he gets a new helmet. Sancho worries about the oath's impracticality. They eat Sancho's provisions and spend the night with goatherds.

One of the goatherds tells them the story of Chrysostom, a student-shepherd who died of love for Marcela, a beautiful shepherdess who chose a life of solitude and rejected all suitors. Don Quixote resolves to attend the burial. At the burial, Marcela appears and eloquently defends her right to freedom and her blamelessness in Chrysostom's death. Don Quixote, impressed, defends Marcela and forbids anyone from following her.

Don Quixote and Sancho search for Marcela, then rest. Rocinante tries to mate with Yanguesan ponies, who kick him. Don Quixote and Sancho are beaten by the Yanguesan carriers. Sancho is in pain and asks for the balsam. Don Quixote blames himself for fighting non-knights and tells Sancho he should fight "rabble" in the future. Sancho refuses to fight. Don Quixote, injured, is carried on Dapple. He finds a valise with gold crowns and a love letter, concluding it belongs to a despairing lover. They then see a ragged man leaping among rocks, whom Don Quixote believes is the owner.

The ragged man, Cardenio, reveals his identity and tells his story: he loved Luscinda, who was forced to marry Don Fernando, the duke's son. Don Fernando had previously seduced Dorothea, a noble maiden, under promise of marriage. Cardenio witnessed Luscinda's forced wedding, where she fainted and a letter was found revealing her prior marriage to Cardenio. Cardenio, in despair, fled to the mountains. Don Quixote, enraged by Cardenio's story of Queen Madasima, attacks Cardenio, who, in a fit of madness, beats Don Quixote and Sancho.

The curate and barber, searching for Don Quixote, find Cardenio. Dorothea, disguised as a peasant, appears and tells her story, revealing she is the maiden seduced by Don Fernando. Cardenio and Dorothea realize their shared plight and a possible way to reclaim their loves. Sancho returns, having left Don Quixote doing penance. Dorothea agrees to pose as Princess Micomicona, a distressed maiden seeking Don Quixote's help against a giant. Don Quixote accepts her plea, promising to restore her kingdom. Sancho is overjoyed, dreaming of becoming a king. Don Quixote, however, reaffirms his fidelity to Dulcinea, causing Sancho to argue and be beaten by his master. Ricote, a Morisco, appears, riding Dapple, whom Sancho reclaims.

Sancho, having failed to deliver Don Quixote's letter to Dulcinea, invents a story about finding her sifting wheat and her being enchanted. Don Quixote believes this, attributing it to his enemy enchanters. The curate and barber, still trying to get Don Quixote home, plot to disenchant Dulcinea.

At the duke's castle, Don Quixote is received with great ceremony. He is subjected to a washing ritual. Sancho, offended, refuses. Don Quixote describes Dulcinea's beauty, but says she is enchanted into a peasant. The duchess questions if Dulcinea is imaginary. Don Quixote insists she is real and noble. Sancho, in a rage, is again beaten by Don Quixote for speaking ill of Dulcinea. Don Quixote is then pinched and beaten by the duchess and Altisidora (a damsel in the castle) in disguise, who are playing a trick on him.

Sancho, appointed governor of the island of Barataria, is subjected to a strict diet by Doctor Pedro Recio. He delivers several wise judgments, including the case of the cane with hidden gold and the woman who accused a pig dealer. He makes ordinances for his island. He receives a letter from Don Quixote with advice on governing. Sancho replies, complaining of hunger and the doctor. He is then subjected to a mock invasion and attack, where he is bound between shields and trampled. He resigns his governorship, preferring his freedom.

Sancho, on his way back to Don Quixote, falls into a pit with Dapple. Don Quixote, hearing his cries, rescues him. They then encounter the Knight of the White Moon, who challenges Don Quixote to confess his lady is less beautiful than his own. If Don Quixote loses, he must retire home for a year. Don Quixote accepts and is defeated. The Knight of the White Moon is revealed to be the bachelor Samson Carrasco, who sought to force Don Quixote home to cure his madness. Don Quixote, dejected, agrees to retire.

Don Gregorio, the youth Ana Felix loved, is rescued from Algiers. Ricote and Ana Felix are reunited. Don Quixote and Sancho leave the castle, Don Quixote lamenting his defeat. He proposes they become shepherds for his year of retirement. Sancho agrees, but complains about the hardships. They are stampeded by a drove of pigs.

Back at the duke's castle, Don Quixote is subjected to another trick: Altisidora, feigning death from his coldness, is "resurrected" by Sancho's supposed whipping. Sancho is again reluctant to inflict the lashes, but eventually agrees to a partial whipping, mostly on trees. Don Quixote believes Dulcinea will be disenchanted.

They encounter Don Álvaro Tarfe, a character from the false "Second Part" of Don Quixote's history. Don Álvaro confirms that Don Quixote is not the one he knew, and makes a legal declaration to that effect. Sancho completes his self-flagellation.

Don Quixote and Sancho return to their village. Don Quixote interprets omens negatively. Sancho tries to counter them. At home, Don Quixote falls ill with a fever.
