They break the circle and flee swiftly. The narrator's guide pursues his track, and the narrator follows. Soon, the sound of water is so near that they can barely hear each other.
The narrator describes the sound as that of a river falling from a craggy steep, roaring loudly enough to stun the ear, like the Acquacheta river falling from the Alpine summit.
The narrator has a cord that braced his girdle, which he once used to catch the "painted leopard." At Virgil's command, he unloosens it, gathers it up, and stretches it forth. Virgil turns to the right, casts it down into the deep abyss, and watches it with an earnest eye. The narrator wonders about this strange signal. He muses on the caution needed with those who spy into thoughts.
Virgil says, "Quickly shall come... what I expect, Thine eye discover quickly, that whereof Thy thought is dreaming." The narrator swears by his notes that he saw a shape swimming up through the "gross and murky air," which might have quelled the stoutest heart, like one returning from loosing an anchor or something in the sea, drawing in his feet.

**CANTO XVII**
Virgil addresses the narrator, "Lo! the fell monster with the deadly sting! Who passes mountains, breaks through fenced walls And firm embattled spears, and with his filth Taints all the world!" He beckons the monster to shore.
The "vile image of fraud" (Geryon) appears, its head and upper part on land, but its "bestial train" not on the shore. Its face resembles a "just man," kind and gracious. The rest is serpent, with two shaggy claws reaching to its armpits, and its back, breast, and sides painted with "nodes And orbits." Its tail is upturned with a "venomous fork, With sting like scorpion’s arm’d."
Virgil says they must turn their way to the beast. They shape their course to the right, proceeding ten paces on the verge to escape the flame and burning marl. Arriving at Geryon, the narrator beholds a tribe of spirits seated on the sand near the chasm. Virgil tells him to go and mark their mien, but not to hold long discourse, as he will parley with Geryon to gain the aid of his "strong shoulders."
The narrator walks alone to the extremity of the seventh circle, where the mournful tribe is seated. Their pangs gush forth from their eyes. They alternately ply their hands against the vapors and torrid soil, like dogs in summer against gnats.
The narrator notes the visages of some, but recognizes none. He perceives that each bears a pouch hanging from his neck, marked with various colors and emblems, on which their eye seems to feed. He sees a yellow purse with azure, bearing a lion's countenance. Another, redder than blood, displays a goose. One, bearing a "fat and azure swine Pictur’d on his white scrip," addresses the narrator: "What dost thou in this deep? Go now and know, Since yet thou livest, that my neighbour here Vitaliano on my left shall sit. A Paduan with these Florentines am I. Ofttimes they thunder in mine ears, exclaiming ‘O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch With the three beaks will bring!’" He then writhes his mouth and lolls his tongue out. The narrator, lest he displease Virgil by staying too long, turns back.
He finds Virgil already seated on the "haunch Of the fierce animal." Virgil encourages him, "Be thou stout; be bold. Down such a steep flight must we now descend! Mount thou before: for that no power the tail May have to harm thee, I will be i’ th’ midst." The narrator is terrified, but shame makes him bold. He settles on Geryon's huge shoulders, wishing to say, "Look thou clasp me firm!" but the words fail. Virgil, whose succor he has proved before, embraces him and holds him up, saying, "Geryon! now move thee! be thy wheeling gyres Of ample circuit, easy thy descent. Think on th’ unusual burden thou sustain’st."
Like a small vessel backing out from land, Geryon loosens and turns his forked tail where his breast had been. He steers like an eel, gathering air with retractile claws. The narrator's dread is immense, greater than Phaeton's or Icarus', as he views only the beast and air around him. Geryon slowly wheels downward, unobserved by the narrator except for the wind rising to his face from below.
On their right, the narrator hears a cataract leap with a hideous crash. Bending to explore, he conceives new terror at the steep plunge, seeing flames and hearing wailings. He crouches, trembling, and then distinguishes how their downward course winds by the torment drawing nearer.
Like a weary falcon descending after a fruitless hunt, Geryon lights, placing them on foot at the base of the "deep-furrow’d rock." Discharged of his burden, he springs forward "like an arrow from the string."

**CANTO XVIII**
They are in Malebolge, a place in hell, all rock, dark-stained, circling around. In its midst yawns a "spacious gulf profound." The circle between the gulf and the high craggy banks forms ten trenches, "in its hollow bottom sunk." These are modeled like fosses around a castle, flanked by bridges. Flinty paths advance from the rock's base, crossing the moles and dikes to the gulf.
Dislodged from Geryon's back, they are in this place. Virgil holds his way to the left, and the narrator follows.
On their right, the narrator sees new misery and pains in the first chasm. Naked sinners come toward them from the middle point, moving with a larger stride beyond them. He compares this to Romans during Jubilee, who devise means for thronging multitudes on a bridge, one side fronting the castle, the other the mount.
He sees "Horn’d demons" on the grisly rock, with huge lashes, mercilessly striking the sinners' backs, making them bound at the first stripe. None wait for the second or third.
One sinner meets the narrator's sight. He fixes his gaze. Virgil pauses, allowing him to walk backward a space. The tormented spirit tries to hide his face, but the narrator exclaims, "Thou who dost cast thy eye upon the ground, Unless thy features do belie thee much, Venedico art thou. But what brings thee Into this bitter seas’ning?"
The spirit replies, "Unwillingly I answer to thy words. But thy clear speech... constrains me." He reveals he was the one who led "fair Ghisola To do the Marquis’ will," though fame has spread the shameful tale. He adds that Bologna sends many "barterers" here, more than tongues taught between the Reno and Savena. He says if the narrator needs proof, to remember their "craving thirst for gold."
A demon strikes him with his thong, exclaiming, "Away! corrupter! here Women are none for sale." The narrator joins Virgil, and they reach a rock issuing from the bank. Ascending it, they turn right, departing from the "eternal barriers."
Arriving where the "gaping arch lets pass The scourged souls," Virgil tells the narrator to pause and look at these "miserable others," whose faces he has not yet seen, though they have walked with them. From the old bridge, they eye the pack coming from the other side, excoriated from the lash.
Virgil, unasked, identifies a "lofty shade" tending their way, who seems too woe-begone to weep, yet retains a regal aspect. This is Jason, whose skill won the ram from Colchos. He went to the Lemnian isle, where pitiless women had slain all their males. There, he beguiled Hypsipyle, a young virgin, with "tokens and fair witching words," leaving her pregnant and forlorn. This guilt condemns him. Medea's injuries are also avenged here. All who practiced similar deceit bear him company. Virgil says this much suffices for the first vale.
They reach the next pier, crossing to another arch. In the second chasm, they hear ghosts "jibber in low melancholy sounds," snort with wide-stretched nostrils, and smite themselves with their palms. A scurf from the foul steam hangs encrusting the banks, combating sight and smell.
The depth is so hollow that the narrator can distinguish nothing except from the summit of the rocky span. From there, he sees a crowd immersed in ordure, appearing like "Draff of the human body." He marks one with a grimed head, hard to deem if clerk or layman, who cries, "Why greedily thus bendest more on me, Than on these other filthy ones, thy ken?"
The narrator replies that if his memory is true, he has seen him with dry locks and he is Alessio of Lucca. The spirit, beating on his brain, says, "Me thus low down my flatteries have sunk, Wherewith I ne’er enough could glut my tongue."
Virgil tells the narrator to stretch his face a little to note the visage of a "besotted, sluttish courtezan," who rends herself with defiled nails, now crouching, now risen. This is Thais, the harlot, whose false lip answered her paramour, "Say rather wondrously" to "Thankest me much!" Virgil says their view is satiated.

**CANTO XIX**
The narrator exclaims woe to Simon Magus and his followers, who prostitute "the things of God" for gold and silver. He declares this is the third chasm. They mount the following vault, where the rock impends directly over the chasm's center.
He praises "Wisdom Supreme" for its wonderful art and just allotment of punishment. He sees the "livid stone" full of circular apertures, equal in width, like baptismal fonts in Saint John's dome. He mentions breaking one of these fonts years past to save a drowning infant, wishing this to be a seal to undeceive doubters of his motive. From each aperture emerges a sinner's feet and legs up to the calf, the rest hidden. The soles of their feet are burning, causing their joints to quiver violently. Flames glide from heel to point.
The narrator asks who is "Glancing in fiercer agony, on whom A ruddier flame doth prey?" Virgil offers to carry him down where the bank is least steep, so the spirit can tell his story. The narrator agrees, trusting Virgil's will.
They descend to the depth of the fourth pier, a narrow, perforated strait. Virgil does not set him down until he reaches the orifice of the quivering limb. The narrator addresses the "sad spirit," asking him to speak if he can. He stands like a friar shriving a condemned wretch.
The spirit shouts, "Ha! already standest there? Already standest there, O Boniface! By many a year the writing play’d me false. So early dost thou surfeit with the wealth, For which thou fearedst not in guile to take The lovely lady, and then mangle her?"
The narrator, not understanding, feels mocked. Virgil admonishes him to quickly say, "I am not he, not he, whom thou believ’st." The narrator replies as enjoined.
The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs woefully, asking what the narrator requires. He then reveals that he was robed "in the mighty mantle" (Pope) and was the son of a "she-bear," eager to advance his "whelps" (family), so he "stow’d" his wealth above and himself here. He says the rest, his "predecessors in the guilt Of simony," are dragged under his head, lying along an opening in the rock. He will fall low when the one he mistook the narrator for arrives, but more time has passed since his soul kindled than is his doom to stand. He prophesies that after him, "One yet of deeds more ugly shall arrive, From forth the west, a shepherd without law, Fated to cover both his form and mine." He will be called a "new Jason" and receive favor from "France’s monarch."
The narrator, perhaps presuming too far, asks what treasures Christ demanded from St. Peter when giving him the keys, noting he asked only "Follow me!" and that Peter and the others took no gold or silver for Matthias's replacement. He tells the spirit his punishment is merited and to look well to the "ill-gotten coin." He says if reverence for the keys did not restrain him, he would use severer speech. He blames avarice for casting the world in mourning, treading good, and raising bad men. He says the Evangelist was aware of such shepherds when he saw "her, who sits upon the waves, With kings in filthy whoredom," who "with seven heads tower’d at her birth, And from ten horns her proof of glory drew." He accuses them of making gold and silver their god, differing from idolaters only in worshipping a hundred gods instead of one. He laments, "Ah, Constantine! to how much ill gave birth, Not thy conversion, but that plenteous dower, Which the first wealthy Father gain’d from thee!"
As the narrator sings, the spirit, whether from wrath or conscience, violently springs up, spinning on either sole. Virgil, pleased, catches the narrator in his arms and lifts him, retracing his descent. He carries him without weariness to the summit of the rock, their passage from the fourth to the fifth pier. He gently places his "cherish’d burden" on the rugged rock, a path difficult for a goat.
Thence, another vale appears to the narrator.

**CANTO XX**
The narrator now proceeds to new torments in the twentieth canto. He looks into the depth, moistened with tears, and sees a tribe weeping silently, advancing along the hollow vale like choirs chanting litanies.
As his eye descends, he sees each spirit "wondrously seem’d to be revers’d At the neck-bone, so that the countenance Was from the reins averted." Compelled to advance with backward gait, none can look before him. The narrator leans against a rock and weeps. Virgil exclaims, "What, and art thou too witless as the rest? Here pity most doth show herself alive, When she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, Who with Heaven’s judgment in his passion strives?"
Virgil tells him to raise his head and see Amphiaraus, before whose eyes earth gaped in Thebes, and who now makes his breast his shoulders, looking backward. He points out Tiresias, who changed from male to female and back.
Aruns comes next, "with more his belly facing," who dwelt in a cavern in Luni's mountains, from which he viewed the stars and sea.
Next is Manto, whose "loosen’d tresses overspread Her bosom." She searched many regions and fixed her seat in Virgil's native land (Mantua). Virgil recounts her story: after her father's death, she wandered the world. In Italy, a lake called Benacus lies at the foot of an Alp. Where it drains, it forms the Mincius river, which flows to the Po. Manto saw a "waste And naked" territory amidst the fen, where she remained with her slaves, practicing her arts, and left her body there. Tribes gathered and built a city, calling it Mantua, for her sake. Virgil warns the narrator against other origins assigned to his country.
The narrator accepts Virgil's words as certain and asks if he sees any other spirits of note. Virgil points out Eurypilus, a seer in Aulis, who gave the sign to cut the cable when Greece was emptied of its males. He then points to Michael Scot, slender in shape, "Practis’d in ev’ry slight of magic wile."
He also points out Guido Bonatti and Asdente, who now repents not having tended his thread and cordwain. Next are "wretches, who the needle left, The shuttle and the spindle, and became Diviners," working "baneful witcheries with images and herbs."
Virgil then says they must move on, as "Cain with fork of thorns" (the moon) now confines on either hemisphere, touching the wave beneath Seville's towers, and the moon was round yesternight, serving them well in the gloomy wood. Both move onward.

**CANTO XXI**
They pass from bridge to bridge, with other talk, reaching the summit to view another gap in Malebolge, with "other bootless pangs." Marvelous darkness shadows the place.
The narrator describes the scene like pitch boiling in the Venetian arsenal to smear unsound vessels. Here, by "art divine," a "glutinous thick mass" boils, liming all the shore beneath. He distinguishes nothing but the surge of the boiling. Virgil draws him back, exclaiming, "Mark! mark!"
The narrator turns and sees a "devil black" running up the rock, with fierce cruelty in his look, buoyant wings, and nimble feet. His shoulder is charged with a sinner, held by either haunch, gripping the foot's sinew.
The devil cries to his "keen-talon’d fiends," "Ye of our bridge! Lo! one of Santa Zita’s elders! Him Whelm ye beneath, while I return for more. That land hath store of such. All men are there, Except Bonturo, barterers: of ‘no’ For lucre there an ‘aye’ is quickly made."
He dashes the sinner down, turns, and speeds back. The sinner sinks and then writhes to the surface. The dark demons, shrouded by the bridge, cry, "Here the hallow’d visage saves not: here Is other swimming than in Serchio’s wave. Wherefore if thou desire we rend thee not, Take heed thou mount not o’er the pitch." They grapple him with "more than hundred hooks," shouting, "Cover’d thou must sport thee here; So, if thou canst, in secret mayst thou filch." The narrator compares this to a cook thrusting flesh into a cauldron.
Virgil tells the narrator to hide behind a craggy rock so they don't see him, and not to fear any force or insult, as he is "well advis’d." Virgil passes beyond the bridge's head to the sixth pier, needing a "forehead terror-proof."
The demons rush forth from beneath the arch like dogs on a poor man, pointing their weapons at Virgil. He cries, "Be none of you outrageous: ere your time Dare seize me, come forth from amongst you one, Who having heard my words, decide he then If he shall tear these limbs." They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One demon advances, asking what this turn will avail Virgil.
Virgil replies, "Believ’st thou, Malacoda! I had come Thus far from all your skirmishing secure, without will divine And destiny propitious?" He states Heaven's pleasure is for him to lead another through this wilderness. Malacoda's pride falls, he drops his instrument of torture, and exclaims to the rest, "We have no power To strike him."
Virgil tells the narrator, who is crouching on the bridge, to return safely. The narrator rises and moves with speed, fearing the fiends might break their compact. He compares this to infantry dreading a foe breaking a covenant at Caprona.
The narrator adheres to Virgil's side, watching the fiends. They protrude their hooks, one asking another, "Wilt thou I touch him on the hip?" The reply is, "Even so; nor miss thy aim."
Malacoda, who was conferring with Virgil, turns and tells the demon, "Stay, stay thee, Scarmiglione!" He then tells them that the rock provides no further footing, being "shiver’d to the base Of the sixth arch." But if they wish to proceed, they must go up a cavern, where "another rock will yield you passage safe." He explains that "Yesterday, later by five hours than now, Twelve hundred threescore years and six had fill’d The circuit of their course, since here the way Was broken." He dispatches ten of his scouts to spy if any bask on the surface, telling them to go with the travelers, as they will find them "nothing fell." He names them: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo, Barbariccia (to lead the troop of ten), Libicocco, Draghinazzo, Fang’d Ciriatto, Grafflacane, Farfarello, and Rubicant. He instructs them to search around the bubbling tar and safely lead the travelers where the other crag traverses the dens.
The narrator asks Virgil what a sight this is, wishing not to journey without escort, and noting their snarls and threats. Virgil tells him not to fear, as their gnarls are only "in token of their spite Against the souls, who mourn in torment steep’d."
The demons turn left over the pier, each pressing his tongue between his teeth, looking to their leader for a signal, which he gives with an "obscene triumphant" sound.

**CANTO XXII**
The narrator describes having seen various military maneuvers, but never such a strange formation of horse or foot, or ship, as the ten demons moving with their leader. He calls it a "fearful company."
He gazes earnestly at the pitch to mark everything in the chasm. Like dolphins showing their backs to mariners, some sinners show their backs to ease pain, then hide more nimbly than lightning. Like frogs at a moat's brink, with only jaws out, the sinners stand, but draw back under the wave when Barbariccia approaches.
The narrator sees one sinner who waits. Graffiacan, the nearest fiend, seizes his "clotted locks" and drags him up, making him appear like an otter. The narrator knew their names from when they were chosen. The crew shouts, "O Rubicant! See that his hide thou with thy talons flay."
The narrator asks Virgil who this wretched soul is. Virgil approaches and asks whence he came. The spirit replies he was born in Navarre, his mother placed him in a lord's retinue, as she bore him to a "losel vile." He served King Thibault, then turned to "peculating," for which he gives account in this heat.
Ciriatto, with tusks like a boar, rips him with one. Barbariccia seizes him with both arms, crying, "Stand thou apart, While I do fix him on my prong transpierc’d." He tells Virgil to inquire further before the sinner is rent again. Virgil asks about his partners in guilt from Latian land. The spirit replies he just parted from one not far thence, wishing he were under shelter with him.
Libicocco cries, "Too long we suffer," and seizes his arm with a prong, mangling the sinewy part. Draghinazzo tries to catch him by the thighs, but their chief restrains them. When the strife ceases, Virgil asks about the spirit from whom he parted.
The spirit replies it was "the friar Gomita... He of Gallura, vessel of all guile," who had his master's enemies in hand and dismissed them for money, playing the part of a "barterer to the height." Michel Zanche, chief of Logodoro, herds with him. Sardinia is a constant theme for them. The spirit then trembles, seeing another fiend grin.
The captain rebukes Farfarello, who was about to strike. The quaking spirit then offers to cause Tuscan or Lombard spirits to appear if the fiends bate their fury, promising to make seven appear with his whistle.
Cagnazzo grins deridingly, wagging his head, saying, "Hear his device, Mischievous as he is, to plunge him down." The spirit replies it is "Mischief forsooth extreme, Meant only to procure myself more woe!"
Alichino, gainsaying the rest, says if the spirit casts himself down, he will not chase on foot but beat his plumes above the pitch. He suggests they quit the vantage ground and use the bank as a shield to see if he can prevail.
The narrator notes the new sport. The fiends turn their eyes to the other shore. The spirit of Navarre chooses his time, plants his feet on land, and escapes in one leap. Resentment stings the fiends, especially Alichino, who pursues, crying, "Thou art caught." But terror outstrips him. The sinner plunges beneath, and Alichino raises his breast with upward pinion.
Calcabrina, enraged by the mockery, flies after Alichino and turns his talons on his comrade. They grapple over the dyke and fall into the boiling lake. The heat acts as umpire, but they cannot lift themselves, their pennons glued. Barbariccia dispatches four others from the other coast, armed with weapons. They descend to their posts, stretching hooks toward the floundering fiends. The narrator and Virgil depart, leaving them to the broil.

**CANTO XXIII**
They go in silence and solitude, like minor friars. The fray makes the narrator muse on Aesop's fable of the mouse and frog. He fears the demons, reasoning that they will pursue them more fiercely due to their recent foil and mockery. He feels his hair stand on end and looks back.
The narrator tells Virgil they must hide quickly from the "evil talons," as imagination makes him feel them already. Virgil replies that his thoughts came before his own, and he has formed one design from both. If the right coast inclines enough to descend into the next chasm, they will escape.
Before Virgil finishes, the narrator sees the demons with spread wings approaching. Virgil catches him like a mother snatching her babe from climbing fires, casting himself supine down from the jutting beach to a pendent rock that closes one part of the chasm.
Virgil runs along the edge, carrying the narrator in his bosom. Scarcely had his feet reached the lowest bed when the demons reached the steep above them. But Virgil has no fear, as "high Providence" took from them the power to depart from the fifth foss.
In the depth, they see a "painted tribe," pacing slowly, weeping, faint and toiled. They wear caps with hoods like Cologne monks, overlaid with dazzling gold but leaden within, so heavy that "Frederick’s compar’d to these were straw." The narrator calls it "everlasting wearisome attire!"
They turn left with them, intent on their dismal moan. The fainting people move so slowly that their company changes with every step. The narrator asks Virgil to find a spirit whose name is known by his deeds.
One spirit, hearing the Tuscan voice, cries aloud, "Hold in your feet, Ye who so swiftly speed through the dusk air. Perchance from me thou shalt obtain thy wish." Virgil tells the narrator to pause and then proceed at their pace.
The narrator waits and sees two spirits eager to overtake him, but their load and the narrow path retard them. They eye him askance, then confer, saying, "This one Seems, by the action of his throat, alive. And, be they dead, what privilege allows They walk unmantled by the cumbrous stole?"
They ask the narrator, "Tuscan, who visitest The college of the mourning hypocrites, Disdain not to instruct us who thou art." The narrator replies he was bred in Florence by the Arno and wears the body he has ever worn. He asks who they are and what torment causes their grief.
One answers that their "bonnets gleaming bright with orange hue" are so "leaden gross" that their weight makes balances crack. They were "Joyous friars," natives of Bologna, Catalano and Loderingo. They were taken by Florence as arbiters to reconcile strifes, and Gardingo's vicinage can best declare how they fared.
The narrator begins to speak of their miseries but breaks off, seeing a spirit "Fix’d to a cross with three stakes on the ground." This spirit writhes distortedly, ruffling his beard. Catalano explains that this "pierced spirit" was he "who gave the Pharisees Counsel, that it were fitting for one man To suffer for the people." He lies transverse, and everyone must make "feeling trial how each weighs" by passing over him. The father of his consort and other partakers in that council are placed in similar straits. The narrator notes Virgil's wonder.
Virgil asks the friar if there is an opening on their right to exit without compelling the dark angels. The friar replies that "Nearer than thou dost hope, there is a rock From the next circle moving, which o’ersteps Each vale of horror, save that here his cope Is shatter’d. By the ruin ye may mount: For on the side it slants, and most the height Rises below."
Virgil stands with head bent, then says, "He warn’d us ill, Who yonder hangs the sinners on his hook." The friar replies that at Bologna, he heard many vices of the devil, including "He is a liar, And the father of lies!" Virgil then proceeds with large strides, disturbed with anger.
The narrator leaves the heavy-laden spirits and follows Virgil's footsteps.

**CANTO XXIV**
In the early part of the year, when the sun is in Aquarius and nights recede towards equal day, the rime whitens the plain. A village hind, lacking winter stores, smites his thighs in impatience, then finds new hope as the world changes countenance, grasps his crook, and drives his flock to pasture. Similarly, the narrator was disheartened by Virgil's troubled forehead, but this ill was cured when they arrived at the fallen bridge. Virgil turned back with a sweet look, like the one at the mountain's foot.
Regarding the ruin, and after some thought, Virgil opens his arm and takes the narrator up. Like one who computes his labor's issue, Virgil lifts him to the summit of one peak, then fixes his eye on another, saying, "Grapple that... but first make proof, if it be such As will sustain thee." The narrator notes that for one capped with lead, this would be no journey. Even for him, though light, and the narrator, pushed from crag to crag, it is difficult. If the precinct were not less ample than the last, his strength would have failed. Malebolge inclines toward the mouth of the nethermost abyss, so each valley slopes upward on one side and falls on the other.
They reach the point of descent from the last flag. The narrator is so exhausted he must sit. Virgil tells him, "Now needs thy best of man; For not on downy plumes, nor under shade Of canopy reposing, fame is won, Without which whosoe’er consumes his days Leaveth such vestige of himself on earth, As smoke in air or foam upon the wave. Thou therefore rise: vanish thy weariness By the mind’s effort... A longer ladder yet remains to scale. From these to have escap’d sufficeth not. If well thou note me, profit by my words."
The narrator rises, showing himself less spent than he feels, crying, "On, For I am stout and fearless." They hold their way up the rock, more rugged, narrower, and steeper. The narrator talks ceaselessly to appear least faint. A voice from the other foss issues forth, "for utt’rance suited ill." Though on the arch, the narrator cannot make out the words but perceives anger. He stoops to look but cannot see due to darkness. He asks Virgil to bend their steps to the next circle and dismount from the wall, as he cannot hear or see. Virgil replies, "I answer not... but by the deed. To fair request Silent performance maketh best return."
They descend from the bridge's head to the eighth mound. The chasm opens, revealing a crowd of "serpents terrible, so strange of shape And hideous." The narrator says Lybia cannot boast of such a brood.
Amid this "dread exuberance of woe," naked spirits run, "wing’d with horrid fear," with no hope of hiding. Serpents bind their hands behind them, their tails and heads twisted in folds before. An adder darts up and transpierces one spirit near them, where the neck joins the shoulders. More quickly than a pen writes O or I, he kindles, burns, and changes to ashes. The dust then spontaneously re-rolls and instantly resumes the self-same form. The narrator compares this to the Arabian Phoenix. The sinner stands aghast when he rises.
The narrator laments God's severe judgment. Virgil asks who he was. He replies, "Vanni Fucci am I call’d, Not long since rained down from Tuscany To this dire gullet. Me the beastial life And not the human pleas’d, mule that I was, Who in Pistoia found my worthy den."
The narrator tells Virgil to make him stay and ask his crime, as he knew him as "choleric and bloody." The sinner, hearing this, does not feign, but turns his face, depicting dismal shame. He says it grieves him more to be caught in this plight than when he was taken from life. He is doomed for rifling the sacristy of its ornaments and falsely charging another. But so the narrator may not joy, he forebodes: "Reft of the Neri first Pistoia pines, Then Florence changeth citizens and laws. From Valdimagra, drawn by wrathful Mars, A vapour rises, wrapt in turbid mists, And sharp and eager driveth on the storm With arrowy hurtling o’er Piceno’s field, whence suddenly the cloud shall burst, and strike Each helpless Bianco prostrate to the ground. This have I told, that grief may rend thy heart."

**CANTO XXV**
After speaking, the sinner raises his hands in mockery, crying, "Take them, God! I level them at thee!" From that day, the serpents become the narrator's friends. One serpent rolls around his neck, twisting as if saying, "Be silent, tongue!" Another glides up his arms, tying them and riveting itself so close it takes away their power to move.
The narrator laments Pistoia's evil. He notes he did not see any spirit swell so proudly against God, not even the one who fell headlong from Thebes. The sinner flees without another word. A centaur, full of fury, comes after him, shouting, "Where Where is the caitiff?" Serpents swarm on his haunch up to where his human face begins. Behind his head, on his shoulders, lies a dragon with open wings, breathing fire. Virgil identifies him as Cacus, who spread a lake of blood under the rock of Aventine. He is here for his "fraudful theft Of the great herd," his deeds ended by Alcides' mace.
While Virgil speaks, the centaur speeds away. Three spirits come up from below, unnoticed until they exclaim, "Say who are ye?" They break off discourse. The narrator does not know them, but one names another, asking, "Where Doth Cianfa lurk?" The narrator puts a finger to his lips, signaling Virgil to be attentive. He tells the reader not to marvel if he doesn't credit what he tells, as he himself scarce allows his eyes' witness.
As he looks, a six-footed serpent springs onto one spirit, fastening upon him: its midmost feet grasp the belly, forefeet seize each arm, fangs flesh deep in cheeks, and hinder feet spread on thighs, tail curled on the reins. Ivy never clasped an oak as the monster entwines the spirit. Then, like burning wax, each melts into the other, mingling hues, so that "which was either now was seen no more." The other two exclaim, "Ah, how dost thou change, Agnello! See! Thou art nor double now, Nor only one." The two heads become one, and two figures blend into one form, where both are lost. Two arms are made of four lengths; belly, chest, thighs, and legs change into unseen members. All trace of former shape vanishes. The miscreated image passes on with tardy steps, seeming neither of the two.
As a lizard shifts from brake to brake, an adder all on fire, "livid and swart," approaches the entrails of the other two. It transpierces one where life is first nourished. The pierced spirit falls, looks at the serpent, but speaks not, standing motionless and yawning. The serpent eyes him, and he the serpent. One breathes thick smoke from the wound, the other from the mouth, their vapory columns joining.
The narrator says Lucan and Ovid should be mute, as they never sang of two natures so transmuted face to face. The serpent splits its tail into a fork, and the pierced spirit draws his steps together, legs and thighs compacted, so no juncture is visible. The tail takes the figure the spirit lost, its skin softening, his indurated to a rind. Shoulders join the monster's armpits, its two shorter feet lengthen as the other's shrink. The feet behind twist up to become the part man conceals, which in the wretch is cleft in twain. The smoke veils both with new color, generating an excrescent pile on one, peeling it off the other. One rises upright, the other falls prone. Their "glaring and malignant lamps" (eyes) are not yet shifted, though features change. Of the one standing, the face retreats toward the temples, superfluous matter shoots out in ears from smooth cheeks, the rest shapes the nose, and lips swell. The one on the earth extends his sharpened visage, drawing down his ears like a slug. His continuous tongue severs, and the other's fork closes. The smoke lays. The soul, transformed into the brute, glides off, hissing. The other, talking, sputters, then turns his new-grown shoulders and says to another, "Along this path Crawling, as I have done, speed Buoso now!"
The narrator saw the "unsteady ballast of the seventh hold" fluctuate in change. He notes that Sciancato alone of the first three did not change. He adds that Gaville still rues the other's fate.

**CANTO XXVI**
The narrator exclaims, "Florence exult!" for her thriving, but notes shame that three of her citizens are among the plunderers in hell. He foresees future woe for Florence, greater than Prato wishes.
They depart from the depth, Virgil remounting the flinty steps, drawing the narrator up. They proceed on their solitary way, using hands and feet among the crags.
Sorrow seizes the narrator as he recalls what he saw, and he curbs his nature lest it run where virtue guides not. He doesn't envy himself the boon of his gentle star.
In the season when the sun least veils its face, and gnats replace flies, a peasant sees innumerable fire-flies. Similarly, the eighth chasm shines with "flames so numberless." Like Elijah's chariot seen by the avenged bears, every flame moves along the gulf, a sinner "enfolded close in each," so none shows "token of the theft."
The narrator bends forward on the bridge to look, grasping a flinty mass to avoid falling. Virgil, noting his gaze, says, "Within these ardours are the spirits, each Swath’d in confining fire." The narrator replies he understood this, but asks who is in the flame that comes "so parted at the summit," like the Theban brothers' funeral pile. Virgil replies, "Ulysses there and Diomede endure Their penal tortures, thus to vengeance now Together hasting, as erewhile to wrath." They deplore the ambush of the horse that opened a portal for the seed of imperial Rome, and the guile that reft Achilles from Deidamia, and the stratagem that spoiled Troy of its Palladium.
The narrator asks if they can speak from within the sparks, begging Virgil to pause until the "horned flame" arrives. Virgil praises his prayer but tells him to refrain his tongue, as he will question them, divining his wish, and they, being Greeks, might shun discourse with him.
When the flame arrives, Virgil asks, "O ye, who dwell two spirits in one fire! If living I of you did merit aught... Move ye not on, till one of you unfold In what clime death o’ertook him self-destroy’d."
The greater horn of the old flame begins to roll, murmuring like a fire in the wind, then wags its top like a tongue, and speaks: "When I escap’d From Circe, who beyond a circling year Had held me near Caieta... Nor fondness for my son, nor reverence Of my old father, nor return of love... Could overcome in me the zeal I had T’ explore the world, and search the ways of life, Man’s evil and his virtue." He sailed into the "deep illimitable main" with one bark and a small band, seeing both shores of Iberia and Morocco, and Sardinia and other islands. He and his companions were old when they reached the "strait pass, where Hercules ordain’d The bound’ries not to be o’erstepp’d by man." He left Seville's walls to his right and passed Ceuta. He urged his brothers, who had reached the west through perils, not to refuse proof of the "unpeopled world," following Phoebus, reminding them they were not formed to live like brutes but to pursue virtue and knowledge. With these words, he sharpened their minds. They turned their poop to the dawn, making their oars wings, gaining on the left. They saw the stars of the other pole, and theirs so low it rose not from the ocean floor. Five times the moon's light vanished since they entered the deep way, when a dim mountain appeared, the loftiest he ever beheld. Joy seized them, but soon changed to mourning. A whirlwind sprung from the new land, struck the vessel, whirled it thrice, lifted the poop, and sank the prow, and "over us the booming billow clos’d."

**CANTO XXVII**
The flame rises and stills its light, speaking no more. It passes on with Virgil's leave. Another flame follows, from whose top a confused sound draws their eyes.
The narrator compares the sound to the Sicilian bull, which made the tormented's cries sound as if the brazen monster itself was pierced. The dismal words turn into language, and then from the point of the flame, they hear: "O thou! to whom I now direct my voice! That lately didst exclaim in Lombard phrase, ‘Depart thou, I solicit thee no more,’ Though somewhat tardy I perchance arrive Let it not irk thee here to pause awhile, And with me parley: lo! it irks not me And yet I burn." He asks if those in Romagna have peace or war, as he was from the mountains between Urbino and the source of the Tiber.
The narrator listens, and Virgil touches his side, saying, "Speak thou: he is a Latian." The narrator replies that Romagna was never without war in its tyrants' bosoms, nor is it now, but he left no "open war." Ravenna's state is steadfast, ruled by Polenta's eagle. The "green talons" grasp the land that withstood the French host. The "old mastiff of Verruchio and the young" still make an auger of their fangs. Lamone's city and Santerno's range under the "lion of the snowy lair," an inconstant partisan. The city washed by Savio's wave lives "’twixt tyrant power and liberty." The narrator asks who the spirit is.
The fire roars, its sharpened point waving, then breathes: "If I did think, my answer were to one, Who ever could return unto the world, This flame should rest unshaken. But since ne’er... any from this depth Has found his upward way, I answer thee, Nor fear lest infamy record the words."
He states he was "A man of arms at first," then clothed himself in "good Saint Francis’ girdle," hoping to make amends. His hope would not have failed, but "the high priest again seduc’d me into sin." He explains that while he lived, his deeds were more like a fox than a lion, knowing "All ways of winding subtlety." When he came to the part of life where one "behoves To lower sails," he rued his past and turned to repentance and confession.
Meanwhile, "The chief of the new Pharisees" (Pope Boniface VIII) waged war near the Lateran, not against Saracens or Jews, but Christians. He did not reverence his charge or the cord (Franciscan habit) that marked leanness. Like Constantine seeking Sylvester's aid for leprosy, this man sought his counsel to cure his pride. The spirit was silent, for his words seemed drunken, but the Pope resumed, "From thy heart banish fear: of all offence I hitherto absolve thee. In return, Teach me my purpose so to execute, That Penestrino cumber earth no more. Heav’n, as thou knowest, I have power to shut And open: and the keys are therefore twain, The which my predecessor meanly priz’d."
Yielding to these arguments, the spirit deemed silence more perilous and answered, "Father! since thou washest me Clear of that guilt wherein I now must fall, Large promise with performance scant, be sure, Shall make thee triumph in thy lofty seat."
He continues: "When I was number’d with the dead, then came Saint Francis for me; but a cherub dark He met, who cried: ‘Wrong me not; he is mine, And must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave. E’er since I watch’d him, hov’ring at his hair, No power can the impenitent absolve; Nor to repent and will at once consist, By contradiction absolute forbid.’" He describes his misery when the cherub seized him, saying, "Thou haply thought’st me not A disputant in logic so exact." He was borne to Minos, who twined his tail eight times, biting it in rage, saying, "This is a guilty soul, that in the fire Must vanish." Hence, he roves, "A prey to rankling sorrow in this garb."
The flame parts in dolour, beating and writhing its sharp horn. The narrator and Virgil move onward up the rock to another arch overhanging the foss, where the penalty for "committed sin" is paid.

**CANTO XXVIII**
The narrator states that no words can fully describe the wounds and blood he now saw in the ninth chasm, comparing it to the vast bloodshed in Apulia by Trojans, in the Punic wars, by Guiscard's Norman steel, and at Ceperano or Tagliacozzo. A rundlet (cask) does not gape so wide as one spirit he marks, torn from chin to "hinder passage," his entrails dangling, midriff and ventricle open.
As the narrator gazes, the spirit eyes him, bares his breast with his hands, and cries, "Now mark how I do rip me! lo! How is Mohammed mangled! before me Walks Ali weeping, from the chin his face Cleft to the forelock; and the others all Whom here thou seest, while they liv’d, did sow Scandal and schism, and therefore thus are rent." He explains that a fiend behind them hacks them cruelly with a sword, slivering them again after their gashes close as they complete their dismal way. He asks who the narrator is, lingering to delay pain.
Virgil replies that death has not yet overtaken him, nor does sin conduct him to torment. He is dead and must conduct the narrator through hell to make "Full trial of your state."
More than a hundred spirits, amazed, stand in the foss to mark the narrator, forgetting their pangs. Mohammed, with foot upraised, speaks to the narrator: "Thou, who perchance Shalt shortly view the sun, this warning thou Bear to Dolcino: bid him, if he wish not Here soon to follow me, that with good store Of food he arm him, lest impris’ning snows Yield him a victim to Novara’s power, No easy conquest else." He then fixes his foot to depart.
Another shade, pierced in the throat, with mutilated nostrils and one ear lopt off, advances from the rest, baring his windpipe, smeared with crimson. He asks the narrator, whom sin condemns not, if he remembers Piero of Medicina, whom he saw in Latian ground. He asks him to instruct "the twain, whom Fano boasts Her worthiest sons, Guido and Angelo," that if the future can be scanned, they will be cast forth from life and whelmed under the waves near Cattolica through a "perfidy Of a fell tyrant." He describes this injury as fouler than any Neptune has seen. He says that "one-ey’d traitor" (Malatestino) will bring them to conference and shape their end so they will need no prayers against Focara's wind.
The narrator asks who the one is who wakes such sad remembrance in him. The spirit lays his hand on another's cheek-bone, expanding his jaws, and cries, "Lo! this is he I wot of; He speaks not for himself: the outcast this Who overwhelm’d the doubt in Caesar’s mind, Affirming that delay to men prepar’d Was ever harmful." The narrator notes how terrified Curio seemed, whose tongue was cut. Then one "Maim’d of each hand" lifts his bleeding stumps, which sully his face, and cries, "Remember thee Of Mosca, too, I who, alas! exclaim’d, “The deed once done there is an end,” that prov’d A seed of sorrow to the Tuscan race." The narrator adds, "Ay, and death to thine own tribe." Mosca hurries off, grief-stung.
The narrator lingers to behold the troop and sees things he fears to tell without more proof, but conscience makes him firm. He sees a headless trunk, pacing onward, bearing its severed head "lantern-wise Pendent in hand," which looks at them and says, "Woe’s me!" The spirit lights himself thus, and "two there were in one, and one in two." When he stands at the bridge's foot, he rears his arm aloft, thrusting the head into view so they might hear its words: "Now behold This grievous torment... behold if any else Be terrible as this. And that on earth Thou mayst bear tidings of me, know that I Am Bertrand, he of Born, who gave King John The counsel mischievous. Father and son I set at mutual war... For parting those so closely knit, my brain Parted, alas! I carry from its source, That in this trunk inhabits. Thus the law Of retribution fiercely works in me."

**CANTO XXIX**
The narrator's eyes are so "inebriate with view Of the vast multitude" that he longs to stay and weep. Virgil rouses him, asking why he gazes below among the maimed shades, noting he has not shown this weakness in other chasms. He explains the valley winds "two and twenty miles," and the moon is already beneath their feet, so time is short.
The narrator replies that if Virgil had weighed the cause for his looking, he might have excused his tarrying. He adds that he deems a spirit of his blood dwells in that cave, wailing his crime.
Virgil tells him not to afflict himself for him. He says that at the bridge's foot, he marked the spirit point with a menacing look at the narrator and heard him named Geri of Bello. The narrator was so busy with the spirit who once ruled Hautefort that he did not look that way before he was gone. The narrator explains that Geri's "violent death yet unaveng’d" made him contemptuous, so he passed speechless, making the narrator more compassionate.
They discourse to where the rock first shows the other valley, which would have more light if it were there. As they reach the "last cloister" of Malebolge, a "many a dart Of sore lament" assails the narrator, so he closes his ears.
He describes the torment as if all the lazar-houses of Valdichiana, Sardinia, and Maremma's fen had heaped their maladies in one foss, with a dire stench.
They descend to the left on the utmost shore of the long rock. The narrator's sight is livelier to explore the depth where "All-searching Justice" dooms forgers. He compares the scene to the nation in Aegina drooping from a pestilent air, but more rueful. He sees spirits languishing, piled on many a stack, confused, one over another, some crawling sideling.
They journey step by step, silently looking and listening to the diseased, who strive in vain to lift their forms. Two sit propped against each other, "as two brazen pans Set to retain the heat." From head to foot, a tetter barks them round. Each quickly plies his keen nails due to "furiousness Of ne’er abated pruriency," drawing crust from underneath in flakes.
Virgil asks one, who is rending off his "coat of proof" with his fingers, if any Latian is among them, wishing his nails serve him forever. The spirit, weeping, replies that both are of Latium, then asks who Virgil is. Virgil replies he descends with the narrator, who lives, to show him hell's abyss.
They start asunder and turn trembling toward them. Virgil tells the narrator to speak. The narrator asks who they are and their race, hoping their "unseemly and disgustful" punishment will not deter them.
One answers, "Arezzo was my dwelling, And me Albero of Sienna brought To die by fire; but that, for which I died, Leads me not here. True is in sport I told him, That I had learn’d to wing my flight in air. And he admiring much, as he was void Of wisdom, will’d me to declare to him The secret of mine art: and only hence, Because I made him not a Daedalus, Prevail’d on one suppos’d his sire to burn me. But Minos to this chasm last of the ten, For that I practis’d alchemy on earth, Has doom’d me. Him no subterfuge eludes."
The narrator asks Virgil if any race is as light as Sienna's. The other leprous spirit hears and replies, "Be Stricca from this charge Exempted, he who knew so temp’rately To lay out fortune’s gifts; and Niccolo Who first the spice’s costly luxury Discover’d in that garden, where such seed Roots deepest in the soil: and be that troop Exempted, with whom Caccia of Asciano Lavish’d his vineyards and wide-spreading woods, And his rare wisdom Abbagliato show’d A spectacle for all." He then tells the narrator to bend his sight to see his face, so he will know he is Capocchio's ghost, who forged transmuted metals by alchemy, and will remember how he aped "Creative nature by my subtle art."

**CANTO XXX**
The narrator describes the frenzies of Athamas (who killed his son Learchus) and Hecuba (who barked like a dog after seeing Polyxena and Polydorus slain), stating that the Furies were never seen with such cruelty as two pale, naked ghosts he now sees. They scamper wildly like swine. One reaches Capocchio, sticks his fangs in his neck-joint, and drags him, his belly rubbing the pavement. The other ghost, from Arezzo, left trembling, says, "That sprite of air is Schicchi; in like mood Of random mischief vents he still his spite."
The narrator asks who the other spirit is. The trembling spirit replies, "That is the ancient soul Of wretched Myrrha... who burn’d With most unholy flame for her own sire, And a false shape assuming, so perform’d The deed of sin." He adds that the other spirit, passing onward, "dar’d to counterfeit Donati’s features, to feign’d testament The seal affixing, that himself might gain, For his own share, the lady of the herd."
The two furious shades vanish. The narrator turns to other cursed spirits. He sees one "In fashion like a lute, had but the groin Been sever’d." Swollen with dropsy, his limbs disproportionate, his paunch not suiting his visage, he gasps with wide lips. He addresses the narrator, asking him to regard "Adamo’s woe." He says he never lacked what he coveted in life, but now craves "One drop of water." The rills of Casentino are ever in his view, and their "pictur’d semblance dries me up" more than his disease. Justice urges him to quicken his sighs. He states he falsified metal with the Baptist's form in Romena, for which his body was burnt on earth. He wishes to see the sorrowing souls of Guido, Alessandro, or their brother, which he would not exchange for Branda's spring. He says one is within if mad spirits tell truly, but his limbs are fettered. If he were light enough to move an inch every hundred years, he would seek him out. These spirits brought him down here, inducing him to stamp florens with three carats of alloy.
The narrator asks about "that abject pair" bounding him on his right, smoking like a band in a chill stream. Adamo replies he found them there when he dropped into the gulf, and they will not turn till time runs its course. One is "that dame The false accuser of the Hebrew youth" (Potiphar's wife, though not named), and the other is Sinon, "that false Greek from Troy." Sharp fever drains their moisture, steaming up in a cloud.
One of them, galled by being darkly named, smites Adamo on his paunch, which resounds like a drum. Adamo smites him back on the face. Adamo says, though his limbs are heavy, he has an arm for such employ. Sinon replies he did not have it so ready when he went to the fire, but readier when he coined "th’ impostor gold." Adamo replies, "Ay, now speak’st thou true. But there thou gav’st not such true testimony, When thou wast question’d of the truth, at Troy." Sinon replies, "If I spake false, thou falsely stamp’dst the coin... I am here but for one fault, And thou for more than any imp beside." Adamo retorts, "Remember... The horse remember, that did teem with death, And all the world be witness to thy guilt." Sinon returns, "To thine... witness the thirst Whence thy tongue cracks, witness the fluid mound, Rear’d by thy belly up before thine eyes, A mass corrupt." Adamo replies, "Thy mouth gapes wide as ever to let pass Its evil saying. Me if thirst assails, Yet I am stuff’d with moisture. Thou art parch’d, Pains rack thy head, no urging would’st thou need To make thee lap Narcissus’ mirror up."
The narrator is fixed to listen. Virgil admonishes him, "Now beware: a little more, And I do quarrel with thee." The narrator perceives Virgil's anger and turns with poignant shame. He feels like one who dreams of harm and wishes it were a dream, wanting to excuse himself but unable to speak. Virgil says, "More grievous fault than thine has been, less shame... might expiate. Therefore cast All sorrow from thy soul; and if again Chance bring thee, where like conference is held, Think I am ever at thy side. To hear Such wrangling is a joy for vulgar minds."

**CANTO XXXI**
The same tongue that reproved the narrator now ministers his cure, like Achilles' javelin. They turn their back on the "vale of woe" and cross the mound in silence. In the dim twilight, the narrator hears a horn sounded aloud, whose peal makes thunder feeble. Following its course, his eyes are bent on that spot. He thinks Orlando did not blow such a blast.
He raises his head and sees many lofty towers. He asks Virgil what land this is. Virgil replies that his eye has too long a space of darkness to traverse, so he has erred in imagining. He will see how distance can delude the sense and urges him on.
Virgil tenderly catches his hand and explains that these are not towers but "giants," immersed in the pit from their navel downward, around the bank. As a fog disperses, the narrator's error flees, and fear comes over him. Like Montereggion crowned with turrets, the shore is "turreted with giants," half their length rearing up, horrible.
He discerns the face, shoulders, breast, and much of the huge belly, and both arms of one giant. He notes nature's wisdom in framing these monsters for "mad War," and if she repents not the elephant and whale, she is wiser, for "when brute force And evil will are back’d with subtlety, Resistance none avails." This giant's visage is as long and bulky as the pine that tops St. Peter's Roman fane. His stature is so great that three Friezelanders could not reach his hair. He is exposed "Full thirty ample palms" downward.
The giant shouts, "Raphel bai ameth sabi almi." Virgil addresses him, "O senseless spirit! let thy horn for thee Interpret: therewith vent thy rage... Search thy neck, There shalt thou find the belt that binds it on. Wild spirit! lo, upon thy mighty breast Where hangs the baldrick!" Virgil then tells the narrator, "He doth accuse himself. Nimrod is this, Through whose ill counsel in the world no more One tongue prevails. But pass we on, nor waste Our words; for so each language is to him, As his to others, understood by none."
They turn left and speed forth, finding another shade "Far fiercer and more huge" at a sling's throw. The narrator cannot say what hand girded him, but he holds his right arm fettered behind and the other with a chain from neck down, meeting five times around his form. Virgil says, "This proud one Would of his strength against almighty Jove Make trial... Ephialtes him they call." He notes Ephialtes' prowess when giants brought fear on the gods, but now he moves those arms never.
The narrator wishes to see Briareus. Virgil replies that not far from hence they will see Antaeus, who speaks and is unfettered, and will place them where guilt is at its depth. Briareus, whom he wishes to see, stands further on, in chains, and seems more fell. Ephialtes shakes like a tower rocked by an earthquake. The narrator fears death, but the cords holding him fast reassure him.
They journey on to Antaeus, who issues from the cave "five ells complete Without the head." Virgil addresses Antaeus, recalling his strength in the fortunate vale where Scipio triumphed over Hannibal, and how he carried a hundred lions as spoil. He asks Antaeus to place them down where "numbing cold Locks up Cocytus," not forcing them to crave Tityus' or Typhon's help, as the narrator can bestow renown on him in the upper world.
Antaeus stretches his hands and catches Virgil. Virgil tells the narrator to clasp him, then catches him up so they are "both one burden." Antaeus seems like the leaning tower of Carisenda. The narrator wishes he could have passed another way. Antaeus lightly places them in the abyss, where Lucifer ingulfs Judas, then rises like a mast.

**CANTO XXXII**
The narrator wishes for "rough rhimes and hoarse" to suit this "hole of sorrow," as describing the depth of the universe is no jest. He invokes the Muses. He laments the ill-starred folk, wretched beyond others.
They stand in the dark pit beneath the giants' feet, but lower. A voice tells the narrator, "Look how thou walkest. Take Good heed, thy soles do tread not on the heads Of thy poor brethren." He turns and sees a lake whose frozen surface seems more like glass than water, thicker than the Danube or Tanais in winter. If Tabernich or Pietrapana fell on it, not even its rim would creak. Like frogs croaking above the wave, the spirits stand "Blue pinch’d and shrin’d in ice," moving their teeth like storks. Their faces are held downward, their mouths cold, their eyes expressing dolour.
The narrator sees two spirits so strictly joined that their hairs are mingled. He asks who they are. They bend their necks, and their eyes, moist within, distill tears onto their lips, which the frost binds. They clash together like enraged goats.
One, from whom the cold has reft both ears, exclaims, "Why on us Dost speculate so long? If thou wouldst know Who are these two, the valley, whence his wave Bisenzio slopes, did for its master own Their sire Alberto, and next him themselves." They issued from one body, and in Caina, one would not find a shade more worthy of congealment, not even him whose breast and shadow Arthur's land dissevered, nor Focaccia, nor the spirit whose head obstructs his view (Mascheroni). He reveals his own name was Camiccione and he awaits his kinsman Carlino, whose deep guilt will wash out his own.
The narrator then marks a thousand visages shaped into a "doggish grin" by the cold, causing a shivering horror. As they journey toward the middle, where all heavy substance unites, the narrator, trembling, accidentally strikes the face of one spirit.
The spirit, weeping, exclaims, "Wherefore dost bruise me? Unless thy errand be some fresh revenge For Montaperto, wherefore troublest me?" The narrator asks Virgil to wait so he can rid himself of doubt. Virgil pauses. The narrator asks the spirit, who curses him, who he is. The spirit asks who the narrator is, roaming through Antenora and striking others' cheeks with such force.
The narrator replies he is living, hoping fame is dear to the spirit, so he can enroll his name. The spirit says the narrator offers the contrary of what he covets most and tells him to vex him no more. The narrator seizes his "hinder scalp," crying, "Name thee, or not a hair shall tarry here." The spirit replies, "Rend all away... yet for that I will not tell nor show thee who I am."
The narrator grasps his tresses and strips off more than one tuft, the spirit barking. Another cries, "What ails thee, Bocca? Sound not loud enough Thy chatt’ring teeth, but thou must bark outright? What devil wrings thee?" The narrator tells the "Accursed traitor" (Bocca) to be dumb, as he will bear true tidings of him. Bocca replies to tell what he lists, but to speak of "him whose tongue hath been so glib" (Buoso da Duera) who wails for the Frenchman's gold. He adds that Beccaria, whose red gorge was stained by Florence's axe, is at his side. Further on, Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello (who opened Faenza) bide.
They leave him and see two spirits pent in one hollow by the ice, one's head serving as a cowl for the other. The uppermost applies his fangs to the other's brain, where the spine joins it, more furiously than Tydeus gnawed Menalippus'. The narrator asks the cause of such hate, promising to repay him in the world above if his grievance is warranted.

**CANTO XXXIII**
The sinner lifts his jaws from his repast, wipes them on the mangled hairs of the head, and begins: "Thy will obeying, I call up afresh Sorrow past cure, which but to think of wrings My heart, or ere I tell on’t. But if words... shall prove seed to bear Fruit of eternal infamy to him, The traitor whom I gnaw at, thou at once Shalt see me speak and weep." He says he does not know who the narrator is or how he came, but he seems Florentine. He reveals he was Count Ugolino, and the archbishop he gnaws is Ruggieri. He explains that through Ruggieri's ill thoughts, reposing trust in him, he was taken and murdered. He will tell what the narrator cannot have heard: how cruel the murder was.
He describes a "small grate Within that mew, which for my sake the name Of famine bears," where others must pine. Several moons had shown through its opening when he slept an "evil sleep," which tore the curtain off the future. He dreamed Ruggieri, as master of the sport, rode forth to chase the gaunt wolf and his whelps (Ugolino and his sons) to the mountain that forbids the sight of Lucca to the Pisan. Lanfranchi, Sismondi, and Gualandi were ranged before him with lean brachs. After a short course, the father and sons seemed tired, and he saw sharp tusks gore their sides.
He awoke before dawn, hearing his sons (who were with him) weep and ask for bread. He calls the narrator cruel if he feels no pang. They had awakened, and the hour for food drew near. Each son had misgivings from his dream. He heard the horrible tower locked up from its outlet. He looked at his sons' visages, weeping not, feeling "all stone within." They wept, and his little Anslem cried, "Thou lookest so! Father what ails thee?" He shed no tear, nor answered all that day or the next night.
When a faint beam made its way to their prison, and he descried his own image in four countenances, he bit his hands through agony. His sons, thinking he did it from hunger, rose and cried, "Father, we should grieve Far less, if thou wouldst eat of us: thou gav’st These weeds of miserable flesh we wear, And do thou strip them off from us again." To avoid making them sadder, he kept his spirit still. That day and the next, they were silent. He laments, "Ah, obdurate earth! Why open’dst not upon us?" On the fourth day, Geddo flung himself at his feet, crying, "Hast no help For me, my father!" There he died. Ugolino saw the three fall one by one between the fifth and sixth day. Then, grown blind, he groped over them for three days, calling on them, then "fasting got The mastery of grief."
Having spoken, he fastens his teeth once more on the wretched skull. The narrator then curses Pisa, calling it a shame to all people, wishing Capraia and Gorgona would rise and dam up the Arno's mouth so every soul in Pisa might perish. He argues that even if Ugolino betrayed castles, Pisa had no right to rack his children, as Brigata, Ugaccione, and the two gentle ones were "Uncapable of guilt" due to their tender years.
They pass onward, where others are "skarf’d in rugged folds of ice," reversed, not on their feet. Here, "weeping suffers not to weep," as grief finds impediment at their eyes, rolling inward for increased anguish. The first tears hang clustered like crystal visors.
Though the cold has dislodged all feeling from his face, the narrator feels a breath of wind. He asks Virgil whence it comes, as he thought all vapor was quenched below. Virgil replies he will soon see the cause of this "airy shower."
One spirit in the chill crust cries out, "O souls so cruel! that the farthest post Hath been assign’d you, from this face remove The harden’d veil, that I may vent the grief Impregnate at my heart, some little space Ere it congeal again!" The narrator replies he will aid him if he reveals who he was, promising to descend to the lowest ice if he fails.
The spirit answers, "The friar Alberigo Am I, who from the evil garden pluck’d Its fruitage, and am here repaid, the date More luscious for my fig." The narrator exclaims, "Hah! Art thou too dead!" Alberigo replies he is ignorant of how his body fares in the world above. He explains that "Ptolomea" has the privilege that the soul drops here before Atropos divorces it. To make the narrator wipe his glazed tear-drops, he says that the moment a soul betrays, as he did, it yields its body to a fiend who moves and governs it until its time is rounded, and the soul falls to this cistern. He says the body of a ghost who winters behind him might still appear above, and the narrator knows him if he is newly arrived. Many years have passed since Branca Doria came to this fastness.
The narrator replies he thinks Alberigo mocks him, as Branca Doria has not died but performs all natural functions. Alberigo replies that Michael Zanche had not yet reached the "upper foss" where pitch boils when Branca Doria left a demon in his stead in his own body, and one of his kin who wrought treachery with him did the same. He asks the narrator to open his eyes. The narrator refuses, deeming "Ill manners were best courtesy to him."
The narrator then curses the Genoese, asking why they are not canceled from earth, as he found one of them with Romagna's darkest spirit, whose soul is plunged in Cocytus even now, yet seems alive in body on earth.

**CANTO XXXIV**
Virgil says, "The banners of Hell’s Monarch do come forth Towards us; therefore look... If thou discern him." As a windmill appears from afar through a dense cloud, such was the "fabric" the narrator thought he saw. He draws behind Virgil to shield himself from the wind.
The narrator comes to a place where souls are whelmed underneath, transparent like glass. Some are prone, others upright, some on their soles, some on their heads, a third arched like a bow. When they reach the point where Virgil wishes him to see the "creature eminent in beauty once," Virgil steps before him and makes him pause.
Virgil exclaims, "Lo! lo! Dis! and lo the place, Where thou hast need to arm thy heart with strength." The narrator becomes frozen and faint, unable to describe his state. He says he was "not dead nor living."
That "emperor, who sways The realm of sorrow" (Lucifer), stands forth from the ice mid-breast. The narrator is more like a giant compared to the giants in Lucifer's arms. He notes the immense size of the whole. If Lucifer were as beautiful as he is hideous now, and dared to scowl at his Maker, all misery might flow from him.
Lucifer has "three faces": one in front, vermilion; the other two joined midway each shoulder and at the crest. The right face seems "’twixt wan and yellow," the left "such as come from whence old Nile Stoops to the lowlands." Under each face shoot forth "Two mighty wings, enormous as became A bird so vast." They have no plumes but are like a bat's texture. He flaps them, creating "three winds, wherewith Cocytus to its depth Was frozen." He weeps from six eyes, tears distilling down three chins with bloody foam. At every mouth, his teeth champ a sinner, bruised as with a ponderous engine, so three are tormented. But the foremost sinner is "far more Than from that gnawing... pang’d By the fierce rending, whence ofttimes the back Was stript of all its skin."
Virgil explains that the "upper spirit, Who hath worse punishment," is Judas, with his head within and feet without. Of the other two, whose heads are under, the one hanging from the murky jaw is Brutus, who writhes and speaks not. The other is Cassius, "large of limb." Virgil states that night re-ascends, and it is time for parting, as "All is seen."
The narrator clips Virgil around the neck as bidden. Virgil, noting time and place, catches fast the shaggy sides when the wings are open enough, and steps down "from pile to pile... Between the thick fell and the jagged ice."
When he reaches the point where the thigh turns on the haunches' swelling, Virgil, with pain and struggle, turns his head where his feet stood before and grapples at the fell, "as one who mounts," making the narrator think they are turning into hell again.
Virgil, panting, says, "Expect that by such stairs as these... We must depart from evil so extreme." He issues forth at a rocky opening and places the narrator on a brink to sit, then joins his side. The narrator raises his eyes, expecting to see Lucifer where he was left, but now sees him "With legs held upward." He asks the "grosser sort" to consider if he was toiled.
Virgil cries, "Arise... upon thy feet. The way is long, and much uncouth the road; And now within one hour and half of noon The sun returns." They are in a natural dungeon with ill footing and scant light. The narrator asks Virgil, before they separate, to free him from error. He asks, "Where is now the ice? How standeth he in posture thus revers’d? And how from eve to morn in space so brief Hath the sun made his transit?"
Virgil replies that the narrator deems he is still on the other side of the center where he grasped the "abhorred worm." He was on the other side as Virgil descended; when Virgil turned, the narrator "didst o’erpass That point, to which from ev’ry part is dragg’d All heavy substance." He is now under the hemisphere opposed to the great continent, and under whose canopy "The Man, that was born sinless, and so liv’d" expired. His feet are planted on the smallest sphere, whose other aspect is Judecca. Morning rises here when evening sets there. Lucifer, whose "shaggy pile was scal’d," still stands fixed as at first. He fell down from heaven on this part, and the earth, prominent before, veiled herself with the sea through fear of him, retiring to their hemisphere. Perhaps the vacant space here was left by the firm land that sprang aloof to shun him.
Beneath, a place exists, distant from Beelzebub, discovered not by sight but by the sound of a brooklet descending through a rock, which the wave has eaten. By that hidden way, Virgil and the narrator enter to return to the "fair world." Heedless of repose, they climb, Virgil first, then the narrator, until the "beautiful lights of heav’n Dawn’d through a circular opening in the cave: Thus issuing we again beheld the stars."

**PURGATORY**

**CANTO I**
The narrator's "light bark of my genius" now lifts its sail "O’er better waves," pleased to leave the cruel sea of Hell behind. He will sing of the "second region," where the human spirit is purged of sin and prepares for Heaven. He invokes the Muses, especially Calliope, to aid his song.
A "sweet hue of eastern sapphire" spreads over the serene, pure air, renewing his joy after escaping the "deadly gloom" of Hell. The sun, the "radiant planet, that to love invites," makes the orient laugh, veiled beneath the light of Pisces.
He turns to the right and fixes his mind on the other pole, where he sees "Four stars ne’er seen before save by the ken Of our first parents." Heaven seems joyous from their rays. He laments the northern site, bereft and widowed without these stars.
As he ceases gazing, an old man stands by his side, alone, worthy of reverence. His beard and locks, mixed with hoary white, descend in a double fold upon his breast. The beams of the four luminaries shine brightly on his face, making him appear like the sun.
The old man asks, "Say who are ye, that stemming the blind stream, Forth from th’ eternal prison-house have fled?" He asks who conducted them or lit their way from the "depth of night" that makes the infernal valley black. He questions if the "firm statutes of the dread abyss" are broken or if new laws are ordained in heaven for them to approach his caves.
Virgil, laying hold of the narrator, makes him pay reverence with bent knees and submissive eye. Virgil replies that he does not come of himself, but a "Dame from heaven" (Beatrice) asked him to bring the narrator. He explains that the narrator, a mortal, never saw the "farthest gloom" but erred by folly and came so near perdition that little space was left to turn. Virgil was dispatched to rescue him, and this was the only way. He has shown the narrator all the regions of the bad and now intends to show the spirits purged from sin under the old man's command. He says "From high descends the virtue, by whose aid I to thy sight and hearing him have led." He hopes their coming pleases him, as the narrator journeys "In the search Of liberty," which is dear to those who refused life for it. He acknowledges the old man (Cato) knows this, having found death sweet in Utica, where he left his "weeds" (body) that will shine bright on the last day. Virgil assures him the "eternal edicts are unmov’d," the narrator breathes, and he (Virgil) is free of Minos' power, abiding in the circle where Cato's "chaste Marcia" beams, praying him to own her. Virgil implores Cato by Marcia's love to let them pass through his "sev’n regions," promising to thank Marcia if Cato does not disdain mention of her below.
Cato replies that Marcia was pleasing to his sight while he was there, and he granted all she asked. But now that she dwells beyond the "accursed stream," she can no longer move him by the law ordained when he issued thence. However, if a "Dame from heaven" directs Virgil, no flattery is needed; her name is enough. He instructs them to go and "with a slender reed See that thou duly gird him, and his face Lave, till all sordid stain thou wipe from thence." He says it would not be seemly for the narrator to come before the "foremost minister in heaven" with eyes obscured. He explains that the islet produces reeds on its oozy bed, and no other plant lives there. He tells them not to return this way but to let the rising sun show them the easiest ascent of the mountain.
Cato disappears. The narrator rises, speechless, and turns to Virgil, who tells him to follow his steps, as they must retreat backward, for that way the "champain to its low extreme declines."
Dawn has chased the morning prime. The narrator spies the trembling of the ocean stream. They traverse the deserted plain like one who, lost, thinks every step is in vain until he regains the path.
When they reach a place where the tender dew still strives with the sun and the wind breathes fresh, Virgil places both hands on the watery grass. The narrator, aware of his intent, stretches out his tear-suffused cheeks. Virgil restores the hue that Hell's shades concealed. Then, on the solitary shore, Virgil girds him as instructed. The narrator notes, strangely, that as Virgil plucks each humble reed, another resembling it immediately arises in its place.

**CANTO II**
The sun has reached the horizon that covers Salem's walls, and night, opposite to the sun, has issued from the Ganges, holding the scales that drop when she reigns highest. Where the narrator is, Aurora's cheek has turned to orange.
They linger by the water's brink, like men musing on their road. As Mars glares with fiery beam over the ocean floor near dawn, a light comes swiftly through the sea, no winged course equaling its career. The narrator withdraws his eyes to inquire of Virgil, then looks again and sees it grown in size and brightness. Something bright appears on either side, and then another from underneath. Virgil stands silent. The brightness reveals wings. Virgil, recognizing the pilot, cries, "Down, down; bend low Thy knees; behold God’s angel: fold thy hands: Now shalt thou see true Ministers indeed."
Virgil notes how the angel sets human means at naught, needing no oar or sail but his wings. He holds them straight up to heaven, winnowing the air with "eternal plumes."
As the "bird of God" comes nearer, he appears brighter, his splendor unbearable to the eye. The narrator bends his eyes down. The angel drives ashore in a small, swift, light bark. The "heav’nly steersman" is seen at the prow, "Visibly written blessed in his looks."
Within the bark sit "a hundred spirits and more." They all sing "In Exitu Israel de Aegypto" with one voice. As soon as the angel blesses them with the sign of the cross, they leap out on land. The angel returns swiftly as he came. The crew, left astounded, gaze around.
The sun darts its beams from every side. The strange tribe, lifting their eyes, ask, "If ye know, Declare what path will Lead us to the mount." Virgil replies they are strangers here, having come by another, rougher road. The spirits, perceiving the narrator is alive from his breathing, grow pale with wonder. Like a multitude flocking to a herald, they fix on the narrator, forgetting their errand.
One spirit darts before the rest with fond ardor to embrace the narrator. The narrator tries to embrace him thrice, but his hands return empty. The shadow smiles and draws back. The narrator hastens to follow, but the spirit enjoins him to desist with a sweet voice. The narrator recognizes him as Casella and asks him to pause and talk.
Casella replies he loves the narrator as in his mortal frame and still loves him, pausing for him. He asks why the narrator walks there. The narrator replies he journeys to return to a better life, asking how Casella lost so much time. Casella answers that the one who "when and whom he chooses takes" has often denied him passage, as his will is just. He says that three months past, the angel took those he chose, and Casella gained "kind Admittance" at the Tiber's mouth, where the angel points his wings, for "there always throng All such as not to Archeron descend."
The narrator asks if new laws have not destroyed the memory of a "sweet song of love" that used to assuage his cares, asking Casella to console his spirit, overcome by travel. Casella then begins to sing "Love that discourses in my thoughts" in such soft accents that the sweetness still thrills the narrator. Virgil and all the spirits are so pleased that nothing else seems to occupy their thoughts.
They stand fixed in mute attention. The venerable old man (Cato) exclaims, "How is this, ye tardy spirits? What negligence detains you loit’ring here? Run to the mountain to cast off those scales, That from your eyes the sight of God conceal."
