Like a flock of pigeons suddenly alarmed, the new-come troop deserts the song and hastens to the mountain's side. The narrator and Virgil depart with no less hurried step.

**CANTO III**
The sudden flight scatters the spirits over the plain toward the mountain. The narrator adheres to Virgil, wondering how he would have fared without him. Virgil seems smitten with "bitter pang of self-remorse."
As Virgil's feet cease hastening, the narrator's mind expands with joy. He sets his face against the steep ascent. The sun, flaring behind, is broken by his form. He turns aside, fearing to be left, seeing only the ground obscured before him. Virgil kindly asks why he distrusts, assuring him he is his guide. He explains that it is evening where his body lies buried in Naples, and the narrator should not marvel if no shadow falls before him, just as one ray does not obstruct another in the sky. He says that to endure "Torments of heat and cold extreme," frames are disposed by a virtue whose working God "Wills not to us should be reveal’d." He calls insane anyone who hopes reason can explore the space holding "three persons in one substance knit." He warns against seeking the "wherefore," reminding them that they have seen men desiring fruitlessly (Plato, Stagyrite, and others), whose desires now serve for eternal grief. Virgil then bends his forehead and breaks off his speech in troubled mood.
They reach the mountain's foot, finding the rock so steep that even the nimblest steps would be vain. Virgil asks, "Who knows on which hand now the steep declines... so that he may Ascend, who journeys without aid of wine?" As he explores the pathway, the narrator gazes upward and sees spirits moving toward them, yet seeming not to move, so slow is their approach.
The narrator tells Virgil to raise his eyes, as some spirits might offer counsel. Virgil looks and replies, "Let us tend thither: they but softly come. And thou be firm in hope, my son belov’d."
The spirits are a thousand paces distant when they draw backward on the crags and stand unmoved, like one walking in doubt. Virgil addresses them, "O spirits perfect! O already chosen!... Instruct us where the mountain low declines, So that attempt to mount it be not vain. For who knows most, him loss of time most grieves."
Like sheep stepping from their fold, one by one or in small groups, while the rest stand fearfully, the first of the fortunate crew move to advance, with modest mien. When they see the light from the narrator's right side fall broken on the ground, casting a shadow, they stop and retire. All who follow do the same, unaware of the cause.
Virgil confesses that the narrator is a human body and that the sun's light is broken by him. He tells them not to marvel but to believe that they aspire to climb "Over this wall" not without "Virtue deriv’d from Heaven." The virtuous tribe replies, "Turn, and before you there the entrance lies," signaling with bent hands.
One spirit begins, asking the narrator to turn his visage and think if he has ever seen him elsewhere. The narrator turns and beholds a comely, fair, gentle spirit, but with a gash marked on one brow. The narrator humbly disclaims ever seeing him. The spirit says, "Now behold!" and shows a wound high on his breast, then smiling, speaks.
He identifies himself as Manfredi, grandson to Queen Costanza. He asks the narrator, when returned, to go to his "fair daughter" (parent of Aragon and Sicily's pride) and inform her of the truth, if anything else is told of him. He says that when his frame was shattered by two mortal blows, he betook himself weeping to God, "who of free will forgives." His sins were horrible, but "goodness infinite" receives all who turn to it. He believes if "Cosenza’s shepherd" (the Pope's agent) had better scanned this divine text, his bones would have lain near Benevento, protected. Instead, rain drenches them and wind drives them "out of the kingdom’s bounds, Far as the stream of Verde," where they were removed with lights extinguished. He says that their curse does not destroy them so much that "the eternal love may turn, while hope Retains her verdant blossoms." He states that one who dies in contumacy against the holy church, though repenting, must wander "thirty-fold for all the time In his presumption past," unless prayers of good men shorten it. He asks the narrator to advance his bliss by revealing to Costanza how he beheld him and the terms of the interdict, for "here By means of those below much profit comes."

**CANTO IV**
The narrator explains that when any sensation seizes a faculty, the soul collects itself, intent on that power alone, disproving the error that the soul is not singly lighted in the breast. Thus, when something heard or seen firmly turns the soul, time passes unperceived. He found this true, hearing the spirit and wondering, for the sun had measured fifty steps aloft unobserved by him when they arrived where spirits shouted, "Here is what ye ask."
A path, narrower than a villager's thorn-forked stake for grapes, is the one by which Virgil and the narrator ascended, solitary after the troop departed. He compares it to the steep roads of Sanleo or Bismantua, requiring flight with "swift wing and plumes of high desire."
They ascend through broken rock, close-pent, needing hands and feet. Near the highest ridge, where the plain opens, the narrator exclaims, "O master! say which way can we proceed?" Virgil replies, "Let no step of thine recede. Behind me gain the mountain, till to us Some practis’d guide appear." The eminence is so lofty no eye can reach its point, and the side rises more steeply than a line from the mid-quadrant to the center.
Wearied, the narrator asks Virgil to turn and behold him, as he remains alone if Virgil does not stay. Virgil replies, "My son! Thus far put forth thy strength;" and points to a track that circles the hill. Spurred on, the narrator climbs until his feet press the plain circuit beneath. Seated together, they turn eastward, whence they ascended, a view many have looked back on with delight.
First, the narrator looks at the nether shores, then raises his eyes to the sun, wondering that it smites them from the left. Virgil, perceiving his amazement at the sun's course, explains that if Leda's offspring (Castor and Pollux, constellations) were with the sun, the "ruddy zodiac" would wheel nearer the bears. He asks the narrator to imagine Sion and this mount placed on earth with one horizon, and the path Phaeton ill knew. He will see how the sun passes by this (Purgatory) on one side and by that (Jerusalem) on the other.
The narrator exclaims, "Of truth, kind teacher! so clear Aught saw I never, as I now discern Where seem’d my ken to fail." He now understands that the "mid orb Of the supernal motion" (the Equator) departs toward the north from here when those in the Hebrew land see it toward the warmer part. He asks how far they have to journey, as the hill mounts higher than his sight.
Virgil replies that the ascent is always difficult at first but grows easier. When it seems pleasant, like going down a tide, he will have reached the end. There, he can hope to rest. Virgil says he will answer no more on this.
A voice sounds near, "Yet ye first perchance May to repose you by constraint be led." They turn and see a huge stone on the left, unnoticed before. They draw near and find some spirits standing behind the rock, as if idle. One, very wearied, sits down, folding his knees and bending his face between them.
The narrator cries, "Sweet Sir! behold that man, who shows Himself more idle, than if laziness Were sister to him." The spirit turns, lifts his face over his thigh, and says, "Up then, proceed Thou valiant one." The narrator recognizes Belacqua. Despite his breathlessness, he approaches. Belacqua barely lifts his head, saying, "Well hast thou discern’d, How from the left the sun his chariot leads."
Belacqua's lazy acts and broken words make the narrator smile. He says he grieves for Belacqua no more but asks why he is seated there, waiting for escort, or if it's just his accustomed ways. Belacqua replies, "My brother, of what use to mount, When to my suffering would not let me pass The bird of God, who at the portal sits?" He says he must wait as long as he delayed repentance in life, unless prayer from a heart in grace aids him first.
Virgil, ascending, cries, "Haste thee, for see the sun Has touch’d the point meridian, and the night Now covers with her foot Marocco’s shore."

**CANTO V**
The narrator leaves the spirits and follows Virgil. He hears one spirit exclaim, pointing at him, "See how it seems as if the light not shone From the left hand of him beneath, and he, As living, seems to be led on." The narrator turns and sees them gazing in wonder at him and the broken light. Virgil exclaims, "Why are thy thoughts thus riveted... that thou hast slack’d thy pace? or how Imports it thee, what thing is whisper’d here? Come after me, and to their babblings leave The crowd. Be as a tower, that, firmly set, Shakes not its top for any blast that blows! He, in whose bosom thought on thought shoots out, Still of his aim is wide, in that the one Sicklies and wastes to nought the other’s strength." The narrator replies, "I come," with a tinge of color that merits pardon.
Meanwhile, some spirits come along the hill, singing "Miserere." When they perceive the narrator's body blocks the rays, their song changes to a long, hoarse exclaim. Two run to meet them, asking about their condition. Virgil tells them to return and report that his frame is "real flesh." If they paused to view his shade, that is enough answer, and they should honor him.
The spirits return swiftly, like fiery vapors or August clouds. They wheel back on them. Virgil exclaims, "Many... are these, who throng Around us: to petition thee they come. Go therefore on, and listen as thou go’st."
The spirits shout, "O spirit! who go’st on to blessedness With the same limbs, that clad thee at thy birth... a little rest thy step. Look if thou any one amongst our tribe Hast e’er beheld, that tidings of him there Thou mayst report. Ah, wherefore go’st thou on? Ah wherefore tarriest thou not? We all By violence died, and to our latest hour Were sinners, but then warn’d by light from heav’n, So that, repenting and forgiving, we Did issue out of life at peace with God, Who with desire to see him fills our heart."
The narrator replies he scans their visages but remembers none. He offers to perform any service they wish, by the peace he seeks. One spirit replies none distrusts his kindness. He, speaking first, entreats the narrator, if he ever sees the land between Romagna and Charles's realm, to pray those in Fano to offer adorations for him to purge his sins. He came from there. He says the deep passages where his blood issued were made on his bosom in Antenor's land, where he thought to be more secure. The deed's author was Este's prince, who pursued him with wrath. He says he might have breathed if he had fled toward Mira when overtaken at Oriaco, but he sped to the marsh, fell, and saw his life-blood float the plain.
Another spirit says, "Ah! so may the wish, That takes thee o’er the mountain, be fulfill’d, As thou shalt graciously give aid to mine. Of Montefeltro I; Buonconte I: Giovanna nor none else have care for me, Sorrowing with these I therefore go." The narrator asks what force or chance drew him from Campaldino's field, as his sepulture was unknown. Buonconte replies that a stream called Archiano runs at Casentino's foot. He came there, pierced in the heart, fleeing on foot, bloodying the plain. Sight and speech failed him, and finishing with Mary's name, he fell, his flesh tenantless. He will report the truth for the narrator to tell the living. God's angel took him, while the angel of hell exclaimed, "O thou from heav’n! Say wherefore hast thou robb’d me? Thou of him Th’ eternal portion bear’st with thee away For one poor tear that he deprives me of. But of the other, other rule I make." He explains that evil will, following evil, raised wind and smoky mist, covering the valley with cloud from Pratomagno to the mountains. The air changed to water, rain fell, and all that the land contained rushed to the fosses and the great river. The Archiano found his "stiffen’d frame" at its mouth, dashed it into the Arno, loosening the cross he made when overcome with pain, then wrapped him in its muddy spoils.
A third spirit speaks, "Ah! when thou to the world shalt be return’d, And rested after thy long road... then remember me. I once was Pia. Sienna gave me life, Maremma took it from me. That he knows, Who me with jewell’d ring had first espous’d."

**CANTO VI**
The narrator describes how men separate from a game of dice: the loser remains sad, while the company goes with the winner, one running before, one twitching his mantle, one asking to be remembered. The winner stops not, but bids each aside. The narrator was like this, escaping the throng with pain by turning his face and promising.
He saw him of Arezzo, who fell by Ghino's arm, and him swallowed by the stream in his chase. Frederic Novello entreated with outstretched hand. He saw the Pisan who tested Marzuco's constancy. He beheld Count Orso. He saw a soul dismissed from its frame for spite and envy, not crime, Peter de la Brosse, and warns the Lady of Brabant to beware lest she herd with worse.
Freed from these spirits praying for others' prayers, the narrator asks Virgil why his text denies that heaven's decree can bend to supplication, yet these entreat. He asks if their hope is vain. Virgil replies that both his writing is plain and their hope is not deceived if the narrator considers that "the sacred height Of judgment doth not stoop, because love’s flame In a short moment all fulfils, which he Who sojourns here, in right should satisfy." He adds that in his time, prayer had no access to God. He tells the narrator not to rest content unless Beatrice assures him, as she infuses light between truth and mind. He says Beatrice is above, on the mountain's crown.
The narrator asks to mend their speed, as he is not tired and the hill stretches its shadow far. Virgil replies their progress will be as much as they can dispatch that day, but the truth is otherwise. He says the narrator cannot be there until he sees the sun return, which is now hidden behind the steep. He points out a solitary spirit looking at them, who will instruct them.
They approach the spirit. The narrator notes his "high abstracted mood," scarce moving his eyes. It speaks not, but eyes them like a lion on watch. Virgil asks it to show the best ascent. It returns no answer but asks of their country and life. When Virgil begins, "Mantua," the solitary shadow quickly rises and cries, "Mantuan! I am thy countryman Sordello." Each embraces the other.
The narrator then laments "slavish Italy!" calling her an inn of grief, a vessel without a pilot, no longer lady of provinces but a brothel. He notes Sordello's glad cheer at the sound of his dear land, while Italy's living ones war among themselves, even those within the same walls. He urges Italy to look around her coasts and within her bosom to see if any part enjoys peace. He questions the use of Justinian's laws if her saddle is unpressed, saying it only aggravates her shame. He says the people should obey and let Caesar sit in the saddle. He blames "German Albert" for abandoning Italy, which has grown savage, and calls for "Just judgment from the stars" to fall on his blood and strike his successor with dread, because Albert and his father, detained by greed for other realms, allowed the "garden of the empire" to run waste.
He urges Albert to "Come see the Capulets and Montagues, The Philippeschi and Monaldi!" and behold the oppression of nobles and their injuries, and what safety Santafiore can supply. He calls on Albert to see Rome, a "Desolate widow!" crying day and night, "My Caesar, why dost thou desert my side?" He asks him to behold the love among his people and to blush for his own report.
The narrator then asks if it is lawful for him to question "Almighty Power" why His just eyes are turned elsewhere, or if this is a preparation for some good end cut off from human thought. He notes that Italian cities are "o’erthrong’d With tyrants," and every villager is a "great Marcellus." He addresses Florence, saying she may remain unmoved by this digression, thanks to her people who "so wisely speed." He notes many have justice in their heart but wait for counsel, while Florence's people answer uncalled, crying, "Behold I stoop!" He ironically tells Florence to be glad, for she is wealthy, at peace, and wisdom-fraught, and facts will witness if he speaks truth. He says Athens and Lacedaemon made little progress compared to Florence, who uses such "nice subtlety" that she weaves a thread in October that scarce reaches mid-November. He asks how many times Florence has renewed customs, laws, coins, and offices, and changed people. If she remembers well, she will perceive herself like a sick wretch, shifting sides for short respite from pain.

**CANTO VII**
After seven joyful greetings, Sordello draws back, exclaiming, "Who are ye?" Virgil replies that his bones were buried by Octavius before this mount was sought by spirits. He is Virgil, deprived of heaven only for "lack of faith." Sordello appears to waver in belief, then bends his eyes, approaches reverentially, and clasps Virgil. He exclaims, "Glory of Latium! In whom our tongue its utmost power display’d! Boast of my honor’d birth-place! what desert Of mine, what favour rather undeserv’d, Shows thee to me? If I to hear that voice Am worthy, say if from below thou com’st And from what cloister’s pale?"
Virgil replies that he has arrived through every orb of that sad region, led by heavenly influence. He describes a place below, not made by torments but by "dun shades alone," where mourning breathes in sighs, not anguish. There he abides with "little innocents" bitten by death's fangs before being exempt from human taint, and with those who did not put on the "three holy virtues" but understood and followed the rest without blame. He asks Sordello to direct them to where Purgatory truly begins.
Sordello replies they have no certain place assigned, and he can go up or around, joining them as guide. But he notes day declines, and they cannot ascend by night. He suggests choosing a "place of pleasant sojourn," where some spirits sit apart to the right, whom they will know with delight. Virgil asks why ascending by night is impossible. Sordello, trailing his finger on the ground, says, "Only this line Thou shalt not overpass, soon as the sun Hath disappear’d; not that aught else impedes Thy going upwards, save the shades of night. These with the wont of power perplex the will." He warns they might return beneath or wander around the mountain if they try.
Virgil, wondering, asks Sordello to lead them quickly to the delightful place. They move a little space, and the narrator perceives the mountain hollowed out like large valleys. Sordello says they go "Where in a bosom the high bank recedes," and they must await the renewal of day.
A crooked path leads them between the steep and plain into the ridge's side. Refulgent gold, silver, scarlet grain, ceruse, Indian wood, and fresh emeralds surpass the herbs and flowers in color. Nature not only lavishes hues but creates a rare fragrance from a thousand smells.
The narrator sees spirits sitting on the grass and flowers, chanting "Salve Regina." Virgil tells him not to desire to be led on among them before sunset, as from this eminence, they will better discern the acts and visages of all.
He points out the one sitting highest, who seems to have neglected his duty and moves not his lip to the others' song: Emperor Rodolph, who might have healed Italy's wounds. The one comforting him with a kindly visage is Ottocar, who swayed the country where the Moldaw springs. Ottocar was worth more in his swaddling clothes than his son Winceslaus, a bearded man pampered with luxury. The one with the "nose depress," counseling with the gentle-looking one, expired flying, withering the lily's flower. He knocks against his breast. The other, making a couch for his cheek with his hand, sighs frequently. These are the father and father-in-law of "Gallia’s bane," grieving for his vicious life.
He points out one "so robust of limb," who keeps measure in song, with him of prominent feature, both braced with every virtue. If the stripling behind him had lived as king, his virtue would have poured into him, which cannot be said of the other heirs. James and Frederick hold his realms, neither obtaining the better heritage. Human worth rarely mounts the branches of the tree, as God ordains it as his free gift. Virgil's words apply to Charles no less than his brother, which Pouille and Provence now confess with grief, as that plant degenerates from its seed. Costanza still boasts of her valorous spouse more than Beatrice and Margaret.
He points out "the king of simple life and plain, Harry of England, sitting there alone," who spreads better issue through his branches. The one sitting lowest, yet gazing aloft, is William, the brave Marquis, for whose cause Alexandria's deed and his war make Conferrat and Canavese weep.

**CANTO VIII**
It is the hour that wakens fond desire in men at sea and pilgrims, making them mourn for the expiring day. The narrator, no longer listening, sees one spirit rise from its seat, imploring audience with its hand. It joins both palms and raises them, fixing its gaze eastward, as if telling God, "I care for naught beside." "Te Lucis Ante" comes from its lip in such a soft strain that the narrator's sense is lost. The rest follow devoutly through the hymn, gazing upward at the "bright supernal wheels."
The narrator urges the reader to make his eyes keen, for the veil is subtle. He sees the gentle band silently look up, pale and lowly, as if in expectation. From on high, he sees two angels descend, with "flame-illumin’d swords, Broken and mutilated at their points." Their vesture is green as new leaves, beaten by green wings. One stands a little over them, the other on the opposing hill, so the troop is contained in the middle. The narrator discerns the whiteness on their heads but their faces are lost to his dazzled eye. Sordello exclaims that both are from Mary's bosom, a guard "Over the vale, ganst him, who hither tends, The serpent." The narrator, not knowing the serpent's path, turns and presses frozen to Virgil's side.
Sordello says, "To the valley now (For it is time) let us descend; and hold Converse with those great shadows: haply much Their sight may please ye." The narrator measures only three steps before he is beneath and notes one spirit who looks desirous to know him. The air is dim, but not so dim that it conceals what was before hidden. They advance toward each other. The narrator recognizes Nino, calling him "courteous judge!" and expressing joy that he is not with the bad. They exchange kind salutations. Nino asks how long since the narrator arrived at the mountain's foot. The narrator replies he came that morning through the "sad seats of woe," still in his first life, journeying to gain the other.
Hearing his words, Nino and Sordello draw back, amazed. Nino turns to Virgil, the other to a seated spirit, crying, "Conrad! up with speed: Come, see what of his grace high God hath will’d." Nino then turns to the narrator, saying, "By that rare mark Of honour which thou ow’st to him, who hides So deeply his first cause, it hath no ford, When thou shalt be beyond the vast of waves. Tell my Giovanna, that for me she call There, where reply to innocence is made. Her mother, I believe, loves me no more; Since she has chang’d the white and wimpled folds, Which she is doom’d once more with grief to wish. By her it easily may be perceiv’d, How long in women lasts the flame of love, If sight and touch do not relume it oft. For her so fair a burial will not make The viper which calls Milan to the field, As had been made by shrill Gallura’s bird." He speaks, and his visage takes the stamp of that right seal.
The narrator's eyes travel to heaven, where the bright stars are slowest. Virgil asks what caught his gaze. The narrator replies, "The three torches, with which here The pole is all on fire." Virgil explains the four stars seen that morning are beneath, and these have risen instead.
While Virgil speaks, Sordello draws him to himself and cries, "Lo there our enemy!" pointing the way. Along the side, where no barrier rises, a serpent lies, "such haply as gave Eve the bitter food." It comes between the grass and flowers, reverting its lifted head, licking its back. The narrator does not see how the celestial falcons move from their seat, but discerns them in motion, hearing the air cut by their green plumes. The serpent flees, and the angels return to their stations.
The spirit who came to Nino does not loosen his sight from the narrator. He begins, "So may the lamp, which leads thee up on high, Find, in thy destin’d lot, of wax so much, As may suffice thee to the enamel’s height." He asks for news of Valdimagra and the neighbor part, identifying himself as Conrad Malaspina, not the old one, but from him he sprang. His love for his people is now refined. The narrator replies he has never been in their dominions, but their glory is manifest throughout Europe. He swears their honored nation does not impair "The value of her coffer and her sword." Nature and use give her such privilege that while the world is twisted by a bad head, she alone walks aright and scorns evil. Conrad then says, "Now pass thee on: sev’n times the tired sun Revisits not the couch, which with four feet The forked Aries covers, ere that kind Opinion shall be nail’d into thy brain With stronger nails than other’s speech can drive, If the sure course of judgment be not stay’d." He says he must away, as the angel comes. He would not hear more.

**CANTO IX**
Tithonus' fair consort (Aurora) looks palely over the eastern cliff, her jewel-lucent brow glittering in the sign of the "chill animal" (Scorpion). Two steps of her ascent have passed, and the third is closing its wing. The narrator, heavy with Adam's nature, sinks upon the grass, overcome with sleep, where all five (including Virgil and Sordello) are seated.
At the hour near dawn, when the swallow renews her sad lay, and minds are more wandering from the flesh, the narrator dreams he sees a "golden-feather’d eagle" in the sky, hovering for descent. He thinks he is in the place from where young Ganymede was snatched aloft. He thinks the eagle strikes its quarry only here. The eagle wheels, rushes down like lightning, and snatches him upward "even to the fire." He dreams both he and the eagle burn, and the intense flames break his sleep.
He shakes himself like Achilles, waking and wondering where he is. His comfort (Virgil) stands at his side, the sun more than two hours aloft. He looks to the sea. Virgil says, "Fear not: assur’d we are at happy point. Thy strength Shrink not, but rise dilated. Thou art come To Purgatory now. Lo! there the cliff That circling bounds it! Lo! the entrance there, Where it doth seem disparted!" He explains that before dawn, when the narrator slept, a lady named Lucia came to him in the flowery vale and asked to take the narrator, saying his way would speed easier. Sordello and the other spirits waited while she carried the narrator up to this summit, and Virgil followed her steps. She placed the narrator here, showed Virgil the entrance, then vanished with his sleep.
The narrator's doubts are replaced by certainty, and terror turns to comfort. Virgil, seeing him fearless, moves up the cliff, and the narrator follows. The narrator notes his theme rises, asking the reader not to wonder if he props the structure more artfully.
They draw near the part where a breach like a wall appears. He discerns a portal and three steps beneath it, each of different color, and one who watches silently. As he looks, he marks the watcher seated on the highest step, his visage unbearable. He holds a naked sword, whose rays glance back, making the narrator often direct his sight in vain. The watcher cries, "Speak from whence ye stand: What would ye? Where is your escort? Take heed your coming upward harm ye not."
Virgil replies that a "heavenly dame" (Lucia) told them to pass this way, as "here the gate is." The "courteous keeper of the gate" (an angel) wishes their ascent to prosper and bids them come before his steps. They go there.
The lowest stair is smooth, polished white marble, reflecting his form. The next is darker than sable grain, a rough, singed block, cracked lengthwise and across. The third, massy above, seems porphyry, flaming red like life-blood. On this, God's angel sustains either foot, seated on a diamond threshold. Virgil cheerily draws the narrator up the steps, telling him to ask with a humble heart to unbar the bolt.
The narrator casts himself piously at the angel's feet, praying for pity and to open to him, first falling thrice on his bosom. The angel inscribes seven P's (denoting inward stain) on his forehead with the blunt point of his drawn sword, crying, "Look... When enter’d, that thou wash these scars away." The angel's robe is the color of ashes or dry earth. From beneath his vestment, he draws two keys, one gold, one silver. With the pale one first, then the burnished, he plies the gate. He says if either key fails to turn, access to this alley is in vain. One key is more precious, but the other needs skill and sagacity to disengage the knot. He holds these keys from Peter, instructed to err rather in opening than keeping fast, if the suppliant implores. He thrusts open the door, exclaiming, "Enter, but this warning hear: He forth again departs who looks behind."
The hinges of the sacred ward turn with a strong, harsh grating sound, not so surlily as the Tarpeian roared when bereft of Metellus. The narrator listens to the thunder that issues forth and thinks he hears "We praise thee, O God," blended with sweet melody, like choral voices with an organ.

**CANTO X**
Having passed the threshold of the gate (which the soul's "ill affection doth disuse, Making the crooked seem the straighter path"), the narrator hears it close. He wonders what plea would have availed if he had turned his eyes back.
They mount the riven rock, winding alternately. Virgil says, "Here some little art Behooves us... that our steps Observe the varying flexure of the path." They speed so slowly that the moon once more o'erhangs her watery couch before they thread the strait. When they are free and open where the mount retires, the narrator is spent with toil, and both are uncertain of the way, standing on a plain more lonesome than desert roads.
From the brink to the foot of the steep bank, the space measures thrice a man's stature. The cornice appears equal in extent as far as the eye can see. Before their feet move on the summit, the narrator discovers the bank is white marble, so exquisitely sculpted that not only Polycletus but nature itself would be shamed.
The angel who came to earth with tidings of peace, opening heavenly gates, appears before them, sculpted to life in a sweet act. One would have sworn he said, "Hail!" for she (Mary) is imaged there, by whom the key opened to God's love, and her act impresses the words, "Behold the handmaid of the Lord."
Virgil tells the narrator not to fix his mind on one place only. The narrator turns and marks another story graven on the rock behind the virgin mother's form. He passes Virgil and draws near. There, the sacred ark is engraved, drawn by a cart and kine, awing mankind. Many people come before it, parted in seven choirs. One sense cries "Nay," another "Yes, they sing." Doubt arises between eye and smell from the curled fume of incense. Preceding the vessel, "Sweet Israel’s harper" (David) comes leaping with a light dance, girt in humble guise, seeming less and yet more than kingly. Opposite, at a great palace, Michol looks from a lattice, full of scorn and sorrow.
The narrator moves to behold the next tablet, shining whitely behind Michol. There, the "exalted glory of the Roman prince" (Trajan) is storied, whose worth moved Gregory. A widow stands at his bridle, attired in tears and mourning. A throng of knights troops around them, and eagles float overhead. The wretch appears to say, "Grant vengeance, sire! for... My son is murder’d." Trajan seems to reply, "Wait now till I return." She, hasty with grief, asks, "O sire, if thou Dost not return?" He replies, "Where I am, who then is, May right thee." She asks, "What to thee is other’s good, If thou neglect thy own?" At length, he answers, "Now comfort thee... It beseemeth well My duty be perform’d, ere I move hence: So justice wills; and pity bids me stay."
Virgil, whose ken surveys nothing new, produced that "visible speaking, new to us and strange." The narrator gazes fondly on these patterns of meek humbleness. Virgil whispers, "Lo... a multitude advance. These to the lofty steps shall guide us on." The narrator turns his eyes. He warns the reader not to miss his good purpose, hearing how God cancels debts, and not to ponder the form of suffering, but to think on what succeeds.
The narrator asks what is tending hither, as it bears no trace of human semblance. Virgil replies that they are "courb’d to earth, beneath their heavy teems Of torment stoop," so his eye struggled at first. He tells the narrator to look intently and discern their pangs. He addresses "Christians and proud! O poor and wretched ones!" who lean their trust on "unstaid perverseness." He reminds them they are worms made to form "winged insect, imp’d with angel plumes That to heaven’s justice unobstructed soars." He asks why they buoy up their unfledged souls, remaining "Abortive then and shapeless."
He describes them like corbels supporting a floor, crumpling their knees to their breast, stirring ruth. Each is more or less contracted by his burden. One, showing most patience, wails, "I can endure no more."

**CANTO XI**
The spirits chant "O thou Almighty Father," praying for God's kingdom, daily manna, and forgiveness, and asking God not to let their virtue be easily subdued by the adversary. They pray not for themselves, but for those who remain after them.
The narrator notes that these spirits go beneath a weight like that felt in dreams, all beset with unequal anguish, purging the world's darkness. He asks if their vows are offered on their behalf, what can be vowed and done by those with "root of goodness." He says it beseems them to help wash away their stains.
He addresses them, "Ah! so may mercy-temper’d justice rid Your burdens speedily, that ye have power To stretch your wing... as ye show us on which hand Toward the ladder leads the shortest way. And if there be more passages than one, Instruct us of that easiest to ascend; For this man who comes with me... but slowly mounts."
The answer comes from an unseen spirit: "Along the bank to rightward come with us, And ye shall find a pass that mocks not toil Of living man to climb: and were it not That I am hinder’d by the rock, wherewith This arrogant neck is tam’d... him, who yet lives, Whose name thou speak’st not him I fain would view. To mark if e’er I knew him? and to crave His pity for the fardel that I bear." He identifies himself as Omberto, "of Latiun, of a Tuscan horn A mighty one." His "old blood and forefathers’ gallant deeds" made him so haughty that he forgot the "common mother" and fell. Sienna's sons can tell his fate. Pride injured not only him but his kindred. He groans under this weight to appease God's justice.
The narrator bends his visage down, listening. One spirit (not the speaker), twisted beneath the weight, sees and recognizes him, calling out, holding his eyes fixed with difficulty. The narrator exclaims, "Art thou not Oderigi, art not thou Agobbio’s glory, glory of that art Which they of Paris call the limmer’s skill?"
Oderigi replies, "Brother! with tints that gayer smile, Bolognian Franco’s pencil lines the leaves. His all the honour now; mine borrow’d light. In truth I had not been thus courteous to him, The whilst I liv’d, through eagerness of zeal For that pre-eminence my heart was bent on. Here of such pride the forfeiture is paid. Nor were I even here; if, able still To sin, I had not turn’d me unto God." He laments the vanity of human glory, nipped if a less bright age does not succeed. Cimabue thought to lord over painting, but now Giotto's name eclipses his. One Guido snatched the prize from another, and perhaps one is born who will drive both from their nest. Worldly fame is a blast of wind that shifts its name. He asks if the narrator will live longer in men's mouths if his flesh shrivels, than if he had died before childhood, or before a thousand years pass, which is briefer than an eye's twinkling compared to eternity. He points to the one treading leisurely before him, Provenzano, who once resounded through Tuscany but is now scarce named in Sienna. He was sovereign when Florence's maddening rage was caught, proud as she is now loathsome. Renown is like an herb whose hue comes and goes.
The narrator tells Oderigi his sayings are true, breathing meekness and allaying his "tumours." He asks who the spirit Provenzano is. Oderigi replies he is there because he presumptuously grasped sway of all Sienna, and thus goes never-resting since he died. This is the acquittance for his daring.
The narrator asks that if souls delaying repentance linger in the lower space, how Provenzano gained admittance. Oderigi explains that "When at his glory’s topmost height... Respect of dignity all cast aside, Freely He fix’d him on Sienna’s plain, A suitor to redeem his suff’ring friend, Who languish’d in the prison-house of Charles, Nor for his sake refus’d through every vein To tremble." He says he will not say more, and his words are dark, but the narrator's neighbors will soon help him comment on the text. "This is the work, that from these limits freed him."

**CANTO XII**
The narrator journeys with the laden spirit at an equal pace as oxen in a yoke, as long as Virgil permits. When Virgil bids him quit and proceed, saying "here... behooves with sail and oars Each man, as best he may, push on his bark," the narrator raises his body upright, but his thought remains submissive.
He pursues Virgil's track. Virgil warns him to bend his eyesight down, as it will be good to ruminate the bed beneath his feet.
Like sculptured forms on earth-level tombs, the narrator sees, but with more curious skill, whatever space stretches from the mountain. He beholds Lucifer, once noblest, falling from heaven. On the other side, Briareus, pierced by celestial bolt, lies cumbering earth. He sees the Thymbraean god with Mars and Pallas, armed, gazing on the giant's limbs. He sees Nimrod, standing bewildered at the foot of the stupendous work, looking at the crowd leagued in his proud attempt on Sennaar's plain.
He sees Niobe in a trance of woe, her seven sons slain on either side. He sees Saul, ghastly, expiring on his sword in Gilboa. He sees Arachne, half spider, crawling up her unfinished web. He sees Rehoboam, no longer louring defiance, but fear-smote, whirled in his chariot with none to chase him.
He also sees how Alcmaeon forced his mother to rate her ornament, how Sennacherib's sons fell on him in the temple, how Tomyris mangled Cyrus, and how the Assyrians fled after Holofernes was slain. He marks Troy in ashes and caverns, lamenting its fallen semblance.
He wonders what master could have traced these shades and lines. The dead seem dead, the living alive. His eye sees the truth on what he treads. He tells the proud sons of Eve to swell out with stiff necks, not to veil their looks, lest they descry the evil of their path.
The narrator, so busied, does not note how much of the mount they have circled, or how much more of the sun's course has passed. Virgil admonishes him to raise his head, for it is not a time for slow suspense. He points to an angel hastening toward them, saying, "Lo Where duly the sixth handmaid doth return From service on the day." He tells the narrator to wear "seemly grace of reverent awe" so the angel may gladly forward them, considering that this day never dawns again.
The narrator, warned often against time's loss, understands. The "goodly shape" approaches, snowy white in vesture, with a visage casting streams of tremulous lustre like the morning star. He opens his arms and wings, and speaks: "Onward: the steps, behold! are near; and now Th’ ascent is without difficulty gain’d."
He notes that few hasten upon hearing such tidings. He asks, "O ye race of men Though born to soar, why suffer ye a wind So slight to baffle ye?" The angel leads them where the rock parts, beats his wings against the narrator's front, then promises he will fare safely. He compares the acclivity to steps carved in the steep above Rubaconte, relieved from the precipitous fall of the other circuit, but with tall cliffs pressing close on each hand.
As they enter, ineffable voices sing, "Blessed are the poor In spirit." The narrator notes how unlike this is to the shrieks of hell. They climb the holy stairs. The narrator feels lighter and asks Virgil what heavy thing he has been lightened of. Virgil replies that when sin's broad characters on his temples are all erased, his feet will be so overcome by heartiness of will that they will feel no labor, but delight.
The narrator, like one who finds something on his head by others' becks, stretches forth his right hand and finds only six of the seven P's traced by the angel's sword. Virgil smiles.

**CANTO XIII**
They reach the summit of the scale and stand on the second buttress of the mount. This cornice, like the former, girdles the hill, but its arch bends with a less ample sweep.
No shadow or image is seen; the rampart and path are smooth, reflecting only the rock's sullen hue. Virgil fears delay if they wait to question someone. He fixes his eyes on the sun, making his right the central point, and turns his left aside. He cries, "O pleasant light, my confidence and hope, Conduct us thou... on this new way... The universal world to thee Owes warmth and lustre. If no other cause Forbid, thy beams should ever be our guide."
They journey a mile in brief space, impelled by prompt will. Invisible spirits are heard flying toward them, courteously inviting them to "love’s table." The first voice cries, "They have no wine," passing behind them. Another comes crying, "I am Orestes." The narrator asks Virgil what tongues these are. A third exclaims, "Love ye those have wrong’d you."
Virgil explains, "This circuit... knots the scourge For envy, and the cords are therefore drawn By charity’s correcting hand. The curb Is of a harsher sound... ere thou reach the pass, Where pardon sets them free." He tells the narrator to look intently through the air, and he will see a multitude seated along the shelving grot.
The narrator opens his eyes wider and sees shadows with garments dark as the rock. As they pass, he hears a crying, "Blessed Mary! pray for us, Michael and Peter! all ye saintly host!"
The narrator thinks no man on earth is so remorseless as not to yearn with pity at the sight. His eyes teem with sorrow as he stands near enough to see their semblances clearly. Their covering seems vile sackcloth. Each leans on another's shoulder, and all lean against the cliff, like blind and poor people begging near confessionals. Heaven is a niggard of its light to them, for a wire impierces and knits up the orbs of all their eyes, like taming a hawk.
The narrator thinks it wrong to pass and look without being seen himself. He turns to Virgil, who knows his mute appeal and says, "Speak; and be brief, be subtle in thy words."
Virgil comes to the part of the cornice with no rim. On the other side are the spirits, bathing their cheeks with penitential tears forced through the "dread impalement."
The narrator turns to them and says, "O shades!... Assur’d that to your eyes unveil’d shall shine The lofty light, sole object of your wish, So may heaven’s grace clear whatsoe’er of foam Floats turbid on the conscience... As ye declare... if any soul Of Latium dwell among ye; and perchance That soul may profit, if I learn so much."
A voice replies, "My brother, we are each one citizens Of one true city. Any thou wouldst say, Who lived a stranger in Italia’s land."
The narrator notes a spirit with an expectant look, chin raised as in one reft of sight. He asks the spirit, if it was the one who answered, to disclose itself by place or name.
It answers, "I was... of Sienna: here I cleanse away with these the evil life, Soliciting with tears that He, who is, Vouchsafe him to us. Though Sapia nam’d In sapience I excell’d not, gladder far Of others’ hurt, than of the good befell me." She offers proof of her folly: when her years were waning, her fellow citizens met enemies near Colle. She prayed God to grant what He had willed (their defeat). They were vanquished, and she, watching the hunt, waxed out of bounds in gladness, lifting her shameless brow, crying, "It is over. Heav’n! I fear thee not." At her life's verge, she wished for peace with God, but repentance would not have supplied her lack of duty if the hermit Piero had not thought of her in his prayers.
She asks who the narrator is, who questions their state "with lids unclos’d, And breathest in thy talk?" The narrator replies his eyes may yet be taken, but not long, for they have not offended grievously with envious glances. But the woe beneath urges his soul with dread, and that nether load already weighs him down.
She asks who brought him aloft if he intends to return. The narrator replies, "He... who standeth mute beside me. I live: of me ask therefore, chosen spirit, If thou desire I yonder yet should move For thee my mortal feet." She replies, "Oh! This is so strange a thing, it is great sign That God doth love thee. Therefore with thy prayer Sometime assist me: and by that I crave, Which most thou covetest, that if thy feet E’er tread on Tuscan soil, thou save my fame Amongst my kindred. Them shalt thou behold With that vain multitude, who set their hope On Telamone’s haven, there to fail Confounded, more shall when the fancied stream They sought of Dian call’d: but they who lead Their navies, more than ruin’d hopes shall mourn."

**CANTO XIV**
Two spirits, bending toward each other, talk of the narrator: "Say who is he around our mountain winds, Or ever death has prun’d his wing for flight, That opes his eyes and covers them at will?" They then both address him, leaning backward, and one asks, "O soul, who yet Pent in the body, tendest towards the sky! For charity, we pray thee’ comfort us, Recounting whence thou com’st, and who thou art: For thou dost make us at the favour shown thee Marvel, as at a thing that ne’er hath been."
The narrator begins, "There stretches through the midst of Tuscany... a brooklet, whose well-head Springs up in Falterona, with his race Not satisfied, when he some hundred miles Hath measur’d. From his banks bring, I this frame. To tell you who I am were words misspent: For yet my name scarce sounds on rumour’s lip."
The first spirit replies, "If well I do incorp’rate with my thought The meaning of thy speech... thou dost speak of Arno’s wave." The other asks why he concealed the river's title, as if it were horrible. The questioned spirit replies he knows not, but "’tis fitting well the name Should perish of that vale; for from the source Where teems so plenteously the Alpine steep Maim’d of Pelorus... even to the point Whereunto ocean is restor’d... Throughout the space is virtue worried down, As ’twere a snake, by all, for mortal foe, Or through disastrous influence on the place, Or else distortion of misguided wills, That custom goads to evil: whence in those, The dwellers in that miserable vale, Nature is so transform’d, it seems as they Had shar’d of Circe’s feeding."
He describes the Arno's course: first, it finds "brute swine, Worthier of acorns," then "Curs, snarlers more in spite than power," then "dogs turning into wolves," and finally, "A race of foxes, so replete with craft." He says it will be well for the narrator if he remembers what this "erring Spirit" reveals. He foresees the narrator's grandson becoming a hunter of those wolves on the fierce stream's shore, cowing them with dread, selling their living flesh, then dooming them like an aged beast. He will reave many of life, himself of worth, leaving such havoc that it will not spread to prime lustihood again in a thousand years.
The listening spirit changes his looks, struck with sadness. The narrator, desiring to know their names, meekly inquires. The spirit who spoke replies, "Thy wish imports that I vouchsafe to do For thy sake what thou wilt not do for mine. But since God’s will is that so largely shine His grace in thee, I will be liberal too. Guido of Duca know then that I am. Envy so parch’d my blood, that had I seen A fellow man made joyous, thou hadst mark’d A livid paleness overspread my cheek. Such harvest reap I of the seed I sow’d. O man, why place thy heart where there doth need Exclusion of participants in good?"
He identifies the other spirit as Rinieri, "the boast And honour of the house of Calboli," where no heritage of his worth remains. He laments that not only his blood, but many others in that region, have been stripped of all that truth or fancy asks for bliss, and a growth of "rank and venom’d roots" has sprung. He asks, "Where is good Lizio? where Manardi, Traversalo, and Carpigna? O bastard slips of old Romagna’s line!" He notes that in Bologna, the artisan, and in Faenza, Bernardin sprout, a gentle scion from ignoble stem. He tells the narrator not to wonder if he weeps, recalling loved names: Guido of Prata, Azzo, Tignoso, Traversaro's house, Anastagio's (each disinherited), and ladies and knights who bewitched them into love and courtesy, where now malice reigns. He questions Brettinoro for tarrying, as its family has gone forth, and many hating evil have joined their steps. He praises Bagnacavallo for letting its lineage cease, and criticizes Castracaro and Conio for propagating a race of Counties. He says the Pagani will do well when their "demon child" tries from amongst them. He assures Hugolin of Fantolini's line that his name is safe, as none is looked for after him to cloud its lustre. He then tells the narrator to go, as he takes more delight in weeping than in words, such pity has wrung his heart.
They knew the gentle spirits heard their steps, so their silence assured them. As they quit them, a voice like lightning meets them, shouting, "Whosoever finds Will slay me," then flees. Another voice follows with a crash as loud as thunder, "Mark in me Aglauros turn’d to rock." The narrator retreats closer to Virgil.
All the air rests in mute stillness. Virgil says, "There was the galling bit. But your old enemy so baits his hook, He drags you eager to him. Hence nor curb Avails you, nor reclaiming call. Heav’n calls And round about you wheeling courts your gaze With everlasting beauties. Yet your eye Turns with fond doting still upon the earth. Therefore He smites you who discerneth all."

**CANTO XV**
As much of heaven's sphere appears between the close of the third hour and dawn, so much remains of the sun's journey toward the western goal. Evening is there, and here noon of night. The sun's beams strike full on their forehead. Their path has circled the mountain so they journey directly toward sunset. The narrator feels a weight of "more exceeding splendour" press on his front. Amazed, he lifts both hands as a screen, clipping the diminished orb of light. Like a ray striking a mirror, refracted light seems to smite the ground before him, making his sight recoil. He cries, "What is this, sire belov’d! ’Gainst which I strive to shield the sight in vain? And which towards us moving seems?"
Virgil replies not to marvel if the "family of heav’n" dims his sense with dazzling radiance, as it is a messenger inviting ascent. Such sights will soon impart delight as his perception is wrought up to their pitch. The angel, as they reach him, hails them with glad voice: "Here enter on a ladder far less steep Than ye have yet encount’red." Ascending, they hear "Blessed the merciful" and "happy thou! That conquer’st" chanted sweet behind them.
The narrator and Virgil pursue their upward way. The narrator asks Virgil what Romagna's spirit meant by "bliss exclusive with no partner shar’d." Virgil replies it is no wonder, as he knows the sorrow of his own worst defect, if he chides others so they may mourn less. He explains that because humans point their wishes at a mark where, by communion, part is lessened, envy causes sighs. No fear of that would touch them if love of a higher sphere exalted their desire, for there, the more they call it ours, the more each's propriety in good increases, and heightened charity wraps the cloister in brighter flame.
The narrator says he lacks more satisfaction than if Virgil had been silent, and doubt gathers. He asks how good distributed makes many possessors richer than if shared by few. Virgil answers, "Thy mind, reverting still to things of earth, Strikes darkness from true light. The highest good Unlimited, ineffable, doth so speed To love, as beam to lucid body darts, Giving as much of ardour as it finds. The sempiternal effluence streams abroad Spreading, wherever charity extends. So that the more aspirants to that bliss Are multiplied, more good is there to love, And more is lov’d; as mirrors, that reflect, Each unto other, propagated light." He says if his words do not allay his thirst, Beatrice will rid him of this want, but he must ensure the five scars on his temples are erased.
The narrator says Virgil contents him when he sees the next round gained. He is mute with wonder. Suddenly, he seems rapt away by an ecstatic vision. In a temple, he sees a crowd and a dame at the entrance, expressing a mother's love, saying, "Child! why hast thou Dealt with us thus? Behold thy sire and I Sorrowing have sought thee;" then she holds her peace, and the vision flees. Next, a female appears, tears coursing down her visage, saying, "If thou, Pisistratus, be lord indeed Over this city... Avenge thee of those arms, whose bold embrace Hath clasp’d our daughter." Her sovereign replies benignly, "How shall we those requite, Who wish us evil, if we thus condemn The man that loves us?" After that, he sees a multitude furiously stone a stripling youth, shouting, "Destroy, destroy!" The youth, heavy with death, bows to the ground, yet lifts his eyes to heaven, praying forgiveness for his foes with compassionate looks.
As his spirit returns from its airy flight, he observes it roved to no unreal scenes. Virgil, seeing him move like one shaking off sleep, exclaims, "What ails thee, that thou canst not hold Thy footing firm, but more than half a league Hast travel’d with clos’d eyes and tott’ring gait, Like to a man by wine or sleep o’ercharg’d?"
The narrator tells Virgil what appeared before him. Virgil replies that even with a hundred vizards, no thought of his could elude him. He says what the narrator saw was shown so he might freely open his heart to the "waters of peace." He asked not what ailed him to see only with the eye that sees no more when the body is spiritless, but to give fresh vigor to his foot, as "Such goads The slow and loit’ring need."
They journey through the evening sky, gazing intent at the bright vespertine ray. Slowly, a fog gathers, dark as night. There is no room for escaping, and the mist bereaves them of sight and pure air.

**CANTO XVI**
The narrator describes the fog as thicker and more palpable than Hell's gloom or any dark night. Entering its shade, his eye cannot endure it with unclosed lids. Virgil draws near, offering his shoulder.
Like a blind man following his leader, the narrator journeys through the "bitter air and foul," listening to Virgil's warning, "Look that from me thou part not." He hears voices, each praying for peace and compassion to the "Lamb of God That taketh sins away." Their prelude is "Agnus Dei," and through the choir, one voice, one measure runs. The narrator asks if these are spirits. Virgil confirms they "loose the bonds of wrath."
One voice asks, "Now who art thou, that through our smoke dost cleave? And speak’st of us, as thou thyself e’en yet Dividest time by calends?" Virgil tells the narrator to reply and ask if the passage leads upward.
The narrator addresses the spirit, asking him to come along to hear and wonder. The spirit replies his steps will follow as long as lawful, and since the smoke forbids seeing, hearing will keep them joined. The narrator explains he ascends to higher regions in his mortal body, having come through Hell's agony. He asks the spirit to reveal who he was and if he correctly tends to the pass, directing him.
The spirit replies, "I was of Lombardy, and Marco call’d: Not inexperienc’d of the world, that worth I still affected, from which all have turn’d The nerveless bow aside. Thy course tends right Unto the summit." He asks the narrator to pray for him when he comes aloft. The narrator pledges his faith.
He then expresses a doubt that sorely wrings him, now doubled by Marco's opinion and one declared elsewhere. He agrees the world is forlorn of good and swarms with evil, but asks Marco to point out the cause, as some place it in heaven, others on earth.
Marco sighs deeply and begins, "Brother! the world is blind; And thou in truth com’st from it. Ye, who live, Do so each cause refer to heav’n above, E’en as its motion of necessity Drew with it all that moves. If this were so, Free choice in you were none; nor justice would There should be joy for virtue, woe for ill." He explains that movements have their primal bent from heaven, but not all. Humans still have light to follow evil or good and "free power" of will, which, if firm, conquers. They are subject to mightier force and better nature, but remain free, "not constrain’d by that, which forms in you The reasoning mind uninfluenc’d of the stars." If mankind errs, the cause is in themselves.
He explains that the soul comes from God like a babe, artless and ignorant, save that its Maker dwells with gladness. It tastes "some slight good" and pursues it, if no guide or rein directs it. Hence, law and a sovereign were needed to mark the "fortress and main tower Of the true city." Laws exist, but none observe them, not even the shepherd of the flock, who "chews the cud but doth not cleave the hoof" (a metaphor for not distinguishing good from evil). The multitude, seeing their guide strike at the good they covet, feed there and look no further. Thus, the cause is not corrupted nature but "ill-conducting."
He says Rome once boasted two suns (Empire and Papacy) that cast light on both the world's and God's way. One has since quenched the other, and the sword is grafted on the crook, so both decline, unawed by fear. He tells the narrator to mark the blade, as each herb is judged by its seed. He says the land between Adice and Po was once courteous and valorous, but now those who for shame have left talking with good men can pass its limits securely. Three aged ones remain: Gherardo, Conrad of Palazzo, and Guido of Castello (called the plain Lombard), who lament the new times. He concludes that the Church of Rome, mixing two governments, has missed its footing and defiled itself and its burden.
The narrator replies that Marco's arguments convince him, and he discerns why Levi's offspring received no heritage. He asks who Gherardo is. Marco replies that either the narrator's words deceive or try him, as he, speaking Tuscan, appears not to have heard of good Gherardo, the only addition being his daughter Gaia's name. He bids them farewell, as dawn glimmers, and he must away before the angel appears. He would not hear more.

**CANTO XVII**
The narrator recalls being taken by a cloud on a mountain top, seeing no better than a mole. Then, as vapors melted, the sun's sphere seemed to wade faintly. He images how he re-beheld the sun, now overhanging its bed.
He describes the "quick and forgetive power" that robs them of themselves. He wonders what moves it if the senses stir not, whether light kindled in heaven or gliding down by divine will. Before him came the traces of the impiety of Procne (whose form changed into a bird), and his mind was so wrapped it gave no place to outside thoughts.
Next, a shape like one crucified (Haman) appeared in his fantasy, his visage speaking fell rancor and malice. Around him were Ahasuerus, Esther, and Mordecai. As that "unsubstantial coinage of the brain" burst like a bubble, a damsel (Lavinia) weeping loudly arose, crying, "O queen! O mother! wherefore has intemperate ire Driv’n thee to loath thy being? Not to lose Lavinia, desp’rate thou hast slain thyself. Now hast thou lost me. I am she, whose tears Mourn, ere I fall, a mother’s timeless end."
Like sleep breaking off when new radiance strikes closed lids, the imagery vanishes as light, outshining earthly beams, strikes his face. As he turns to survey his location, a voice exclaims, "Here ye mount," leaving him no other purpose than to gaze at the speaker. His virtue fails, unequal to the light. Virgil explains this is a "Spirit from above, Who marshals us our upward way, unsought; And in his own light shrouds him." He says they should not refuse to lend a ready foot, but hasten to ascend before it darkens.
Virgil leads them to a ladder. Approaching the first stair, the narrator perceives the waving of a wing that fans his face and whispers, "Blessed they The peacemakers: they know not evil wrath."
The last beams of the sun are now raised high, followed by hooded night, and many stars shine out. The narrator feels his sinews slacken and asks himself, "Why partest from me, O my strength?" They reach the summit and are fixed like a bark at land. Waiting for a short space, the narrator asks Virgil what guilt is purged on this circle.
Virgil replies, "The love of good, whate’er Wanted of just proportion, here fulfils. Here plies afresh the oar, that loiter’d ill." He tells the narrator to listen to understand more clearly.
He explains that "Creator, nor created being, ne’er... was without love, Or natural, or the free spirit’s growth." Natural love is without error, but the other swerves if bent on an ill object or through excess or defect. While it seeks primal blessings or inferior ones with due measure, no delight from it partakes of ill. But if it warps to evil, or pursues good with too much or too little ardor, the created thing works against its Maker. Hence, love is the "germin of each virtue... And of each act no less, that merits pain."
Since love intends the welfare of the loved thing, all are secure from self-hatred. And since no being can exist apart from the first, a bar restrains from hating that.
Granting this, the evil loved must be another's. Such love is gendered three ways: one hopes for preeminence by depressing a neighbor's worth; another fears loss of power, fame, or favor, sickening at the thought of a fellow rising above him; and a third thirsts for vengeance from wrong or insult. This threefold love is mourned here.
He then instructs on the other sort, which follows good with disordered course. All indistinctly apprehend a bliss on which the soul may rest, yearning after it. If they behold or seek it with "a love remiss and lax," this cornice lays its penal torment on them. Other good exists where man finds not happiness; it is not true fruition. Love too lavishly bestowed on this is mourned along three circles above them. He says not to expect account of that tripartite division, as it is fitter for the narrator's own research.

**CANTO XVIII**
Virgil ends his discourse, inquiring if the narrator is content. The narrator, still thirsty to hear him, is mute, but inwardly fears his questioning offends. Virgil, a true father, marks his secret wish and gives him boldness to speak. The narrator says his sight gathers lively virtue from Virgil's beams, so all his words are distinct. He asks Virgil to unfold "that love, from which as from their source thou bring’st All good deeds and their opposite."
Virgil tells him to direct his clear ken to what he discloses, and he will plainly behold how much the blind guides of men have erred. The soul, created apt to love, moves whichever way anything pleasing prompts her, once wakened by pleasure. Apprehension forms a counterfeit of true substance, presenting the ideal shape, which attracts the soul. If she inclines toward it, that inclining is love, a new nature knit by pleasure. As fire points up, seeking its birthplace, so the captive soul enters desire, a spiritual motion that rests not before enjoying the loved thing. This shows how truth is hidden from those who aver all love is praiseworthy in itself, though its substance seems good. Yet, if the wax is good, the impression need not be.
The narrator replies that Virgil's words and his docile mind reveal what love is, but new doubts have sprung. If love is offered from without, and the spirit knows no other footing, whether she tends right or wrong is not her desert. Virgil replies he can show what reason discovers, but what lies beyond, he must expect from Beatrice, as it is faith's task, not reason's.
He explains that the spirit, a substantial form joined with matter, has a specific virtue born of that union, felt only when it works, and proved only through effect, like vegetable life by the green leaf. Man knows not whence his intellect deduced its primal notices or his appetites their first affections; such in them is like zeal in bees to gather honey, a volition meriting neither blame nor praise. But supreme over each lower faculty, which are summoned to her bar, they have a virtue whose just voice utters counsel and whose word should keep the threshold of assent. Here is the source of merit, as affections are taken or severed. Those who reasoned to profound depths marked this innate freedom and left their moral teaching to the world. He grants that all love arises from necessity, but the power to dismiss or harbor it is in themselves. He reminds him that Beatrice calls free choice "The noble virtue."
The moon, belated near midnight, makes stars wink and fade, her disk like a crag on fire. The weight on the narrator's thought is lightened by Virgil.
The narrator, his questions answered, stands musing in dreary slumber, but not long. Suddenly, a multitude rushes from behind, turning the steep. With fury and random rout, like Ismenus and Asopus echoing for Thebes, they come tumultuous, curving their rapid steps, impelled by eagerness of holy love.
They overtake them swiftly. Two spirits at their head cry weeping, "Blessed Mary sought with haste The hilly region. Caesar to subdue Ilerda, darted in Marseilles his sting, And flew to Spain." The others shout, "Oh tarry not: away; let not time be lost Through slackness of affection. Hearty zeal To serve reanimates celestial grace."
Virgil addresses them, saying the narrator, who yet lives, desires to ascend, and asks which hand leads nearest to the rifted rock. A shade replies, "Come after us, and thou shalt find the cleft. We may not linger: such resistless will Speeds our unwearied course. Vouchsafe us then Thy pardon, if our duty seem to thee Discourteous rudeness." He identifies himself as an abbot of San Zeno in Verona during Barbarossa's reign. He foresees one with one foot in his grave who will weep for that monastery, having misused his power by setting his ill-compacted son in place of its true pastor. The narrator does not know if he spoke more, as he sped far beyond them.
Virgil, who never failed him, cries, "Hither turn. Lo! two with sharp remorse Chiding their sin!" In the rear, these two shout, "First they died, to whom the sea Open’d, or ever Jordan saw his heirs: And they, who with Aeneas to the end Endur’d not suffering, for their portion chose Life without glory." As they flee from sight, new thoughts rise in the narrator, until his eye closes, and meditation changes to dream.

**CANTO XIX**
It is the hour near dawn when the geomancer sees his "Greater Fortune" ascend. Before the narrator in his dream comes a woman's shape with stammering lips, aslant eyes, distorted feet, maimed hands, and pale color. He looks at her, and his look, like sunshine cheering numb limbs, loosens her tongue, raises her decrepit form, and illumines her faded face with love's hue. Recovering speech, she sings, "I... am the Siren, she, whom mariners On the wide sea are wilder’d when they hear: Such fulness of delight the list’ner feels. I from his course Ulysses by my lay Enchanted drew. Whoe’er frequents me once Parts seldom; so I charm him, and his heart Contented knows no void."
Before her mouth closes, a dame of holy semblance appears at her side to shame her. With stern voice, she asks Virgil, "Say, O Virgil, who is this?" Virgil approaches. The dame seizes the Siren, tearing her robes, opening her before the narrator, and showing her belly, from which a loathsome smell exhales, waking him.
The narrator turns his eyes, and Virgil says, "At the least Three times my voice hath call’d thee. Rise, begone. Let us the opening find where thou mayst pass." The narrator rises. Day fills the circuits of the mount, and the early ray smites their shoulder. The narrator follows, stooping his forehead like a man overcharged with thought. He hears, "Come, enter here," in a soft, mild tone.
An angelic shape with swan-like wings marshals them along where the sloping walls retire. Fanning them, he affirms that those who mourn are blessed, for comfort shall be theirs.
Virgil asks, "What aileth thee, that still thou look’st to earth?" The narrator replies that a "New vision" has raised strange surmises and anxious doubts, allowing no other thought. Virgil asks if he saw the "old enchantress" for whom the spirits weep, and how man may free himself. He tells him to spurn the earth and fix his ken on the lure of heaven's King. Like a falcon looking down then stretching for food, the narrator follows the call as far as the dividing rock gives way, reaching the plain.
On the fifth circle, a race of spirits appears, lying prone on the ground, weeping sorely. He hears, "My soul hath cleaved to the dust," with sighs. They ask, "O ye elect of God, whose penal woes Both hope and justice mitigate, direct Tow’rds the steep rising our uncertain way." They are told, "If ye approach secure from this our doom, Prostration—and would urge your course with speed, See that ye still to rightward keep the brink."
The narrator notes what remains hidden from them, then looks at Virgil, who interprets their suit and beckons assent. The narrator draws near and stands over the shade whose words he marked. He asks the spirit who he was, why they grovel prone, and if he wishes his service in the living world.
The spirit replies he will know why Heaven reverses their back toward its cope, but first to know him. He identifies himself as a successor of Peter, his lineage from the stream between Chiaveri and Siestri. He learned in a month and little more the weight of the robe of sovereignty. He says his conversion was late, but when he became Rome's pastor, he discerned the dream and cozenage of life, saw that the heart rested not there, and no prouder height lured him. So, enamored no more of that life, love of purer being kindled in his bosom. Until then, he was a soul in misery, alienated from God and covetous of earthly things. Now, he is punished for his doting. Such cleansing from avarice is what converted spirits need. This mount inflicts no direr penalty. As their eyes were fastened below and never lifted, justice has leveled them on earth. As avarice quenched their love of good, justice holds them prisoned, hand and foot chained, as long as heaven's Lord pleases.
The narrator stoops his knees to speak, but the spirit perceives his reverence and asks, "What cause... Hath bow’d thee thus!" The narrator replies, "Compunction... And inward awe of your high dignity."
The spirit exclaims, "Up... upon thy feet Arise: err not: thy fellow servant I... of one Sovran Power." He says if the narrator has marked the gospel truth, "nor shall be given ill marriage," he may discern the reasons of his speech. He tells him to go and linger no more, as his tarrying lets his tears, with which he hastens what the narrator spoke of. He has a kinswoman on earth, Alagia, worthy in herself if ill example does not corrupt her, and she is all that remains of him there.

**CANTO XX**
The narrator moves onward, Virgil leading, coasting along the rock wherever vacant, like a man on narrow battlements. Those on the other part, who wring out their malady drop by drop, press the verge too closely. The narrator curses the "Inveterate wolf!" (avarice) whose maw is bottomless. He asks the spheres of heaven when the one for whom fate reserves to chase her hence will appear.
They pass with wary, slow steps. The narrator is attentive to the shades, hearing them lament and wail. Amidst the wailing, one cries out, "O blessed Virgin!" like a dame in childbed, adding, "How poor Thou wast... witness that low roof Where thou didst lay thy sacred burden down. O good Fabricius! thou didst virtue choose With poverty, before great wealth with vice."
The narrator is pleased by the words and wishes to know the spirit. It speaks of Nicholas's gift to maidens to save their prime unblemished. The narrator asks who he is and why he renews such praise with a single voice, hoping for reward if he returns to life.
The spirit replies he will tell, not for hell, but because "Grace so exceeding shines" in the narrator. He identifies himself as the "root Of that ill plant, whose shade such poison sheds O’er all the Christian land, that seldom thence Good fruit is gather’d." He calls for vengeance, saying it should come if Ghent, Douay, Lille, and Bruges had power, and he implores it from Heaven's Judge. He reveals he was Hugh Capet, from whom the Philips and Louis of France descend, born of one who plied the slaughterer's trade. When the ancient kings vanished, he found the reins of empire and powers of new acquirement, so the crown was soon girt on his son's temples, from whom the anointed race begins.
He says until the "great dower of Provence" removed the stains from their lowly blood, their sway was narrow but wrought no evil. There, with force and lies, rapine began. Then, for amends, Poitou, Navarre, and Gascony were seized. Charles came to Italy and slew young Conradine, "an innocent victim," still for amends. He foresees another Charles from France, unarmed save with the lance the "arch-traitor" tilted with, who will thrust it into Florence's bowels, gaining no territory but sin and shame. He sees another, a prisoner, exposing his daughter to the market like corsairs sell slaves. He laments avarice, which subdues their blood so they care not for their own flesh. He sees the "flower-de-luce" (French royal emblem) enter Alagna to hide past and future ill, making Christ a captive in his Vicar, mocking him, applying vinegar and gall to his holy lip, and dooming him to bleed among living robbers. He sees the "new Pilate" pushing on into the temple.
He asks the "sovran Master" when he will rejoice to see vengeance. He explains that during daylight, what the narrator heard of Mary is the general theme of their prayers. But when it darkens, they utter a different strain, recording Pygmalion (made traitor, robber, parricide by gold), Midas (whose greedy wish brought derision), and Achan (who stole prey, pursued by Joshua's ire). They blame Sapphira and her husband and praise the forefeet that spurned Heliodorus. The mountain rings with the infamy of Thracia's king (Polymnestor), who slew his Phrygian charge. Last, a shout ascends: "Declare, O Crassus! for thou know’st, The flavour of thy gold." Each voice, high or low, is led through many a pitch. He says he rehearsed that blessedness not singly, but none near him raised his accent.
They part from him and try to surmount the way. The narrator feels the mountain tremble, seizing him with an icy chill, like one conveyed to death. Delos did not shake so much. A vehement shout arises from every side. Virgil draws near, crying, "Doubt not, while I conduct thee." All shout, "Glory! Glory in the highest be to God." They stand suspended like the shepherds who first heard that song in Bethlehem. When the trembling and song cease, they resume their hallowed path, eyeing the prostrate shadows who renew their mourning. The narrator's ignorance struggles with desire for knowledge, but he dares not question.

**CANTO XXI**
The narrator's "natural thirst," unquenched save from the well of the Samaritan woman, impels him to haste along the path after Virgil. Pity moves him for the vengeful deed, though just.
Like Luke's account of Christ appearing to two on their way, a shade appears behind them, contemplating the crowd beneath its feet. Unaware, they hear it say, "God give you peace, my brethren!" They turn, and Virgil returns a fitting salute, crying, "Peace in the blessed council be thy lot Awarded by that righteous court, which me To everlasting banishment exiles!"
The shade exclaims, without stopping, "How! If that ye be spirits, whom God Vouchsafes not room above, who up the height Has been thus far your guide?" Virgil replies that if the narrator's tokens (the P's) are observed, it is plain he must share in the kingdom of the just. But since Clotho has not yet drawn the yarn of his mortal life, his soul, sister to theirs, cannot mount by itself. Virgil was taken from Hell's gulf to lead him as far as his lore avails. He asks the shade to instruct them why the mount shook and trembled and why all shouted.
The narrator's thirst for knowledge abates from expectance. The shade replies that this mount witnesses nothing irregular or unsanctioned. No influence other than what heaven receives can reach them. No tempest, shower, hail, snow, frost, or dew falls higher than the "threefold steps" (of the gate). No thick clouds, lightning, or rainbow are seen. Vapor never mounts above the highest of Peter's stairs. Lower, the soil may tremble with various motion, but here, through wind pent in earth's hollow, it never trembles except "when any spirit feels itself So purified, that it may rise, or move For rising, and such loud acclaim ensues." Purification is proved by the will alone, which, free to change society, seizes the soul rejoicing in her will. Desire for bliss is present from the first, but strong propension (to sin) hinders it, opposed by heaven's ordinance. Now, propension is eager to fulfill the allotted torment.
The shade says he has lain in this punishment for "Five hundred years and more," but now feels a "Free wish for happier clime." Therefore, the narrator felt the mountain tremble and heard the spirits utter praise to their Liege Lord. The narrator is full of content.
Virgil says he now sees the net that takes them and how the toils are loosed, why the mountain rocks and why they rejoice. He asks the shade who he was on earth and why he was prostrate for so many ages.
The shade replies that in the time when Titus avenged the wounds from which Judas's blood issued, he was renowned by the "Most lasting and most honour’d name," though "not yet with faith endued."
