His "vocal Spirit" drew him from Tolosa to Rome, where he merited a myrtle garland. His name is Statius. He sang of Thebes and Achilles but fell with the second burden (the Aeneid). The sparks of his flame (inspiration) derived from the "bright fountain of celestial fire" (Virgil's Aeneid), which was his nurse and authority. He says to have lived coeval with Virgil, he would bide the revolution of another sun beyond his stated years in banishment.
Virgil turns to the narrator, enjoining silence by his countenance. But the will does not bear supreme control, and laughter and tears follow passion closely. The narrator smiles, "as one who winks." Statius breaks off, peers into his eyes, and asks why a smile beamed across his visage.
The narrator is straitened, one conjuring him to speak, the other to silence. He sighs. Virgil tells him to speak and tell Statius what he asks. The narrator says Statius marvels at his smiling, but there is room for more wonder. He reveals that Virgil, who guides his ken, is the Mantuan by whom Statius sang of men and gods. He tells Statius to believe this is the true cause of his smile.
Satius bends down to embrace Virgil's feet, but Virgil forbids him, "Brother! do it not: Thou art a shadow, and behold’st a shade." Statius rises and replies, "Now hast thou prov’d The force and ardour of the love I bear thee, When I forget we are but things of air, And as a substance treat an empty shade."

**CANTO XXII**
They leave the angel, who has erased one P from the narrator's forehead, and ascend to the sixth circle. Those whose wishes tend to justice shout, "Blessed!" and end with, "I thirst." The narrator, more nimble, journeys without toil, following the swift-footed shades.
Virgil begins, "Let its pure flame From virtue flow, and love can never fail To warm another’s bosom’ so the light Shine manifestly forth." He explains that since the spirit of Aquinum's bard (Thomas Aquinas) came among them in the deep and told of Statius's affection, his goodwill for Statius has been strong. He says the stairs will seem short. He asks Statius, as a friend, how covetous desire found place in his bosom, amidst such wisdom.
Statius, somewhat moved to laughter, replies that each syllable of Virgil's is a dear pledge of love. Things often appear to minister false matters to doubts when true causes are removed. Virgil's question assures him that he believes Statius was covetous, perhaps because he found him in that circle. Statius reveals he was too far from avarice, and for that excess, thousands of moons have passed. If he had not noted Virgil's exclamation against the "cursed thirst Of gold," he would have met the "fierce encounter of the voluble rock." He then became aware that hands may hasten to lavishment with too ample wing and turned from this evil in penitence. Many will rise from their grave with shorn locks who did not repent this offense through ignorance. He explains that the fault directly opposite to any sin wastes its rankness on a common heap here. Therefore, his lot was to be with those who wail their avarice, to cleanse himself through the reverse of their transgression.
Virgil then asks Statius, "While thou didst sing that cruel warfare wag’d By the twin sorrow of Jocasta’s womb, From thy discourse with Clio there, it seems As faith had not been shine: without the which Good deeds suffice not. And if so, what sun Rose on thee, or what candle pierc’d the dark That thou didst after see to hoist the sail, And follow, where the fisherman had led?"
Statius replies, "By thee conducted first, I enter’d the Parnassian grots, and quaff’d Of the clear spring; illumin’d first by thee Open’d mine eyes to God." He says Virgil was like one who, journeying through darkness, hears a light behind that profits not himself but makes his followers wise, when he exclaimed, "Lo! A renovated world! Justice return’d! Times of primeval innocence restor’d! And a new race descended from above!" Statius owes both poet and Christian to Virgil. He will stretch his hand to inform the lines with livelier coloring. Soon, the true belief teemed over the world by messengers from heaven, and Virgil's word accorded with the new instructors. Induced by this, Statius resorted to them, and their sanctity won him over. During Domitian's rage, he mixed his tears with theirs and succored them, and their righteous customs made him scorn all other sects. Before he led the Greeks in tuneful fiction to Thebes, he was baptized, but secretly, through fear, remained a Christian and conformed to Pagan rites. For that lukewarmness, he was fain to pace round the fourth circle for five centuries and more.
He asks Virgil, who has raised the covering hiding this blessing from him, if he knows where Terence, Caecilius, Plautus, and Varro bide, and if they are condemned. Virgil replies that these, with Persius, himself, and many others, are with "that Greek, Of mortals, the most cherish’d by the Nine" (Homer) in the first ward of darkness. There, they often converse of the mount where their nurses live. They have the bard of Pella (Alexander), the Teian (Anacreon), Agatho, Simonides, and other Greeks. Of Statius's train, Antigone, Deiphile, Argia, Ismene, and she who showed Langia's wave (Hypsipyle), Deidamia with her sisters, and blind Tiresias's daughter, and the sea-born bride of Peleus (Thetis) are there.
Both poets are silent. Four handmaids of the day have finished their office, and the fifth is at the chariot-beam. Virgil says, "Methinks, it well behooves us to the brink Bend the right shoulder’ circuiting the mount, As we have ever us’d." Custom guides them.
They go before the narrator, who follows, listening to their speech conveying "Mysterious lessons of sweet poesy." They cease, for midway a tree is found with goodly fruitage, pleasant to smell, spreading less amply downward, so none may climb aloft. A liquid crystal falls from the steep rock by the side that closes their path. The bards draw near the plant, and a voice from the leaves says, "Ye shall be chary of me;" adding, "Mary took more thought For joy and honour of the nuptial feast, Than for herself who answers now for you. The women of old Rome were satisfied With water for their beverage. Daniel fed On pulse, and wisdom gain’d. The primal age Was beautiful as gold; and hunger then Made acorns tasteful, thirst each rivulet Run nectar. Honey and locusts were the food, Whereon the Baptist in the wilderness Fed, and that eminence of glory reach’d And greatness, which the’ Evangelist records."

**CANTO XXIII**
The narrator's eyes are fixed on the green leaf, like one idly chasing the diminutive, when Virgil warns him, "Son! our time Asks thriftier using. Linger not: away."
The narrator turns his face and steps toward the sages, cheered by their converse, feeling no toil. He hears a sound of weeping and a song, "My lips, O Lord!" mingled to create pleasure and pain. He asks Virgil what he hears. Virgil replies, "Spirits... who as they go, perchance, Their debt of duty pay."
Like thoughtful pilgrims overtaking strangers, a crowd of silent, devout spirits, moving with speedier motion, eyes them as they pass. Their eyes are dark and hollow, their visages pale and lean, bones staring through the skin. The narrator thinks Erisicthon was not so dry and meager.
He muses, "Lo! the race, who lost Jerusalem, when Mary with dire beak Prey’d on her child." Their eye sockets seem like rings without gems. He wonders who would deem that the scent of water and an apple could cause such pining want. A spirit turns his deep-sunken eyes on the narrator and cries, "What grace is this vouchsaf’d me?" The narrator does not recognize him by his looks, but his voice reveals Forese. Forese implores, "Ah! respect This wan and leprous wither’d skin... this macerated flesh. Speak to me truly of thyself. And who Are those twain spirits, that escort thee there? Be it not said thou Scorn’st to talk with me."
The narrator replies that Forese's face, which he once bewailed dead, disposes him to weep now. He asks by Heaven what blasts them thus, saying he is unapt to speak while wondering.
Forese replies, "The water and tee plant we pass’d, Virtue possesses, by th’ eternal will Infus’d, the which so pines me. Every spirit, Whose song bewails his gluttony indulg’d Too grossly, here in hunger and in thirst Is purified. The odour, which the fruit, And spray, that showers upon the verdure, breathe, Inflames us with desire to feed and drink. Nor once alone encompassing our route We come to add fresh fuel to the pain: Pain, said I? solace rather: for that will To the tree leads us, by which Christ was led To call Elias, joyful when he paid Our ransom from his vein."
The narrator asks Forese how he came so soon, as not five years have passed since he changed worlds, and he thought to find him lower, where time is recompense for time. Forese replies that Nella's tears and prayers brought him early from the coast where expectance lingers, freeing him from other circles. His widow is dearer in God's sight as she is more eminent for virtuous deeds. He says Sardinia has more chaste dames than Florence. He foresees a time when Florence's unblushing dames will be warned from the pulpit not to bare unkerchiefed bosoms. He asks what savage women needed such discipline to cover their limbs. He says if they saw Heaven's swift wing approaching, their mouths would open for howling, and they shall taste sorrow before the cheek of one now rocked asleep is clothed with down. He asks the narrator to hide himself no more, as all gaze where he veils the sun.
The narrator replies that remembrance of their past together might grieve him. He says his forsaking that life was due to Virgil, who preceded him a few evenings past. He points to the sun, saying Virgil brought him through the "profoundest night Of he true dead... with this flesh As true, that follows." Virgil's comfort drew him to climb this mountain-steep, which rectifies what the world made crooked. He has Virgil's word that he will bear him company until he comes where Beatrice dwells, but must leave him there. He points to Virgil. The other shade, for whom their realm shook, is Statius.

**CANTO XXIV**
Their journey and talk are not slackened. The shadowy forms, appearing dead and dead again, show rare wonder at the narrator's life. The narrator continues, saying he journeys perhaps more tardily for others' sake. He asks Forese where Piccarda is and if he sees any notable spirits among the multitude.
Forese replies, "My sister (she for whom, ’Twixt beautiful and good I cannot say Which name was fitter ) wears e’en now her crown, And triumphs in Olympus." He adds that because spare diet has worn out their semblance, it is lawful to name each one. He points out Buonaggiuna of Lucca. He points to the face beyond him, pierced to a leaner fineness, who had keeping of the church, from Tours, purging Bolsena's eels and muscadel by abstinence.
He shows many others, all seeming content when named. The narrator sees Ubaldino grind his teeth on emptiness, and Boniface wave the crozier. He sees the Marquis, who had time to swill at Forli. The narrator singles out the one from Lucca, who seemed to note him most. He hears him whisper of Gentucca, the sound indistinct where justice fixes her sting.
The narrator asks the spirit to speak, as mutual wish prompts conversation. The spirit answers that a woman is born whose brow no wimple shades yet, who will make his city please the narrator. He tells the narrator to go with this forewarning, and if his whisper implied anything false, the event will tell. He asks if the narrator is the inventor of the "new lay" beginning with "Ladies, ye that con the lore of love."
The narrator replies he is "the scribe of love; that, when he breathes, Take up my pen, and, as he dictates, write."
The spirit replies that the hindrance that held the notary, Guittone, and himself short of that "new and sweeter style" is now disclosed. He sees how they stretch their plumes as the inditer guides them, which theirs did not. He who seeks a grace beyond sees not the distance between styles. He then holds his peace, contented.
Like birds wintering near the Nile, the tribe of spirits turn their visage, deaf, nimble alike through leanness and desire. Like a man tired from a trotting steed, Forese lets the holy crew proceed, lingering at the narrator's side, asking, "When shall I again behold thee?"
The narrator replies he knows not how long his life will last, but his wishes will arrive before him, as his place of living is daily scooped of good and threatened by ruin.
Forese cries, "Go now: lo! he, whose guilt is most, Passes before my vision, dragg’d at heels Of an infuriate beast." He describes it speeding toward the vale of no redemption, each step increasing swiftness, until it strikes a blow that leaves him a "corse most vilely shatter’d." He looks up to heaven, saying, "No long space Those wheels have yet to roll... ere thou shalt plainly see That which my words may not more plainly tell. I quit thee: time is precious here: I lose Too much, thus measuring my pace with shine."
Like a knight pricking forth from chivalry, he parts with lengthened strides, leaving the narrator with Virgil and Statius.
When Forese is out of sight, branches of another fruit, thick hung and blooming fresh, appear. As they turn thither, a multitude beneath it raises their hands, shouting to the boughs, like greedy children begging. He at arm's length holds the object of their wish above them.
At length, undeceived, they go their way. They approach the tree, which vows and tears sue to in vain. Sounds from the thickets say, "Pass on, And come not near. Stands higher up the wood, Whereof Eve tasted, and from it was ta’en This plant." The narrator passes forth with both bards.
Next, they hear, "Remember... those noblest creatures of the clouds, How they their twofold bosoms overgorg’d Oppos’d in fight to Theseus: call to mind The Hebrews, how effeminate they stoop’d To ease their thirst; whence Gideon’s ranks were thinn’d."
Coasting near one border, they still hear the sins of gluttony, with woe requited. Then, along the lonely path, they travel a thousand paces, contemplative and mute.
Suddenly, a voice exclaims, "Why pensive journey thus ye three alone?" The narrator shakes and raises his head. He sees a shape as bright and glowing red as glass or metal in a furnace. The shape cries, "If ye desire to mount... here must ye turn. This way he goes, Who goes in quest of peace." His countenance dazzles the narrator, who faces backward to his guides, walking as sound directs.
A gentle wind, like May's air, breathes on his front, and he perceives the moving of a wing shedding ambrosial smell. Then a voice says, "Blessed are they, whom grace Doth so illume, that appetite in them Exhaleth no inordinate desire, Still hung’ring as the rule of temperance wills."

**CANTO XXV**
It is an hour when one climbing needs to walk uncrippled, as the sun has left Taurus and the night the Scorpion. They enter their way, one before the other, as only singly can one climb the steep, narrow scale.
Like a young stork lifting its wing to fly but not venturing to quit the nest, the narrator's desire to question his guide arises and falls. Virgil, not restrained by their haste, says, "Fear not to speed the shaft, that on thy lip Stands trembling for its flight." Encouraged, the narrator asks, "How there can leanness come, Where is no want of nourishment to feed?"
Virgil replies that if he had remembered Meleager wasting with the brand, or how his reflected form vibrates in a mirror, this would not trouble him. But to fully repose his will in certainty, he calls on Statius to heal his wound.
Statius replies, "If in thy presence I unfold to him The secrets of heaven’s vengeance, let me plead Thine own injunction, to exculpate me." He then begins, "Attend my words, O son, and in thy mind Receive them: so shall they be light to clear The doubt thou offer’st. Blood, concocted well, Which by the thirsty veins is ne’er imbib’d, And rests as food superfluous... in the heart Derives effectual virtue, that informs The several human limbs, as being that, Which passes through the veins itself to make them."
He explains that more concocted, it descends where shame forbids mention, and from there distills into a natural vessel on another's blood. Then each unites, one to endure, the other to act, through the recipient mold. It begins to coagulate, then vivifies what its substance caused to bear. With animation, the active virtue (differing from a plant only in being on the way or at its limit) continues to operate, moving and feeling like a sea sponge, assuming organic powers. This is the period when the virtue from the generating heart is pliable and expansive, for each limb is planned in the heart by nature. He explains how an animal becomes a babe, saying that the narrator erred in making the soul disjoined from passive intellect because he saw no organ for the latter.
He tells the narrator to open his bosom to the truth: as soon as articulation is complete in the embryo's brain, the "primal Mover" turns with a smile of joy on such work and imbreathes a new spirit replete with virtue, which draws what it finds active to its own substance, forming an individual soul that lives, feels, and reflects on itself. To make the narrator marvel less, he points to the sun's heat changing wine, mixed with moisture filtered through the vine.
When Lachesis has spun the thread, the soul takes with her both human and divine, memory, intelligence, and will, keener than before, other powers inactive. Self-moving, it falls to one strand where the departed roam, learning its destined path. As the place receives her, the plastic virtue beams, distinct as in living limbs. As air, saturated with showers, refracts a beam and decks itself with hues, so the ambient air wears the form imprinted by the soul. Like a flame following fire, the new form follows the spirit. Hence, it has semblance and is called shadow, endowed with every sense, even sight. Hence, speech, laughter, tears, and sighs are theirs, which the narrator may have witnessed on the mount. The obedient shadow presents whatever passion moves within them. This is the cause of what the narrator marvels at.
They reach the last flexure of their way and turn right, where "other care Awaits us." The rocky precipice hurls forth flames, and a blast drives them back. They must pass one by one along the side bordering the void. The narrator fears fire on one hand and falling headlong on the other. Virgil warns, "Strict rein must in this place direct the eyes. A little swerving and the way is lost."
From the burning mass, the narrator hears "O God of mercy!" sung and feels desire to turn. He sees spirits proceeding along the flame and wishes to share his view between their footsteps and his own. At the hymn's close, they shout, "I do not know a man;" then in low voice again take up the strain, which ends with, "To the wood... Ran Dian, and drave forth Callisto, stung With Cytherea’s poison." Then they return to their song, extolling many pairs who lived chastely and the bands of wedded love. They do not cease this task as long as the fire clasps them, as such skill is needed to medicine the last-healing wound.

**CANTO XXVI**
As they walk singly along the rim, Virgil often warns the narrator to look well. The sun has changed the western clime from azure to white. The narrator's passing shadow makes the umbered flame burn ruddier. Many spirits marvel at this strange sight.
This gives occasion to speak of the narrator: "He seems... no insubstantial frame." To gain certainty, they stretch toward him, careful not to overpass the burning pale. One spirit asks, "O thou, who followest The others, haply not more slow than they, But mov’d by rev’rence, answer me, who burn In thirst and fire: nor I alone, but these All for thine answer do more thirst, than doth Indian or Aethiop for the cooling stream. Tell us, how is it that thou mak’st thyself A wall against the sun, as thou not yet Into th’ inextricable toils of death Hadst enter’d?"
The narrator would have declared himself, but his attention turns to a new appearance. Meeting these, a crowd comes midway the burning path. The narrator sees the shadows press forward, each snatching a hasty kiss, then moving away. He compares this to ants peering at each other.
After this friendly greeting, before the first step onward, loud clamor rises from either tribe. Those newly come shout "Sodom and Gomorrah!" These shout, "The cow Pasiphae enter’d, that the beast she woo’d Might rush unto her luxury." Like cranes flying to Riphaean mountains or Lybic sands, one crowd hastens off, the other advances, resuming their song and shout.
The same spirit who asked before draws near, eager to listen. The narrator, having noted their will twice, speaks: "O spirits secure, Whene’er the time may be, of peaceful end! My limbs, nor crude, nor in mature old age, Have I left yonder: here they bear me, fed With blood, and sinew-strung. That I no more May live in blindness, hence I tend aloft. There is a dame on high, who wind for us This grace, by which my mortal through your realm I bear. But may your utmost wish soon meet Such full fruition, that the orb of heaven, Fullest of love, and of most ample space, Receive you, as ye tell (upon my page Henceforth to stand recorded) who ye are, And what this multitude, that at your backs Have past behind us."
Each spirit appears confounded and struck dumb, like a rustic entering a city. But when rid of that amaze, the one who questioned before resumes: "O blessed, who, for death preparing, tak’st Experience of our limits, in thy bark! Their crime, who not with us proceed, was that, For which, as he did triumph, Caesar heard The snout of ‘queen,’ to taunt him. Hence their cry Of ‘Sodom,’ as they parted, to rebuke Themselves, and aid the burning by their shame. Our sinning was Hermaphrodite: but we, Because the law of human kind we broke, Following like beasts our vile concupiscence, Hence parting from them, to our own disgrace Record the name of her, by whom the beast In bestial tire was acted." He says the narrator now knows their deeds and sin. He says time permits not to tell their names, but the narrator can learn what he wishes of him: "Guinicelli I, Who having truly sorrow’d ere my last, Already cleanse me."
The narrator feels pious joy, like two sons gazing on their mother rescued from Lycurgus, when he hears the name of him who was a father to him and his betters in sweet rhymes of love. He listens thoughtfully, gazing on him, approaching not nearer only for the fire. When his eyes are fed, he devotes himself to Guinicelli's service. Guinicelli replies that what he hears is deeply engraved and Lethe will not wash it off. He asks what cause impels the love his looks and speech betray.
The narrator answers, "Those dulcet lays... which, as long As of our tongue the beauty does not fade, Shall make us love the very ink that trac’d them."
Guinicelli cries, "Brother!" and points to a shade before him, saying there is one whose mother tongue owes him a fairer ornament. He stands unrivaled in love ditties and prose tales, letting fools talk who think the songster of Limoges (Giraut de Bornelh) overtops him. He says rumor and popular voice are looked to more than truth. He notes many of the elder time cried up Guittone until truth vanquished by strength of numbers. He asks the narrator, if he has gained free entrance to the cloister where Christ is Abbot, to say one Paternoster for him. Guinicelli then vanishes through the fire like a fish.
The narrator draws a little onward to the spirit Guinicelli showed him and asks his name. The spirit frankly begins, "Thy courtesy So wins on me, I have nor power nor will To hide me. I am Arnault; and with songs, Sorely lamenting for my folly past, Thorough this ford of fire I wade, and see The day, I hope for, smiling in my view. I pray ye by the worth that guides ye up Unto the summit of the scale, in time Remember ye my suff’rings." With such words, he disappears in the refining flame.

**CANTO XXVII**
The sun is stationed as when its early radiance quivers on the heights where Christ's blood streamed, while Libra hangs above Hesperian Ebro, and new fires flash on Ganges' tide.
Day is sinking when the angel of God appears before them, joy in his mien. He stands forth from the flame on the brink and sings, "Blessed are the pure In heart," in a voice of lively clearness. As they come near, he cries, "Go ye not further, holy spirits! Ere the fire pierce you: enter in; and list Attentive to the song ye hear from thence."
The narrator, hearing this, is like one laid in the grave. He clasps his hands, stretches them upward, and looks at the fire, his fancy conjuring forms consumed in flames.
The escorting spirits turn with gentle looks. Virgil says, "My son, Here torment thou mayst feel, but canst not death. Remember thee, remember thee, if I Safe e’en on Geryon brought thee: now I come More near to God, wilt thou not trust me now? Of this be sure: though in its womb that flame A thousand years contain’d thee, from thy head No hair should perish. If thou doubt my truth, Approach, and with thy hands thy vesture’s hem Stretch forth, and for thyself confirm belief. Lay now all fear, O lay all fear aside. Turn hither, and come onward undismay’d." The narrator, though conscience urged, does not advance.
When Virgil sees him fixed and obstinate, he cries, "Mark now, my son, From Beatrice thou art by this wall Divided." Like Pyramus's eye opening at Thisbe's name, the narrator turns to Virgil, relenting, when he hears the name that springs forever in his breast.
Virgil shakes his forehead and says, "How long Linger we now?" then smiles like one smiling at a child eyeing fruit. He walks into the fire before the narrator, and asks Statius, who had parted them, to come behind.
The narrator would have cast himself into molten glass to cool, so intense is the conflagrant mass. Virgil, to comfort him, talks of Beatrice, saying, "Her eyes... E’en now I seem to view." From the other side, a voice singing guides them, and following it, they issue forth where the path leads upward. They hear, "Come... Come, blessed of my Father." These sounds hail them from a light so radiant the narrator cannot endure the view. The voice adds, "The sun... hastes: and evening comes. Delay not: ere the western sky is hung With blackness, strive ye for the pass."
Their way rises upright within the rock, facing a part of heaven that shrouds the sinking sun's beams from his steps. Not many stairs are passed when they perceive the sun behind them by the fading shadow. Before one face of darkness involves the horizon, each has made a stair his pallet, not from failing will but power, forbidden further travel by the mountain's nature. Like goats ruminating under shade, or a swain lodging by his flock, all three abide, the narrator as a goat, Virgil and Statius as shepherds, close-pent by shelving rock.
A little glimpse of sky is seen above, showing stars in magnitude and lustre with more than wonted glory. As he lies gazing, sleep overcomes him, bringing tidings of future hap. About the hour when Venus lightens the mountain from the east, the narrator dreams a young, beautiful lady is passing over a lea, bending to cull flowers, singing, "Know ye, whoever of my name would ask, That I am Leah: for my brow to weave A garland, these fair hands unwearied ply. To please me at the crystal mirror, here I deck me. But my sister Rachel, she Before her glass abides the livelong day, Her radiant eyes beholding, charm’d no less, Than I with this delightful task. Her joy In contemplation, as in labour mine."
As glimmering dawn appears, darkness flees, and with it his slumber. He rises and sees Virgil already risen. Virgil says, "That delicious fruit, Which through so many a branch the zealous care Of mortals roams in quest of, shall this day Appease thy hunger." The narrator finds this greeting pleasant. Desire to mount grows within him, and at each step, he feels wings increasing for flight.
When they reach the topmost round of the ladder, Virgil fixes his eyes on the narrator and says, "Both fires, my son, The temporal and eternal, thou hast seen, And art arriv’d, where of itself my ken No further reaches. I with skill and art Thus far have drawn thee. Now thy pleasure take For guide. Thou hast o’ercome the steeper way, O’ercome the straighter. Lo! the sun, that darts His beam upon thy forehead! lo! the herb, The arboreta and flowers, which of itself This land pours forth profuse! Till those bright eyes With gladness come, which, weeping, made me haste To succour thee, thou mayst or seat thee down, Or wander where thou wilt. Expect no more Sanction of warning voice or sign from me, Free of thy own arbitrement to choose, Discreet, judicious. To distrust thy sense Were henceforth error. I invest thee then With crown and mitre, sovereign o’er thyself."

**CANTO XXVIII**
Through the "celestial forest," whose thick shade tempers the new-springing day, the narrator eagerly leaves the bank, pursuing his way leisurely along the champaign, which breathes delicious odor. A pleasant, unvarying air smites his temples, making the sprays lean trembling toward where the mountain casts its shade. Yet, the feathered quiristers still apply their art, welcoming the hours of prime and warbling amid the leaves. His slow steps have carried him so far into the wood that he cannot see where he entered when his path is bounded by a rill. The water flows to the left, rippling the grass, and is transpicuous and clear, unlike any earthly wave, yet it rolls darkly beneath perpetual gloom, admitting neither sun nor moon.
His feet do not advance, but his eyes pass over the streamlet to survey the tender May-bloom. Suddenly, he beholds a lady all alone, singing and culling flowers. He addresses her, "Lady beautiful! Thou, who... with love’s own beam Dost warm thee... Ah! please thee hither towards the streamlet bend Thy steps so near, that I may list thy song. Beholding thee and this fair place, methinks, I call to mind where wander’d and how look’d Proserpine, in that season, when her child The mother lost, and she the bloomy spring."
Like a lady turning in a dance, she turns at his suit, maiden-like, veiling her sober eyes, and comes so near that he distinctly catches her dulcet sound. Arriving where the limpid waters lave the sward, she raises her eyes, which shoot splendor. She stands on the opposite bank and smiles, shifting the intermingling dyes (flowers) with her graceful fingers, which the lofty land unbosoms without seed. Only three paces separate them, yet the flood is more hateful to the narrator than the Hellespont was to Leander, because it gives no passage.
She says, "Strangers ye come, and haply in this place, That cradled human nature in its birth, Wond’ring, ye not without suspicion view My smiles: but that sweet strain of psalmody, ‘Thou, Lord! hast made me glad,’ will give ye light, Which may uncloud your minds. And thou, who stand’st The foremost, and didst make thy suit to me, Say if aught else thou wish to hear: for I Came prompt to answer every doubt of thine."
The narrator replies he knows not how to reconcile this wave and rustling sound with what he heard of opposite report (from Statius). She answers she will unfold the cause and purge the cloud. She explains that the "First Good," whose joy is only in himself, created man for happiness and gave this place as a pledge of eternal peace. Man fell through his own defect, changing laughter and delight to bitterness. To prevent vapors from earth or waters from ascending to vex man's state, this mountain rose high toward heaven, exempt from elemental rage where the gate bars its limit. Because the circumambient air circles with its first impulse, it strikes the summit, making the wood resound. The shaken plant impregnates the voyaging breeze, which flies abroad, and the other land receives it, conceiving and producing many trees of various virtue. This explains why some plants on earth are found without apparent seed.
She further explains that this holy plain is filled with "prolific foison of all seeds" and bears fruit never plucked elsewhere. The water he beholds does not spring from a vein but issues from a "fountain, solid, undecaying, sure," and by God's will, feeds whatever it pours on either side. On one side, it takes away remembrance of offense (Lethe); on the other, it brings back remembrance of good deeds (Eunoe). Both must be tasted. She says though his thirst may be content, she will give a corollary: those whose verse recorded the golden age on Parnassus perhaps dreamed of this place. Here was man guiltless, here perpetual spring and every fruit, and this the "far-fam’d nectar."
Turning to the bards, the narrator notes a smile at her conclusion, then directs his face to the lady.

**CANTO XXIX**
Singing as if enamored, she resumes and closes her song with "Blessed they whose sins Are cover’d." Like wood-nymphs, she moves against the current up the verdant rivage, and the narrator follows.
Not a hundred paces between them, the bank bends to face the orient. She turns to him and cries, "My brother! look and hearken." A sudden lustre runs across the forest, so bright he doubts it is lightning. But it endures and waxes, and a sweet melody runs through the luminous air. The narrator chides the hardihood of "our first parent" for not enduring restraint of any veil, which would have brought ineffable joys.
Walking in suspense through that wilderness of sweets, expectant of higher beatitude, he sees the air glow like a blazing fire under green boughs, and hears distinct melody. He invokes the "thrice holy virgins" (Muses) to aid him, as the verse unfolds things that mock thought.
A space onward, what seem seven trees of gold appear, but closer, he discerns them as "tapers of gold" and traces the sound "Hosanna" in the singing. Their garniture flames with more ample lustre than the moon.
The narrator turns to Virgil, who shows no less amazement. His view reverts to the lofty things moving so slowly that a bride would outstrip them. The lady (Matilda) calls aloud, "Why thus yet burns Affection in thee for these living, lights, And dost not look on that which follows them?"
The narrator marks a tribe walking behind them, attendant on their leaders, clothed in white raiment. The watery gleam on his left reflects his left side like a mirror.
He stands on the river's edge, separated only by the stream, for a clearer prospect. He beholds the flames go onward, painting the air behind them with "liveliest pencils," distinctly marked with the seven listed colors of the sun's bow and Cynthia's zone. These streaming gonfalons flow beyond his vision. Ten paces separate the outermost.
Beneath this beautiful sky, "foul and-twenty elders" come, two by two, crowned with flower-de-luces. All sing one song: "Blessed be thou among The daughters of Adam! and thy loveliness Blessed for ever!" After these, four animals come, each crowned with verdurous leaf, with six wings full of eyes. The narrator says he will not waste more rhymes on their form, but refers the reader to Ezekiel, who paints them coming from the north by Chebar's flood, in whirlwind, cloud, and fire, and such as he describes them, here they are, save for the pennons, where John accords with him.
The space surrounded by the four encloses a triumphal car on two wheels, drawn by a Gryphon. The Gryphon stretches either wing uplifted between the middle and the three listed hues on each side, so the wings cleave none. Its bird-like members are golden, the rest white with vermeil. The narrator says no car in Rome graced Augustus' or Africanus' pomp like this, not even the sun's chariot that fell at Tellus' prayer.
Three nymphs circle at the right wheel, one ruddy, one emerald, one snow-white. Now the white, now the ruddy leads, and the others take their treasure from her song. At the other wheel, a quaternion band, each in purple, advances with festive step, one conducting the rest, one with three eyes on his front. In the rear, two old men, dissimilar in raiment but alike in port and gesture, solid and grave. One shows himself a favored counselor of the "great Coan" (Hippocrates). His fellow marks an opposite intent, bearing a sword whose glitter and keen edge appall the narrator. Next, four others of humble seeming, and behind them all, one single old man, sleeping as he comes, with a shrewd visage. These seven are habited like the first troop but wear no lilies, rather roses and vermeil flowers, appearing as if on fire above their brow.
When the car is opposite him, a thundering is heard, at which the chosen multitude halts, making a solemn halt with the first ensigns.

**CANTO XXX**
As the polar light, which knows no setting or rising, stands firmly fixed, convoying each to duty, the saintly tribe in the van turn to the car. One, as if commissioned, thrice shouts, "Come, spouse, from Libanus!" and all the rest take up the song. The narrator compares this to the blessed rising at the last audit. A hundred ministers and messengers of eternal life spring from the sacred litter at the elder's voice. They cry, "Blessed thou! who com’st!" and scatter "Unwith’ring lilies" overhead and around.
The narrator has seen the eastern clime roseate at daybreak. Thus, in a cloud of flowers from angelic hands, falling within and outside the car, a virgin appears in his view, veiled in white with an olive wreath, beneath a green mantle, robed in the hue of living flame.
No shuddering terror creeps over his spirit, which had long abode in her presence. His eyes no longer recognize her, yet a hidden virtue moves from her, awakening the power of ancient love within him.
No sooner does the heavenly influence, which thrilled him in childhood, smite his vision than he turns leftward to Virgil, panting like a babe seeking refuge. He would have cried, "There is no dram of blood, That doth not quiver in me. The old flame Throws out clear tokens of reviving fire:" but Virgil has left them, his "best-lov’d father," to whom he gave himself for safety. Nothing could save his undewed cheeks from tears.
A voice says, "Dante, weep not, that Virgil leaves thee: nay, Weep thou not yet: behooves thee feel the edge Of other sword, and thou shalt weep for that."
Like an admiral pacing the deck, inspiring his crew, the narrator sees the virgin stationed on the left side of the car, turning at the sound of his own name. She bends her eyes toward him across the stream. Though her veil, bound with Minerva's foliage, prevents him from seeing her clearly, she adds with royal act, "Observe me well. I am, in sooth, I am Beatrice. What! and hast thou deign’d at last Approach the mountain? knewest not, O man! Thy happiness is whole?"
His eyes fall on the clear fount, but seeing himself, he recoils to the greensward, such is the shame on his forehead. She looks with stern majesty, like a mother to her awe-struck child, a flavor of bitterness mingled in her pity. Her words break off, and the angels sing, "In thee, O gracious Lord, my hope hath been:" but go no farther than, "Thou Lord, hast set My feet in ample room."
Like snow melting in the sun-thaw, the narrator is without sigh or tear until the angels sing, their warbling chiming with heaven's sphere. When their "dulcet symphony" expresses soft compassion for him, the ice congealed about his bosom turns to spirit and water, gushing forth from his lips and eyelids.
Beatrice stands immovable on the chariot's right edge and addresses the bright semblances, "Ye in th’ eternal day your vigils keep... thence with more heed I shape mine answer, for his ear intended, Who there stands weeping, that the sorrow now May equal the transgression." She explains that not only through the mighty orbs but through "benign Largess of heav’nly graces," the narrator was in his freshness "so gifted virtually, that in him All better habits wond’rously had thriv’d." The more kindly strength in the soil, the more evil seed and lack of culture mar it. Her looks sometimes upheld him, as she showed her youthful eyes and led him by their light. But as she reached the threshold of her second age and changed her mortal for immortal, he left her and gave himself to others. When she rose from flesh to spirit, with increased beauty and virtue, she was less dear to him. His steps turned to deceitful ways, following false images of good. Her inspirations, in dreams and otherwise, availed not to call him back. He fell so deep that only his viewing the "children of perdition" could preserve him. To this end, she visited the "purlieus of the dead," and Virgil received her supplications. It would be a breaking of God's decree if Lethe were passed and its food tasted "Without the cost of some repentant tear."

**CANTO XXXI**
Beatrice turns her words to the narrator, asking him, "Say thou, who stand’st beyond the holy stream, If this be true. A charge so grievous needs Thine own avowal." Such amazement hangs on his faculty that his voice expires imperfectly.
After a little space, she asks, "What dost thou muse on? Answer me. The wave On thy remembrances of evil yet Hath done no injury." A mingled sense of fear and confusion produces an imperfect "Yea" from his lips. Like a cross-bow bent beyond its pitch, the narrator bursts beneath the heavy load with tears and sighs, his voice slackened.
She asks, "When my desire invited thee to love The good, which sets a bound to our aspirings, What bar of thwarting foss or linked chain Did meet thee, that thou so should’st quit the hope Of further progress, or what bait of ease Or promise of allurement led thee on Elsewhere, that thou elsewhere should’st rather wait?"
The narrator draws a bitter sigh, then wails, "Thy fair looks withdrawn, Things present, with deceitful pleasures, turn’d My steps aside." She replies that even if he had been silent or denied, he would not have hidden his sin, as her eye observes it. But when the sinner's cheek breaks into tears of self-accusing, justice's wheel runs counter to the edge. She tells him to lay aside his grief and listen as she unfolds how her buried flesh should have impelled him. He never saw anything in art or nature so sweet as her limbs, which are now dust. If the sweetest thing failed him with her death, what mortal thing should have tempted his wish? When he first felt the dart of perishable things, upon her departing for better realms, he should have pruned his wing to follow her, not stooped again for a slight girl or other transient gaud. The new bird awaits the fowler's aim twice or thrice, but for one with full plumes, the net is spread in vain.
The narrator stands silent and ashamed like a child, acknowledging his fault. She resumes, "If, but to hear thus pains thee, Raise thou thy beard, and lo! what sight shall do!"
With less reluctance than a sturdy holm torn by a blast, the narrator raises his visage. By "the beard," he notes the secret sting of her words.
No sooner does he lift his aspect than the vision of goodly creatures vanishes. His eyes, wavering, bend their light on Beatrice. She turns toward the Gryphon, and even under her veil, parted by the verdant rill, she appears more lovely than her former self, surpassing all others on earth. Remorseful goads shoot through him. Everything else that had beguiled him is now loathsome. The bitter consciousness smites his heart, and he falls to the ground.
When his strength returns, he finds the lady he first saw (Matilda) above him. She cries, "Loose me not... Loose not thy hold;" and drags him up to his neck into the stream, sweeping along swiftly like a shuttle.
Approaching the blessed shore, "Tu asperges me" is heard so sweetly that the narrator cannot remember or tell the sound. The beautiful dame, expanding her arms, clasps his temples and immerses him where the wave should drench him. Raising him up, she presents him, so laved, to the "fourfold dance of lovely nymphs," who cover him with their arms. Nick Carraway, the narrator, begins by recounting advice his father gave him about reserving judgments, a habit he generally maintains, except for Jay Gatsby, the man who gives his name to the book. Nick describes Gatsby as having an "extraordinary gift for hope" and "romantic readiness."

In the spring of 1922, Nick, a graduate of New Haven and a veteran of the Great War, moves East from the Middle West to learn the bond business. He rents a small, weather-beaten bungalow in West Egg, Long Island, situated between two enormous mansions. One of these belongs to Jay Gatsby. Across the bay, in the more fashionable East Egg, live his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, former football player husband, Tom Buchanan, whom Nick knew from college.

Nick visits the Buchanans for dinner. Tom is a physically imposing and arrogant man who expresses racist views about "The Rise of the Coloured Empires" and the "Nordic race." Daisy is charming but seems restless and cynical. Also present is Jordan Baker, a professional golfer, whom Nick finds intriguing. During dinner, the telephone rings for Tom, and Jordan reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy, aware of Tom's infidelity, expresses a desire for her young daughter to be a "beautiful little fool." After dinner, Nick observes Tom and Daisy in a moment of strained intimacy. Upon returning home, Nick sees Gatsby for the first time, standing alone on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a distant green light across the bay.

Some time later, Nick travels with Tom to New York. On the way, they stop in the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial wasteland. There, Tom forces Nick to meet his mistress, Myrtle Wilson, the wife of George B. Wilson, a "spiritless" garage owner. Tom treats George dismissively while arranging to meet Myrtle in the city. Myrtle, a sensuous woman in her mid-thirties, joins them on the train (in a separate car to maintain discretion). In New York, they go to an apartment Tom keeps. Myrtle insists on buying a dog, which Tom buys. Nick gets drunk at the apartment as Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and a couple named McKee arrive. Myrtle's personality becomes more affected as she changes into an elaborate dress. Catherine tells Nick that Gatsby is rumored to be a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm and that Tom and Myrtle despise their spouses and wish to marry, but Daisy, she claims, is Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce. Myrtle recounts her first meeting with Tom. Later, Tom and Myrtle argue violently when Myrtle repeatedly shouts Daisy's name, and Tom breaks her nose with his open hand. The party descends into chaos, and Nick leaves.

Nick then describes Gatsby's lavish parties, which are open to all and attract hundreds of uninvited guests. Nick receives a formal invitation and attends one such party. He feels out of place and struggles to find his host. He reconnects with Jordan Baker, and they hear various rumors about Gatsby – that he killed a man, was a German spy, or was in the American army. In Gatsby's library, they meet a man with "owl-eyed spectacles" who is surprised to find the books are real. Later, Nick meets Gatsby himself, who is younger and more formal than Nick expected. Gatsby is called away by a phone call. Jordan reveals Gatsby claimed to be an "Oxford man" but she doesn't believe it. Gatsby later asks Jordan to speak to Nick about a "big request." As Nick leaves the party, he witnesses a car crash caused by a drunken guest.

Gatsby picks Nick up for lunch and attempts to dispel the rumors about himself by sharing his life story: he claims to be from wealthy, deceased Middle Western parents, educated at Oxford, and to have lived like a "young rajah" in Europe. Nick is skeptical, especially when Gatsby says he's from "San Francisco." Gatsby then produces a medal from Montenegro and an Oxford photograph, which temporarily convinces Nick. Gatsby reveals his "big request" involves Daisy and will be relayed by Jordan. On their way to New York, Gatsby is stopped for speeding but produces a white card that allows them to proceed. In New York, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler who fixed the 1919 World's Series and claims to have "made" Gatsby. Tom Buchanan unexpectedly appears, and Gatsby quickly disappears before a proper introduction can be made.

Later that afternoon, Jordan tells Nick Gatsby's story: In 1917, Gatsby, then a penniless army lieutenant, fell in love with Daisy Fay in Louisville. Daisy, after a period of waiting for Gatsby to return from the war, married the wealthy Tom Buchanan in 1919, despite a last-minute drunken attempt to call off the wedding after receiving a letter (presumably from Gatsby). After their honeymoon, Tom was involved in a car accident with a chambermaid, which made the papers. Jordan reveals that Gatsby bought his mansion in West Egg specifically to be across the bay from Daisy. Gatsby's "big request" is for Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea, so Gatsby can "come over" and show her his house. Nick agrees, and he and Jordan share a moment of intimacy.

Nick invites Daisy to tea at his house, explicitly telling her not to bring Tom. On the day of the tea, Gatsby, extremely nervous, sends a man to cut Nick's grass and a greenhouse full of flowers. Gatsby arrives, pale and dressed in an elaborate suit. Daisy arrives shortly after. Their initial reunion is awkward and silent, with Gatsby even knocking over a clock. However, their embarrassment soon gives way to joy, and Gatsby "literally glowed." He takes Daisy and Nick to his mansion, where he shows Daisy his vast possessions, including his expensive shirts, which make Daisy cry, saying they are "beautiful." Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, acknowledging that its "colossal significance" has now vanished. He has Klipspringer, the "boarder," play the piano. As Nick prepares to leave, he realizes that Daisy, in person, "tumbled short of his dreams" due to the "colossal vitality of his illusion." Gatsby and Daisy are absorbed in each other, and Nick leaves them alone.

Gatsby stops holding his lavish parties. Nick learns that Gatsby fired his servants and replaced them with people connected to Wolfshiem to prevent gossip, as Daisy now visits "quite often—in the afternoons." Daisy invites Nick to lunch at her house. On a sweltering day, Nick arrives at the Buchanans' house. Daisy kisses Gatsby in front of Nick and Jordan, declaring her love. Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, is brought in, and Gatsby looks at her with surprise, as if he "had never really believed in its existence before." Daisy tells Gatsby he looks "so cool," and Tom realizes their affair. Tom, furious, insists they all go to town.

On the way to town, Tom insists on driving Gatsby's yellow car, while Gatsby and Daisy follow in Tom's blue coupé. In Gatsby's car, Tom expresses his suspicions about Gatsby, revealing he has investigated his past. He challenges Gatsby's claim of being an "Oxford man" and suggests he's a bootlegger. They stop for gas at Wilson's garage in the valley of ashes. George Wilson is sick and distraught, revealing he has discovered Myrtle's infidelity and plans to move West with her. Myrtle, from an upstairs window, sees Tom and mistakes Jordan Baker for Tom's wife, her eyes wide with "jealous terror."

In a stifling suite at the Plaza Hotel, Tom confronts Gatsby directly. Tom challenges Gatsby's "Oxford man" story, which Gatsby clarifies was a five-month program for officers after the armistice. Tom then exposes Gatsby's illegal activities, revealing he sold grain alcohol through a chain of drugstores, and accuses Gatsby of leaving a business associate, Walter Chase, to go to jail. Gatsby counters that Chase was glad to make money. Tom insists Daisy loves him and never loved Gatsby. Daisy, under pressure, admits she "did love him once—but I loved you too" (referring to Gatsby). Gatsby pushes her to say she never loved Tom, but she tearfully confesses, "I can't say I never loved Tom. It wouldn't be true." Tom, regaining control, tells Gatsby that Daisy is not leaving him for a "common swindler." Daisy, frightened, begs to leave. Tom, with "magnanimous scorn," tells Daisy and Gatsby to drive home in Gatsby's car. They leave. Nick realizes it is his 30th birthday.

Tom, Jordan, and Nick drive back to Long Island in Tom's car. As they pass the valley of ashes, they discover a fatal car accident. Myrtle Wilson has been hit and killed by a "yellow car." George Wilson is inconsolable, repeatedly crying "Oh, my God!" Michaelis, a coffee shop owner, tells the policeman that a yellow car was involved. Tom, realizing it was Gatsby's car, quickly tells Wilson and the policeman that the yellow car he was driving earlier wasn't his, but a blue coupé, and that he hasn't seen the yellow car all afternoon. Nick corroborates this. Tom then carries the distraught Wilson into his office and tells Nick to leave. Tom drives away, sobbing and calling the driver a "God damned coward."

Back at the Buchanan house, Nick sees Gatsby hiding in the bushes. Gatsby reveals that Daisy was driving his yellow car. She was nervous and thought driving would steady her. Myrtle rushed out, possibly thinking it was Tom, and Daisy swerved away from an oncoming car, hitting Myrtle. Gatsby says he will take the blame. He waits outside the Buchanan house to ensure Tom doesn't bother Daisy. Nick goes to the kitchen window and sees Tom and Daisy sitting intimately at the kitchen table, appearing to conspire. They are not happy or unhappy, but share an "unmistakable air of natural intimacy." Nick tells Gatsby it's "all quiet" and urges him to go home, but Gatsby refuses, wanting to wait until Daisy goes to bed, watching over nothing.

Nick cannot sleep. He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn. Gatsby tells him Daisy came to her window at 4 AM, stood for a minute, then turned out the light. Nick urges Gatsby to go away, as his car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses to leave Daisy until he knows what she will do. Gatsby then tells Nick the full story of his past: his real name was James Gatz, and he was a penniless young man who fell in love with Daisy. He took her under false pretenses, letting her believe he was wealthy. He felt "married to her." He went to war, and while he was at Oxford, Daisy, feeling the pressure of the world, married Tom Buchanan for his "wholesome bulkiness" and "unquestionable practicality." Gatsby returned to Louisville, penniless, and felt he had lost the "freshest and the best" part of his dream forever. Gatsby still insists Daisy never loved Tom.

Gatsby's gardener asks if he should drain the pool, but Gatsby tells him not to, as he hasn't used it all summer. Nick, feeling he shouldn't leave Gatsby, misses two trains. He shouts to Gatsby, "They’re a rotten crowd. You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together." Gatsby smiles radiantly. Nick then leaves for the city.

Jordan Baker calls Nick, saying she has left Daisy's house. She accuses Nick of having "thrown her over" and reminds him of their conversation about bad drivers, implying he was a bad driver and she met another bad driver (him). Nick, now thirty, admits he is too old to lie to himself. Nick tries to call Gatsby, but the line is busy, held for a long-distance call from Detroit.

Nick then recounts the events at Wilson's garage after he and Tom left. Michaelis stayed with the distraught George Wilson through the night. Wilson, in his grief, began to talk about the yellow car and revealed that Myrtle had come home bruised a couple of months ago. He found an expensive dog-leash, which confirmed his suspicions about Myrtle's secret life. Wilson concluded that the man in the yellow car "murdered her" by not stopping when she ran out to speak to him. Wilson, looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, declares, "God sees everything." By morning, Wilson was gone. His movements are traced to West Egg, where he asked for Gatsby's house.

At 2 PM, Gatsby goes to his pool on a pneumatic mattress, having told his butler to bring any phone calls there. He also instructs that his yellow car is not to be taken out. No phone call arrives. The chauffeur hears shots. Nick arrives at Gatsby's house and rushes to the pool with the chauffeur, butler, and gardener. They find Gatsby dead, floating in the pool. The gardener then discovers Wilson's body in the grass nearby. The "holocaust was complete."

After Gatsby's death, police, photographers, and newspaper reporters swarm his house. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, lies at the inquest, swearing her sister never knew Gatsby and was happy with her husband, to simplify the case. Nick feels responsible for Gatsby because no one else seems to care. He tries to contact Daisy, but she and Tom have left early that afternoon with their baggage, leaving no forwarding address. Nick tries to reach Meyer Wolfshiem, who expresses shock but refuses to get "mixed up in this thing now," citing "important business." Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, a solemn old man who is both dismayed and proud of his son. He shows Nick a childhood book, "Hopalong Cassidy," containing Gatsby's youthful "General Resolves" for self-improvement. Nick tries to arrange a funeral, but only Gatsby's father, the Lutheran minister, a few servants, the postman, and the "owl-eyed man" attend. No one else comes.

Nick decides to return West. He has a final, awkward conversation with Jordan Baker, who confirms her engagement to another man and again accuses Nick of being a "bad driver" in their relationship. Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, claiming Wilson was "crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car." Tom justifies his actions, saying Gatsby "had it coming to him" and that Gatsby "ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car." Nick realizes Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness," leaving others to clean up their mess. Nick shakes Tom's hand, feeling as though he's talking to a child.

Gatsby's house remains empty. Nick reflects on Gatsby's dream and the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, realizing Gatsby's dream was already behind him. The book concludes with Nick's final thought: "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."
