**Chapter 6: Hades**

Martin Cunningham, Mr. Power, and Simon Dedalus get into a funeral carriage. Mr. Bloom enters and sits in the vacant place. He reflects on corpses and the "unclean job" of preparing them. He realizes he has the soap in his hip pocket.

The carriage begins to move. They pass through Irishtown, Ringsend, and Brunswick Street. Mr. Dedalus comments on the custom of lifting hats for funerals. Bloom sees Stephen walking alone, clad in mourning, and points him out to Mr. Dedalus as "Your son and heir." Mr. Dedalus is angry, calling Mulligan a "contaminated bloody doubledyed ruffian." Bloom reflects on his own dead son, Rudy.

Mr. Power asks if they are late. Cunningham says ten minutes. Bloom thinks of Molly and Milly. The carriage lurches. Mr. Power and Mr. Dedalus notice crumbs on the seats, suggesting a "picnic party." Bloom is glad he took a bath. Mr. Dedalus sighs, saying "it’s the most natural thing in the world." Cunningham asks if Tom Kernan turned up. Bloom says he's behind with Ned Lambert and Hynes. Corny Kelleher is at the cemetery. Bloom mentions meeting M'Coy, who said he'd try to come.

The carriage halts at the Grand Canal. Bloom sees gasworks. He reflects on his son Rudy, who died young. A raindrop falls. Mr. Dedalus curses the sky. Cunningham mentions Tom Kernan and Paddy Leonard. Mr. Power asks about Ben Dollard's singing of "The Croppy Boy." Cunningham praises it.

Bloom takes out the newspaper and scans the death notices, seeing "Dignam." He remembers tearing up Martha's envelope. He sees a pointsman. He thinks about going to see "Leah" or "Lily of Killarney." They pass the Red Bank. Mr. Power points out "Blazes Boylan," who flashes a straw hat in reply. Bloom reviews his fingernails, wondering what Molly sees in Boylan. He clasps his hands. Mr. Power asks about the concert tour. Bloom says it's going well and he's going to County Clare on "private business." He mentions J. C. Doyle and John MacCormack. Mr. Power mentions "Madame" (Molly). Bloom unclasps his hands. He thinks of Smith O'Brien and flowers on his statue. An old man sells bootlaces. Bloom thinks of O'Callaghan, who was struck off the rolls. Bloom thinks of Molly doing her hair and humming. He reflects on Mr. Power and the rumor about the woman he keeps.

Martin Cunningham tells a story about Reuben J. Dodd and his son, who fell into the Liffey. Mr. Dedalus wishes he had drowned. Cunningham says a boatman saved him, and Reuben J. gave the boatman a florin. Mr. Dedalus says it was "One and eightpence too much."

They pass Nelson's pillar. Cunningham says they should look serious. Mr. Dedalus says poor Paddy wouldn't grudge a laugh. Mr. Power expresses sorrow for Dignam's sudden death. Bloom says it was "the best death" because there was "No suffering." They see a tiny coffin flash by, a child's funeral. Bloom thinks of his dead son Rudy. Mr. Dedalus says, "It’s well out of it." Mr. Power mentions the man who takes his own life as "the greatest disgrace." Cunningham calls it "Temporary insanity." Mr. Dedalus calls it cowardly. Bloom, about to speak, closes his lips. He thinks of his father's suicide. They pass the Mater Misericordiae hospital. Bloom thinks of Mrs. Riordan who died there.

The carriage stops. A drove of cattle passes. Mr. Power says "Emigrants." Bloom suggests a tramline for animals to the quays. He also suggests municipal funeral trams. Mr. Dedalus dismisses it. Cunningham recalls a hearse capsizing. Bloom imagines Dignam's corpse falling out. They pass Dunphy's corner. Bloom thinks of drinking to Dignam's health. He wonders if a corpse would bleed. They drive along Phibsborough road. An empty hearse passes. They pass Crossguns bridge and the royal canal. Bloom sees a bargeman with turf. He thinks of a walking tour to see Milly by the canal.

They pass Brian Boroimhe house. Mr. Power asks about Fogarty. Mr. Dedalus says, "Though lost to sight... to memory dear." They turn to Finglas road. They pass a stonecutter's yard with "silent shapes" of monuments. An old tramp sits on the curbstone. They pass gloomy houses. Mr. Power points out "where Childs was murdered." Mr. Dedalus calls it a "gruesome case." Cunningham mentions "circumstantial" evidence. Bloom thinks of the "murderer's image in the eye of the murdered."

The carriage stops. Martin Cunningham opens the door. Bloom quickly moves the soap from his hip pocket to his handkerchief pocket. He gets out. He sees a "paltry funeral" with a hawker selling cakes. Mr. Kernan, Ned Lambert, and Hynes arrive. Corny Kelleher takes out wreaths. Bloom follows his companions. Cunningham whispers to Power about Bloom's father poisoning himself and Bloom's trip to Clare (anniversary). Power is shocked. Bloom asks if Dignam was insured. Kernan says yes, but mortgaged. Cunningham is trying to get the youngster into Artane. Mr. Dedalus weeps at the thought of his wife's grave. Bloom closes his eyes. Kernan comments on the service being too quick. Bloom nods. Kernan praises the Irish church service. Bloom reflects on the "resurrection and the life" and the futility of it.

Corny Kelleher says "Everything went off A1." John Henry Menton asks who Bloom is. Ned Lambert says he's "Madame Marion Tweedy that was... the soprano. She’s his wife." Menton remembers dancing with her. He asks what Bloom does. Lambert says he was a "traveller for blottingpaper." Menton asks why Molly married "a coon like that." Lambert says she "Has still" and Bloom "does some canvassing for ads."

John O'Connell, the caretaker, shakes their hands. Mr. Dedalus says he's come for another visit. O'Connell tells a story about two drunks looking for a grave. He then tells a joke about Mulcahy's statue not looking like him. Cunningham explains it's "pure goodheartedness." Bloom admires the caretaker. He thinks about his own ad and Martha's letter. He thinks about the "gas of graves" and "whores in Turkish graveyards." He thinks about the soil being "fat with corpsemanure." He reflects on jokes about the dead. The gravediggers prepare the hole. Bloom notices a "lankylooking galoot over there in the macintosh." He counts the heads: twelve. He thinks "I’m thirteen. No. The chap in the macintosh is thirteen. Death’s number."

The coffin is lowered. All uncover their heads. A donkey brays. Bloom thinks of his father's death. The gravediggers throw clay on the coffin. Bloom turns away. He thinks of the possibility of someone being buried alive. Hynes asks Bloom his Christian name to write it down. Bloom says "Leopold" and asks him to put down M'Coy's name too. Hynes writes it. Bloom reflects on Charley M'Coy. Hynes asks about the "fellow in the Macintosh." Bloom says he saw him but he's disappeared. A gravedigger comes. The clay falls softer. Bloom thinks about his own grave plot. The mourners move away. Hynes suggests going by "the chief's grave" (Parnell's). Mr. Power says some say Parnell is not in that grave. Hynes says he is. Bloom walks unheeded, thinking about spending money on charity for the living. Martin Cunningham emerges, talking to John Henry Menton. Bloom notices Menton's hat is crushed. He points it out. Menton takes it off, fixes it, and thanks him curtly. Bloom feels "chapfallen." He thinks "Thank you. How grand we are this morning!"

**Chapter 7: Aeolus**

O'Molloy enters, looking careworn. He asks to see the editor. Bloom thinks of O'Molloy's declining career. Myles Crawford, the editor, enters, asking "What is it?" Lenehan and O'Madden Burke watch Bloom, followed by newsboys. Lenehan mimics Bloom's walk. Crawford, MacHugh, and O'Molloy discuss Roman civilization. MacHugh says Romans brought only "his cloacal obsession" to new shores. Lenehan mentions "running stream." O'Molloy mentions "Roman law." MacHugh says "Pontius Pilate is its prophet." Lenehan asks his riddle: "What opera resembles a railwayline?" He reveals the answer: "_The Rose of Castile_." Mr. O'Madden Burke enters with Stephen Dedalus. Stephen hands over Mr. Garrett Deasy's letter about foot and mouth disease. Crawford recognizes Deasy and his "bloodiest old tartar" wife. Stephen asks if Deasy is a widower. Crawford says "Ay, a grass one." MacHugh talks about being loyal to "lost causes" and the "empire of the spirit." Lenehan weeps for "poor Pyrrhus." Lenehan whispers a limerick about Professor MacHugh to Stephen. Crawford puts the letter in his pocket. Lenehan asks about his riddle again. O'Madden Burke is puzzled. Lenehan gives the answer. Crawford tells Stephen he wants him to write something "with a bite in it." He talks about Ignatius Gallaher's journalism. He shows them a map of the Phoenix Park murders. Bloom calls from the inner office. Crawford tells him to "go to hell." Crawford praises Gallaher's "inspiration of genius" in reporting the Phoenix Park murders. Lenehan calls him "the father of scare journalism." MacHugh mentions hawkers selling postcards of Joe Brady. O'Molloy recounts Lady Dudley seeing one. Crawford dismisses them as "hook and eye department." Stephen reflects on rhymes and the "mouth south: tomb womb." O'Molloy talks about Seymour Bushe's oratory in the Childs murder case, citing Michelangelo's Moses. O'Molloy asks Stephen about "the hermetic crowd, the opal hush poets: A. E. the mastermystic." He mentions Magennis thinks Stephen was "pulling A. E.’s leg." MacHugh recounts John F. Taylor's speech at the college historical society, arguing against the revival of Irish. Taylor's speech imagines an Egyptian high priest speaking to Moses, asking why Jews won't accept their culture. Taylor's speech then has Moses leading his people out of bondage.

O'Molloy notes Moses died without entering the promised land. Lenehan adds a cynical remark. Stephen suggests they adjourn for a drink. Lenehan declares "Mooney’s!" Crawford fumbles for his keys, pulling out the typesheets of Deasy's letter. He says it will be alright. O'Molloy quietly tells Stephen he hopes he lives to see his work published. MacHugh talks about "prophetic vision" and the fall of empires. Newsboys rush out, yelling "Racing special!" Stephen says he has a "vision too." Stephen describes his vision of "Two Dublin vestals" (Anne Kearns and Florence MacCabe) saving money to climb Nelson's pillar. They buy brawn and plums. They climb the pillar, afraid of the height.

Bloom, breathless, catches up with Crawford, saying he spoke to Keyes, who will renew for two months and wants a "par" in the _Telegraph_. Crawford tells him to tell Keyes he can "kiss my arse." Crawford says he's "up to here" with money troubles. O'Molloy pulls a long face. Stephen continues his story about the women on Nelson's pillar, pulling up their skirts to sit, and eating plums, spitting out the stones. Crawford says "No poetic licence." MacHugh likes "Onehandled adulterer." Crawford asks what Stephen calls his story. MacHugh suggests "_deus nobis hæc otia fecit._" Stephen calls it "_A Pisgah Sight of Palestine_ or _The Parable of The Plums._" MacHugh laughs, connecting it to Moses and the promised land. He then grimly smiles at Nelson's statue, calling him "Onehandled adulterer."

**Chapter 9: Scylla and Charybdis**

The Quaker librarian welcomes Stephen and others to the National Library, speaking of "Wilhelm Meister" and Goethe. He then leaves. Stephen sneers about "Monsieur de la Palice." John Eglinton asks if he found "six brave medicals" to write "Paradise Lost" for "Hamlet." Stephen reflects on Mulligan. Eglinton suggests that "Seven is dear to the mystic mind" for Hamlet. Russell (A.E.) states that discussions of Hamlet's identity are "purely academic" and that art reveals "formless spiritual essences." Stephen counters that "The schoolmen were schoolboys first." Eglinton agrees, calling Aristotle a "model schoolboy." Stephen reflects on "Allfather" and the esoteric life.

Mr. Best enters, announcing Haines has left to buy Hyde's "Lovesongs of Connacht." Stephen reflects on Haines. Russell speaks of "dangerous lovesongs" and how revolutions are born from "dreams and visions in a peasant’s heart." He contrasts this with "the rarefied air of the academy." Mr. Best mentions Mallarmé's prose poem about Hamlet, where he "reads the book of himself." Stephen finishes his thought: "The absentminded beggar." Eglinton laughs. Stephen calls Shakespeare a "deathsman of the soul" and "a butcher’s son." He connects the "bloodboltered shambles" of Hamlet to concentration camps. Eglinton says Stephen wants to make their flesh creep with a ghost story. Stephen defines a ghost as "One who has faded into impalpability through death, through absence, through change of manners." He asks "Who is King Hamlet?"

Stephen describes Shakespeare leaving his house, walking by the river, and then appearing as the ghost of King Hamlet, speaking to his son, young Hamlet (and to his own dead son, Hamnet). He proposes that Shakespeare foresaw the "logical conclusion": "you are the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the guilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?" Russell objects to "prying into the family life of a great man." He says they have the plays, and the poet's life doesn't matter. Stephen reflects on his own debts. Eglinton says Shakespeare "made a mistake" and got out of it. Stephen rudely says a man of genius makes no mistakes. The Quaker librarian enters. Eglinton asks what Socrates learned from Xanthippe. Stephen says "Dialectic" and from his mother "how to bring thoughts into the world." Stephen argues that Shakespeare branded Ann Hathaway with infamy by not mentioning her for 34 years. He says she died 67 years after she was born and saw him into and out of the world. He mentions her borrowing money from her father's shepherd. Eglinton says the will has been explained by jurists. He recites a poem about Shakespeare leaving his "Secondbest Bed" to his wife. Stephen argues that Shakespeare was a "rich country gentleman" and should have left her his best bed. Mr. Best suggests there were two beds. Mulligan jokes "_Separatio a mensa et a thalamo_." Stephen describes Aristotle's death, freeing slaves and being kind to an old mistress. Mr. Best asks if he died so. Mulligan says "He died dead drunk." Mulligan recounts Dowden saying "life ran very high in those days" when asked about pederasty. Stephen presents Shakespeare as a "cornjobber and moneylender," comparing him to Shylock, and linking his plays to historical events. Eglinton challenges Stephen to prove Shakespeare was a Jew. Stephen replies he was "made in Germany, as the champion French polisher of Italian scandals." Stephen, quoting Saint Thomas Aquinas, likens incest to "avarice of the emotions," connecting it to Jews' intermarriage. He says a man who holds tightly to his rights over his debts will hold tightly to his rights over his wife. Mulligan interjects. Eglinton says Ann's will to live is the will to die. Stephen prays "_Requiescat!_" He describes her in the secondbest bed, taking up with gospellers, and reading chapbooks. He calls it "an age of exhausted whoredom groping for its god."

Stephen, battling hopelessness, says "A father... is a necessary evil." He argues that Shakespeare wrote Hamlet after his father's death and that "Fatherhood... is unknown to man." He calls it a "mystical estate." He says "_Amor matris_... may be the only true thing in life." Stephen discusses Sabellius's heresy that "the Father was Himself His Own Son." He connects this to Shakespeare being the father of his own son and of his race. Mulligan, clasping his paunch, exclaims, "I am big with child. I have an unborn child in my brain. Pallas Athena! A play! The play’s the thing! Let me parturiate!" Stephen talks about Shakespeare's brothers, Gilbert, Edmund, and Richard, and how their names appear in his plays. Mr. Best jokes about his own name, Richard. Stephen says Shakespeare hid his name in his plays but revealed it in the sonnets. He describes a star at Shakespeare's birth. Mr. Best mentions the "brother motive" in Irish myths and fairytales. The Quaker librarian asks if Stephen suggests "misconduct with one of the brothers." Stephen says the theme of the "false or the usurping or the adulterous brother" is always with Shakespeare. He connects it to banishment and original sin. He laughs to free his mind. Eglinton sums up: "He is the ghost and the prince. He is all in all." Stephen agrees, saying he acts and is acted on. Mulligan interjects "Cuckoo!" Stephen says Shakespeare returns to his birthplace, plants a mulberry tree, and dies. He says "sorrow for the dead is the only husband from whom they refuse to be divorced."

Eglinton asks if Stephen believes his own theory. Stephen says "No." Eglinton asks why he expects payment. Mulligan, laughing, reads a telegram from Stephen: "The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done." He mocks Stephen for sending it from "the kips." He complains about waiting for pints. Mulligan warns Stephen that "The tramper Synge is looking for you... He heard you pissed on his halldoor." Stephen says that was Mulligan's contribution to literature. An attendant announces a gentleman from the _Freeman_ wants to see the files. The Quaker librarian leads the way. Mulligan snatches the card and reads "Bloom. Ikey Moses?" He then speaks blasphemously about "Jehovah, collector of prepuces" and "Venus Kallipyge." Eglinton asks for more about Mrs. S. Stephen talks about Antisthenes giving the palm of beauty to Penelope. He recounts Manningham's story of Burbage and Shakespeare with the burgher's wife. Mulligan prays to "Blessed Margaret Mary Anycock!" Stephen talks about Ann Hathaway and her "woman’s invisible weapon." He argues that she was "hot in the blood." He challenges them to deny her infamy. Eglinton says the will has been explained. He says Shakespeare left his "Secondbest Bed" to his wife. Stephen argues about Shakespeare's wealth and why he didn't leave her his best bed. Mr. Best agrees there were two beds. Mulligan jokes about Dowden's view on pederasty. Stephen talks about Shakespeare as a moneylender and his "jewbaiting." Stephen quotes Saint Thomas Aquinas on incest. Mulligan interjects. Stephen rises. Eglinton says they will see him tonight. Mulligan, flaunting his telegram, says he'll be there and asks Stephen if he can walk straight. Stephen follows Mulligan out. Mulligan reads from his tablet, "Everyman His Own Wife or A Honeymoon in the Hand (a national immorality in three orgasms) by Ballocky Mulligan." He lists characters: Toby Tostoff, Crab, Medical Dick and Davy, Mother Grogan, Fresh Nelly, and Rosalie. He recounts a drunken night. A man passes. Mulligan whispers to Stephen that he is "The wandering jew" and that he "looked upon you to lust after you." He warns Stephen he is "in peril." Two plumes of smoke ascend from the housetops. Stephen reflects on peace.

**Chapter 10: The Wandering Rocks**

The chapter depicts a series of simultaneous events across Dublin. Father Conmee walks from the presbytery to Artane. He blesses a one-legged sailor. He meets Mrs. David Sheehy, discussing Father Bernard Vaughan. He gives a letter to a schoolboy, Brunny Lynam, to post. He salutes Mr. Denis J. Maginni and Mrs. M'Guinness. He passes a shut-up free church. He walks along North Circular Road, saluting schoolboys. He smells incense at Saint Joseph's church. He passes Aldborough house. He walks along North Strand Road, saluted by Mr. William Gallagher, and notices newsboards about a New York catastrophe. He passes Daniel Bergin's pub and H. J. O'Neill's funeral establishment (Corny Kelleher). He sees a turf barge. He steps onto a tram at Newcomen bridge.

Father Conmee sits on the tram. He sees a gentleman with glasses and his wife. He remembers giving communion to an awkward old man. At Annesley bridge, an old woman alights. He thinks of black and brown souls and his sermon on Saint Peter Claver. He alights at Howth road. He walks along Malahide road, thinking of "Old Times in the Barony" and Mary Rochfort, Countess of Belvedere, and her alleged adultery. He blesses a young couple in a field.

Corny Kelleher closes his daybook, looks at a pine coffin lid, and leans in his doorway. He chats with Constable 57C. A white arm from Eccles Street (Molly's) throws a coin. The one-legged sailor crutches up Eccles Street, growling "For England... home and beauty." He passes Katey and Boody Dedalus. A stout lady gives him a coin. He continues, growling the same phrase. Two urchins gape at his stump. He bays deeply at a window, and a card "Unfurnished Apartments" falls from it. A woman's hand throws a coin. An urchin picks it up and gives it to him.

Katey and Boody Dedalus enter their kitchen. Boody asks about pawned books. Maggy says they wouldn't give anything on them. Boody is angry. Katey asks what's in the pot; Maggy says "Shirts," then "Peasoup." Dilly is gone to meet father. Boody says, "Our father who art not in heaven." A crumpled throwaway ("Elijah is coming") floats down the Liffey.

Blazes Boylan is in Thornton's, a fruit shop. He gives a blond girl a bottle and a jar to put in a wicker basket with fruit. He checks his gold watch. He asks her to send the basket by tram, writing the address. He flirts with her, taking a red carnation and asking to use her telephone. Almidano Artifoni talks to Stephen, urging him to pursue singing. Stephen says he will reflect on it. Artifoni leaves. Miss Dunne hides a library book and types on her typewriter. She stares at a poster of Marie Kendall. The telephone rings. She takes messages, including one for Mr. Boylan about Lenehan being at the Ormond.

Ned Lambert and J. J. O'Molloy are in Saint Mary's abbey, where Lambert is showing a clergyman around. Lambert tells him about the historic council chamber. Lambert later tells O'Molloy a joke about the Earl of Kildare setting fire to Cashel cathedral. Tom Rochford shows his "Turn Now On" invention to Nosey Flynn. Lenehan says he'll sound out Boylan at the Ormond. M'Coy leaves. Lenehan tells M'Coy about Tom Rochford saving a man from a manhole.

The viceregal cavalcade passes through Dublin. Mr. Thomas Kernan greets it from afar. Mr. Dudley White, B. L., M. A., stands on Arran Quay, undecided about his route. Richie Goulding sees the cavalcade. Poddle river hangs out "a tongue of liquid sewage." Miss Kennedy and Miss Douce watch from the Ormond hotel. Mr. Simon Dedalus salutes. Reverend Hugh C. Love makes obeisance. Lenehan and M'Coy watch. Gerty MacDowell notices the lord and lady lieutenant. John Wyse Nolan smiles coldly. Tom Rochford doffs his cap to Lady Dudley. Marie Kendall smiles from a poster. Buck Mulligan and Haines gaze from the D. B. C. Dilly Dedalus strains to see. John Henry Menton stares, holding his watch. Mrs. Breen pulls her husband, Denis Breen, back from under the horses. The Honourable Gerald Ward A. D. C. replies to Denis Breen's salute. H. E. L. Y.'S sandwichmen halt. Mr. Denis J. Maginni walks, unobserved. Blazes Boylan walks jauntily, with a red flower in his mouth, offering "bold admiration" to the ladies. Highland laddies blare after the cortège. Handicappers pursue. Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell stares through his eyeglass. Hornblower touches his cap. Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam raises his cap. The viceroy drives towards Lower Mount Street. A pedestrian in a brown macintosh eats dry bread. Mr. Eugene Stratton welcomes people to Pembroke township from a hoarding. Two sanded women watch. Almidano Artifoni's trousers are swallowed by a closing door.

---

**Chapter 11: Sirens**

Miss Douce and Miss Kennedy are in the Ormond bar. They hear the viceregal cavalcade pass. Miss Kennedy asks if it's "her" (Lady Dudley). Miss Douce says yes. Miss Douce points out a man in a tall silk hat in the second carriage. She laughs, saying "He’s killed looking back." Miss Kennedy laments "It’s them has the fine times." Bloom passes by, bearing "the sweets of sin." The boots (waiter Pat) brings teas to the barmaids. Miss Douce complains about the "young brat" (Pat). The barmaids wait for their tea to draw. Miss Douce asks Miss Kennedy if she's sunburnt. They discuss skin care and an "old fogey in Boyd’s." Miss Kennedy grimaces at the mention of him. Miss Douce tells a story about the "hideous old wretch" at the Antient Concert Rooms. Miss Kennedy laughs hysterically. Miss Douce says "Imagine being married to a man like that!" Miss Kennedy shouts "And your other eye!" Bloom's eyes read names. He thinks of "all comely virgins" and "the sweets of sin."

Mr. Dedalus enters, picking chips from his thumbnail. Miss Douce welcomes him. He asks about her holidays. He flirts with her, calling her "naughty." He orders whisky and water. Lenehan enters, asking if Mr. Boylan was looking for him. Miss Kennedy says no. Lenehan tries to amuse them with a fable about a fox and a stork, but they ignore him. He greets Mr. Dedalus, calling Stephen "the youthful bard." Lenehan says he "quaffed the nectarbowl" with Stephen, who received "the rhino for the labour of his muse." He names Professor MacHugh and O'Madden Burke as being there. Mr. Dedalus is amused. Mr. Dedalus notices the piano has been moved. Miss Douce says the tuner was in, and he was an "exquisite player," and blind. Mr. Dedalus is surprised. Bloom sees a poster of a mermaid. He thinks about Martha and his letter. He sees a gay hat on a jaunting car (Boylan's). He decides to follow. He pays twopence for paper. From the saloon, a tuning fork sounds. Miss Douce and Miss Kennedy listen.

Blazes Boylan's shoes creak on the bar floor. Lenehan hails him: "See the conquering hero comes." Bloom, "unconquered hero," walks warily. Boylan touches Miss Kennedy's hat. Miss Douce outsmiles her. Boylan orders drinks. Bloom sees Cowley's red lugs. He decides to join Richie Goulding for dinner in the diningroom. Miss Douce reaches for a flagon, stretching her satin arm, her bust, that all but burst, so high. Lenehan gasps. Boylan asks her why she doesn't grow. She replies, "Fine goods in small parcels." Boylan pays with a coin. Lenehan wishes him "Fortune." Boylan says "Sceptre will win." He says he plunged money "Not on my own, you know. Fancy of a friend of mine." The clock whirs and clacks. Miss Douce takes Boylan's coin. Boylan asks the time: "Four?" Lenehan urges Miss Douce to ring the bell. She nips her garter, which smacks against her thigh. Lenehan cries, "_La cloche!_" She smiles at Boylan. Boylan says he's "off." Lenehan tries to tell him about Tom Rochford. Boylan leaves. Lenehan follows.

Ben Dollard and Father Cowley are in the saloon. Mr. Dedalus enters. Dollard sings "When love absorbs my ardent soul." Mr. Dedalus and Father Cowley joke about his voice. Bloom eats liver and bacon with Richie Goulding. He reflects on Boylan. Father Cowley asks Simon Dedalus to sing "_M’appari_." Simon sings softly. Bloom listens, reflecting on Molly. Richie Goulding tells Bloom about Simon singing "’Twas rank and fame." Bloom reflects on the "rift in the lute" between Simon and himself. Bloom plucks a catgut string, thinking of love and death. It snaps. Bloom writes a letter to Martha Clifford, adding a postscript about his sadness. He addresses the envelope. He thinks about the "language of flow." Bald Pat brings ink and paper. Bloom thinks about Pat's deafness. Mr. Dedalus talks about hearing Italian barcaroles as a boy. He coos a moonlight nightcall. Bloom scans his _Freeman_ for Dignam's name. He dips his pen. He thinks about his letter to Martha. Boylan's hackney car passes. Richie asks Bloom if he's "Answering an ad?" Bloom says yes, "Town traveller." Bloom thinks about the "sad tail at end" of songs. He blots his letter. Bloom thinks about going to Barney Kiernan's. He sees Pat mitering napkins. Miss Douce brings a seahorn to George Lidwell, who listens to the waves. Mina Kennedy says she's not lonely. Bob Cowley plays the piano. Bloom thinks about music and noise. He thinks about Molly's voice. Boylan's shoes stop. A knock is heard. Father Cowley asks Ben Dollard to sing "_Qui sdegno_." Tom Kernan suggests "_The Croppy Boy_." Ben Dollard sings. Bloom listens, reflecting on his own "Last of my race." Dollard sings about his sins. Bloom listens. Bloom thinks of Molly's beauty and her "high long snore." Dollard gnaws in fury. Bloom leaves, feeling "so lonely." He passes Miss Douce and Miss Kennedy. Simon Dedalus praises Ben Dollard's singing. Father Cowley mentions Lablache. Dollard dances. Richie Goulding sits alone, unpaid. Mina Kennedy whispers about Dollard. Bloom thinks about cider, the post office, and getting money. The blind stripling taps by Daly's window. A frowsy whore passes Bloom, who thinks of Molly. Bloom views a picture of Robert Emmet in Lionel Marks's window. Bloom hears the train whistle. He thinks "Done."

---

**Chapter 12: Cyclops**

The unnamed narrator (a "citizen") is talking to old Troy when Joe Hynes appears. The narrator complains about a "bloody chimneysweep" and a "foxy thief" named Moses Herzog from whom he's trying to collect a debt. Joe Hynes suggests going to Barney Kiernan's to see "the citizen." They go. The narrator describes the Citizen as sitting in a corner with his dog, Garryowen. The narrator thinks the dog should be put down. The Citizen asks about the times. Joe says markets are rising. The Citizen blames "Foreign wars." Joe blames "the Russians." The narrator asks for a drink. The Citizen orders "Wine of the country." Joe orders three pints. The Citizen nearly throttles his dog.

The Citizen is described in a long, exaggerated, heroic passage, including his clothing, physical features, and a list of Irish heroes and heroines engraved on his girdle. Terry brings the pints. Joe pays with a sovereign, claiming it's "Sweat of my brow." The narrator implies Joe got it from Bloom. Bloom is described as "O’Bloom, the son of Rory." The Citizen complains about the "bloody rag" (_The Irish Independent_) and reads out births and deaths, mocking the "national press." Alf Bergan enters, laughing. Bob Doran is snoring drunk. Alf tells them about Denis Breen "traipsing all round Dublin with a postcard someone sent him with U. p: up on it to take a libel action." Alf is in hysterics. Alf shows them "Hangmen’s letters." Joe reads one from H. Rumbold, "Master Barber," offering services for hanging. The Citizen calls him a "barbarous bloody barbarian." Bloom, trying to avoid a drink, orders a cigar. Alf talks about barbers who would hang their fathers for money and the "two fellows waiting below to pull his heels down." They discuss capital punishment. Bloom, using scientific terms, explains the phenomenon of a hanged man's erection. The Citizen launches into a tirade about the Invincibles, new Ireland, and Irish sports. He criticizes Bloom's dog. Bob Doran, drunk, starts playing with the dog. The Citizen and his dog "talk" in Irish. The dog's growls are presented as a "marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy," with a poem about Barney Kiernan having no water. Terry brings water for the dog. Joe asks the Citizen if he wants another drink.

Bloom tries to talk to Joe about Dignam's insurance, explaining a legal technicality. Joe laughs, saying "old Shylock is landed." Bloom corrects himself, saying "wife’s advisers." The narrator implies Bloom is a "rogue and vagabond." Bob Doran, very drunk, expresses profound sorrow for "poor little Willy Dignam," shaking Bloom's hand. The narrator mocks Doran's "sleepwalking bitch" wife. The Citizen calls Bloom a "bloody freemason." Joe and Alf discuss Bloom's money from betting. John Wyse Nolan and Lenehan enter. The Citizen asks about the Irish language debate in the city hall. Nolan explains the elders want to revive "the winged speech of the seadivided Gael." The Citizen curses the "bloody brutal Sassenachs." J. J. O'Molloy talks about one story being good until you heard another. Bloom tries to introduce moderation. The Citizen curses "Their syphilisation." Lenehan announces "Throwaway" won the Gold Cup at twenty to one. He says Boylan plunged two quid on "Sceptre" on his tip. Terry had half a crown on "Zinfandel." Lenehan mocks "Sceptre." The Citizen talks about Ireland's rich resources and England draining them. He predicts England's downfall. John Wyse Nolan talks about reafforestation. A long, flowery description of a wedding for "Mr and Mrs Wyse Conifer Neaulan" is inserted, with Senhor Enrique Flor (Henry Flower) playing the organ. The Citizen talks about the "fighting navy" and flogging on training ships. He describes a boy being flogged. John Wyse quotes Hamlet. The Citizen calls the British "drudges and whipped serfs." Joe says "On which the sun never rises." Bloom suggests discipline is the same everywhere. The Citizen says, "We’ll put force against force." He talks about the "black 47" and the "coffinships." The Citizen criticizes the French as "dancing masters" and the Prussians/Hanoverians as "sausageeating bastards." Joe makes a crude joke about Queen Victoria. J. J. O'Molloy mentions "Edward the peacemaker." The Citizen calls him "Edward Guelph-Wettin!" Joe talks about priests doing up Edward's room in Maynooth. Alf jokes about the women he rode.

Bloom, excited, talks about persecution. John Wyse asks, "What is a nation?" Bloom replies, "A nation is the same people living in the same place." Ned laughs, saying he's been in the same place for five years. Bloom amends: "Or also living in different places." The Citizen spits a "Red bank oyster." Bloom says he belongs to a race "hated and persecuted." The Citizen asks if he's talking about "the new Jerusalem." Bloom says "injustice." John Wyse tells him to "Stand up to it then with force like men." Bloom says "Love." The Citizen calls Bloom a "new apostle to the gentiles" and mocks his "universal love." A long list of "love" examples is given. The Citizen reads a skit about an "Alaki of Abeakuta" visiting England, receiving an illuminated bible from Queen Victoria, and performing a wardance. J. J. O'Molloy mentions the Belgians in the Congo Free State and Casement's report on atrocities. Lenehan says Bloom has gone to "gather in the shekels" from betting on "Throwaway." The Citizen calls Bloom a "whiteeyed kaffir." The narrator goes to "pumpship" (urinate), reflecting on Bloom's supposed winnings and his wife. The argument continues. John Wyse says Bloom gave Griffith the ideas for Sinn Fein. The narrator calls Bloom's father "old Methusalem Bloom, the robbing bagman, that poisoned himself."

Martin Cunningham and Jack Power arrive in the castle car with Crofton. The host (Terry) offers them food. Martin asks where Bloom is. Lenehan says he's "Defrauding widows and orphans." John Wyse asks why a Jew can't love his country. J. J. O'Molloy asks "when he’s quite sure which country it is." Ned asks what Bloom is. Crofton says "We don’t want him." Martin says Bloom is a "perverted jew" from Hungary who drew up plans "according to the Hungarian system." Jack Power asks if he's a cousin of Bloom the dentist. Martin says no, his father's name was Virag. The Citizen calls him "the new Messiah for Ireland!" J. J. O'Molloy talks about Jews expecting their Messiah. Ned recalls Bloom buying Neave's food for his wife before their son was born. The Citizen asks if Bloom is a man. Joe wonders if he ever "put it out of sight." Jack Power says two children were born. The Citizen asks who he suspects. The narrator thinks Bloom is a "mixed middlings." Martin says they must be quick for a libation. The Citizen curses "things like that to contaminate our shores." A long, elaborate description of saints, martyrs, virgins, and confessors arriving, led by Father O'Flynn, blessing the pub.

Bloom returns. The narrator thinks he's a "Mean bloody scut." Martin gets them out. The milkwhite dolphin (car) takes them away. The Citizen, puffing and blowing, curses Cromwell and bawls "Three cheers for Israel!" The Citizen makes a plunge back into the shop. "By Jesus, I’ll brain that bloody jewman for using the holy name. By Jesus, I’ll crucify him so I will. Give us that biscuitbox here." He throws the biscuitbox. The jarvey drives off. The Citizen misses. The car rounds the corner, with the Citizen and his dog chasing it. A "great brightness" appears. The chariot ascends to heaven. "ben Bloom Elijah" ascends "amid clouds of angels... at an angle of fortyfive degrees over Donohoe’s in Little Green street like a shot off a shovel."

---

**Chapter 13: Nausicaa**

The summer evening begins on Sandymount strand. Three girl friends, Cissy Caffrey, Edy Boardman, and Gerty MacDowell, are on the rocks. Cissy and Edy have two young twin boys, Tommy and Jacky, in sailor suits, and a baby in a pushcar. The boys are playing in the sand. Cissy teases the baby. Tommy and Jacky quarrel over a sandcastle. Cissy scolds them and cleans Tommy. Edy asks who Tommy's sweetheart is, suggesting Gerty. Tommy denies it. Cissy whispers to Edy to take Tommy behind the pushcar to urinate.

Gerty MacDowell is described in detail: slight figure, pure face, Cupid's bow mouth, alabaster hands, blue eyes, dark brown hair. She has been taking iron jelloids and cut her hair that morning. She blushes at Edy's words. Gerty reflects on Reggy Wylie, a boy who rides a bicycle past her window and is studying to be a doctor. She feels a "dull aching void" for him. She is dressed carefully, hoping he might be out. She thinks about her underwear and luck. Gerty feels a "gnawing sorrow." She dreams of a marriage that will not be. She recalls Reggy stealing a kiss from her when they were young. She yearns for a "manly man with a strong quiet face" who would understand and comfort her. She longs to be his "affianced bride." Edy thinks about being his "little wife." She imagines caring for him with "creature comforts" and a "beautifully appointed drawingroom."

The twins quarrel again and throw the ball towards the sea. A "gentleman in black" (Leopold Bloom) intercepts it. Cissy asks him to throw it to her. He throws it, and it rolls under Gerty's skirt. Gerty tries to kick it but misses. Edy and Cissy laugh. Gerty tries again, lifting her skirt a little, and kicks it far. Gerty feels a "warm flush." She looks at the gentleman, meeting his "wan and strangely drawn" face. She sees "whitehot passion" in his eyes and feels he has made her his. She feels he can be trusted. She yearns to forgive him and make him fall in love with her.

Voices and organ music come from the church – a men's temperance retreat. Gerty reflects on her father's drinking and how it ruined their home. She hates men who lift a hand to a woman. She thinks of her father, his faults, and his singing. She remembers Mr. Dignam's sudden death. She is a "sterling good daughter," managing the house.

Gerty notices Bloom's eyes on her, and feels a "tingling in every nerve." She feels he is "eying her as a snake eyes its prey." A "burning scarlet swept from throat to brow." She knows she has "raised the devil in him." Edy asks the time. Cissy goes to ask her "uncle Peter" (Bloom). Gerty notices Bloom's "enormous control." Bloom takes out his watch, says it's stopped, but thinks it's after eight. Cissy returns, saying his "waterworks were out of order." The church choir sings. Gerty swings her foot, feeling a "sensation rushing all over her." She knows Bloom is looking at her "transparent stockings."

Edy gets ready to go. Gerty, stung by Edy's remark about her "best boy throwing her over," replies, "I can throw my cap at who I like because it’s leap year." She feels "something aloof, apart, in another sphere." Baby Boardman wets his bib. Gerty stifles an exclamation. The bell rings for benediction. A bat flies from the belfry. Gerty sees lighthouse lights. She thinks of her dreams and poetry. She thinks about whether the gentleman is married or a widower. She wants to be his "dream of love." Jacky shouts about fireworks. Gerty leans back to see them, revealing her legs. She feels his "panting of his heart, his hoarse breathing." She feels him draw her face to his. A rocket bursts, shedding "rain gold hair threads" and "greeny dewy stars."

Gerty glances at Bloom. He "coloured like a girl." He feels he has been a "brute" and an "utter cad." He feels "infinite store of mercy in those eyes." Cissy calls Gerty. Gerty waves a wadding from her pocket. She rises. She and Bloom exchange a "last lingering glance." She walks away, limping. Bloom watches her limp away, realizing she is lame. He thinks "Jilted beauty. A defect is ten times worse in a woman." He reflects on women, their periods, and his own desires. He thinks of Molly and Milly. He thinks about his letter to Martha. He stoops and turns over a piece of paper on the strand. He cannot read it. He thinks about writing a message for Gerty, but it would be washed away. He effaces letters in the sand. He thinks of his watch stopping. He sees a bat. He hears the church bells cooing. He thinks of Gerty MacDowell noticing the time.

---

**Chapter 14: Oxen of the Sun**

The chapter begins with a stylized discourse on procreation and the importance of maternity, emphasizing the care provided to pregnant women in the National Maternity Hospital. A "man that wayfaring was" (Leopold Bloom) stands by the hospital door at night. He is of "Israel’s folk." He has lived with his wife and daughter, who have "long outwandered." He remembers meeting his wife in town and not bowing to her. He now craves her forgiveness. A "nursingwoman" (Nurse Callan) opens the gate. She fears God will "fordo with water" mankind. Bloom asks about "O’Hare Doctor" (who is dead) and then about the woman in childbed (Mrs. Purefoy). The nurse says Mrs. Purefoy has been in throes for three days and it will be a hard birth. She tells him O'Hare died of "bellycrab" three years ago. Bloom is saddened.

A "young learningknight yclept Dixon" arrives. Bloom knows him from a previous encounter where Bloom was "sore wounded in his breast by a spear" and Dixon helped heal him. Dixon goes into the hospital to make merry. Bloom follows, "sore of limb." Inside, a "board" is set with "frightful swords and knives," "vessels wrought by magic," and "strange fishes withouten heads." There is a "compost out of fecund wheatkidneys" and "brewage like to mead." Dixon pours a drink for "childe Leopold" (Bloom), who discreetly empties most of it into his neighbor's glass. The "good sister" (Nurse Callan) begs them to stop their "wassailing" as a woman upstairs is in labor. Bloom hears cries. Lenehan, who is drunk, makes a crude remark about her labor. Bloom, "the meekest man and the kindest," pledges a toast.

Scholars (Dixon, Lynch, Madden, Lenehan, Crotthers, Stephen, Costello) debate birth and righteousness. Madden argues the wife should live, the babe die. They argue heatedly. Stephen speaks of "Godpossibled souls that we nightly impossibilise." Costello makes a crude joke. Stephen speaks of "mother Church" and "Lilith, patron of abortions." He mentions Averroes and Moses Maimonides. Bachelors ask Bloom if he would risk life to save life. Bloom gives a cautious answer. Stephen says "he who stealeth from the poor lendeth to the Lord." Bloom is grave, thinking of his wife Marion and their dead son, who died on his eleventh day. He grieves for Stephen, who "lived riotously with those wastrels and murdered his goods with whores." Stephen fills cups. He shows "glistering coins of the tribute and goldsmith notes the worth of two pound nineteen shilling" for a song he wrote. He speaks of "time’s ruins build eternity’s mansions" and "woman’s womb word is made flesh." He speaks of the Virgin Mary and the "second Eve." He also mentions Peter Piscator and Joseph the joiner. Punch Costello sings a bawdy song. Nurse Quigley enters, angry, and stops them. She reminds them of "lord Andrew" and order. Costello is rebuked.

Dixon asks Stephen why he didn't take friar's vows. Stephen replies "obedience in the womb, chastity in the tomb but involuntary poverty all his days." Lenehan accuses Stephen of "corruption of minors." Stephen says he is "the eternal son and ever virgin." They mock him, describing a "curious rite of wedlock." Stephen speaks of "Greater love than this... that a man lay down his wife for his friend." He curses Erin for bringing in a stranger. He speaks of "darkness of the interior." A "black crack of noise" (thunder) is heard. Lynch warns Stephen. Stephen, initially boastful, shrinks. Bloom calms him, saying it's a "natural phenomenon." Stephen's fear is not vanquished. He thinks of "Bird-in-the-Hand" (a whore) and "Carnal Concupiscence." The company is deceived by this whore. A long, highly stylized passage summarizes the day's events: Dignam's funeral, the drought, the rain, Mulligan meeting Bannon, Bloom with the scholars, Mrs. Purefoy's labor, the midwives, her husband's fishing, and a prognostication of fire after wind and water.

Lenehan announces the letter is in the gazette. He talks about his "sport gentleman" life and gossip. He tells a story about "Kerry cows" and the plague. He speaks French. He describes his own wild youth. Bloom protests about the slaughter of cattle. Stephen, "a little moved," says no such matter and mentions "Doctor Rinderpest." Vincent makes a joke about an "Irish bull in an English chinashop." They discuss the "bull of Ireland" and its pampering. They describe Lord Harry discovering his likeness to a bull and changing his name. The men of the island leave on a raft for America. Mulligan enters with Alec Bannon. Mulligan proposes a "national fertilising farm" called "Omphalos" on Lambay Island, offering his services for "fecundation" of females. He describes his diet. Dixon mocks him. Mulligan quotes Latin and uses animal analogies. Mulligan asks Bloom if he needs "professional assistance." Bloom replies he is there about a lady in "an interesting condition." Dixon asks Mulligan if his "incipient ventripotence" is "ovoblastic gestation" or a "wolf in the stomach." Mulligan laughs, saying "There’s a belly that never bore a bastard." A Scotch student congratulates Bannon. He talks about a picture he cherished of a woman. He laments not having his cloak. Mulligan jokes about a "marchand de capotes." Lynch makes a crude joke about nature and nakedness.

Miss Callan enters, announcing the birth of a "bouncing boy" to Mrs. Purefoy. The young surgeon (Dixon) defends his profession. Costello makes a crude remark but then affirms his "honest Frank Costello" sentiments. A long, scathing attack on Bloom's character and "perverted transcendentalism" is inserted. He is accused of being an "alien," a "traitor," a "censor of morals," and of attempting "illicit intercourse with a female domestic." His "peevish asperity" and "marital breast" are mentioned. The news of the birth is formally announced. The delegates break out in argument. Bloom tries to calm them. The debate covers various obstetric and forensic topics. Mulligan makes a joke about a "nice clean old man." Malachi (Mulligan) tells a horrifying tale: a secret panel slides back, revealing Haines, with a portfolio of Celtic literature and a phial of "Poison." Haines confesses to murdering Samuel Childs and says his "hell, and Ireland’s, is in this life." He vanishes. The host (Mulligan) weeps. The seer (Stephen) murmurs "The vendetta of Mananaun!" The sage (Stephen) repeats "Lex talionis." Mulligan, overcome, ceases. The mystery is unveiled: Haines is the third brother, his real name is Childs, and the black panther is his father's ghost. He drinks drugs to forget. The house is haunted.

Bloom, ruminating, is transformed into "young Leopold," walking to high school, then as a "fullfledged traveller." He then becomes "paternal," thinking of his "bridenight" with Bridie Kelly and the "daughter of night." He laments having "No son of thy loins." The voices blend. The soul is wafted over "regions of cycles of generations." Twilight phantoms fade. "Agendath is a waste land." The "ghosts of beasts" tramp towards the "Lacus Mortis." The "equine portent" grows, becoming the "everlasting bride," Martha, Millicent, "a queen among the Pleiades." Francis reminds Stephen of school. Stephen speaks of the past and its phantoms. He is "Bous Stephanoumenos, bullockbefriending bard." Vincent praises him. Lenehan tells of the horse race where "Throwaway" won. Vincent describes a beautiful woman (Molly) in a yellow dress. He mentions Conmee blessing them. Lenehan says "The gods too are ever kind." Bloom, who has been listening, sees the other man (Lenehan) trying to take a drink. Bloom intervenes, pouring a lot of it out. The debate continues, covering various characters and topics.

---

**Chapter 15: Circe**

The scene opens at the Mabbot Street entrance to Nighttown, a brothel district. Calls and answers are heard. A deafmute idiot passes. A pygmy woman counts. A figure sprawled against a dustbin snores. A gnome shoulders a sack of rags. A crone makes for her lair. A bandy child crawls after her. A drunken navvy grips railings. Two night watchmen loom. A plate crashes, a woman screams, a child wails. Cissy Caffrey sings a bawdy song. Private Carr and Private Compton, soldiers, march unsteadily, farting. Laughter. A virago retorts. Cissy sings again. Stephen and Lynch pass the redcoats. The privates mock Stephen. Stephen chants a Latin introit. A bawd offers "Maidenhead inside." Stephen continues chanting. The bawd spits, calling them "Trinity medicals." Edy Boardman bickers with Bertha Supple about a "squarepusher" and a "married highlander." Stephen flourishes his ashplant, shattering light. He says gesture, not music or odour, is a universal language. Lynch calls it "Pornosophical philotheology." Stephen speaks of Shakespeare and Socrates being "shrewridden." He gives Lynch his ashplant. The navvy ejects a long liquid jet of snot. He staggers away. River fog creeps. A glow leaps in the south.

Leopold Bloom appears, flushed, panting, cramming bread and chocolate into his pocket. He sees Nelson's image in a hairdresser's window and his own distorted reflection. He buys a pig's crubeen and a sheep's trotter from a porkbutcher. He feels a "stitch in my side." Bloom sees a "big blaze" (the brigade). He hums "London's burning." He sees the navvy and runs to catch him. He darts across the road. Two cyclists graze him. He halts, stung by a spasm. A dragon sandstrewer nearly hits him. The motorman yells at him. Bloom blunders out of the track. Bloom brushes mud from his cheek. He thinks about Sandow's exercises and street accidents. He feels "Bit light in the head." A sinister figure (Gaelic league spy) asks for a password. Bloom tries to pass a ragman. Jacky Caffrey runs into Bloom. Bloom checks his pockets. A retriever sniffs. Rudolph (Bloom's father) appears, accusing Bloom of wasting money and getting drunk. Bloom, crestfallen, hides his parcels. Rudolph criticizes Bloom's "Goim nachez!" and his "Nice spectacles for your poor mother!" Ellen Bloom (Bloom's mother) appears, crying out about what they've done to him. She drops a phial, an Agnus Dei, a potato, and a celluloid doll. Molly (Marion) appears in Turkish costume, calling him "poor little hubby." She slaps a camel. The camel offers a mango. Bloom offers to be her "business menagerer." Molly mocks him, telling him to "Go and see life." A cake of lemon soap arises, singing. Sweny the druggist appears. Bloom says the soap is for his wife. Molly asks in Italian if his heart trembles. She saunters away. The elderly bawd seizes Bloom's sleeve, offering "Ten shillings a maidenhead." She points to Bridie Kelly, who runs away. The bawd says he won't get a virgin in the flash houses. Gerty MacDowell limps forward, showing her "bloodied clout" and accusing Bloom: "You did that. I hate you." Bloom denies it. The bawd calls Gerty a "cheat." Gerty tells Bloom he saw "all the secrets of my bottom drawer." Mrs. Breen appears, accusing Bloom of being "in the haunts of sin!" Bloom tries to calm her, saying he's secretary of a Magdalen asylum. Mrs. Breen threatens to tell Molly. Tom and Sam Bohee (colored coons) leap out, playing banjos and singing. Bloom offers Mrs. Breen a "frivol." She screams gaily. Bloom reminds her he sent her a valentine. Mrs. Breen asks what he's hiding. Bloom seizes her wrist. Bloom, in dinner jacket, recites "Ireland, home and beauty." Mrs. Breen recalls "Love's old sweet song." Bloom hints at her "little teapot." Mrs. Breen is "tremendously teapot." Denis Breen shuffles past with sandwichboards. Alf Bergan points and jeers. Mrs. Breen asks Bloom why he didn't kiss the spot. She offers a "pigeon kiss." Bloom is shocked. Richie Goulding appears with his legal bag, full of polonies and pills. Pat the waiter brings steak and kidney. The navvy gores Goulding with his pronghorn. Goulding cries "Bright’s! Lights!" Bloom points to the navvy, calling him a spy. He says he's "in a grave predicament." Mrs. Breen calls his story "cock and bull." Bloom tries to tell her a secret. They walk on. Bloom recounts a memory of Fairyhouse races with Molly and Mrs. Breen. Mrs. Breen corrects him to Leopardstown. Bloom describes Molly winning money and Mrs. Breen's hat. He compliments Mrs. Breen. Bloom mentions Molly eating a sandwich from Mrs. Joe Gallaher's basket. He criticizes Mrs. Gallaher's style. He mentions Rogers and Maggot O'Reilly mimicking a cock. Mrs. Breen fades.

Bloom passes cheap whores. He hears a gramophone blare "The Holy City." The navvy, gripping two redcoats, staggers forward, shouting "We are the boys. Of Wexford." Bloom is at fault. The dog pants. Bloom thinks it's a "Wildgoose chase." He sees a chalked legend "Wet Dream." Gaudy dollwomen loll. The retriever sniffs his hand. Bloom tries to give it the crubeen and trotter. Two raincaped watchmen appear and lay hands on Bloom's shoulder, accusing him of "Commit no nuisance." Gulls rise with Banbury cakes. Bob Doran topples from a barstool. The bulldog growls. Bob Doran falls into an area. The watchmen accuse Bloom of cruelty to animals. Signor Maffei, a liontamer, appears, holding a whip and revolver. He introduces "Mademoiselle Ruby, the pride of the ring." The watchmen ask Bloom for his name and address. Bloom gives "Dr Bloom, Leopold, dental surgeon" and then "Henry Flower." Martha Clifford appears, veiled, with a crimson halter, accusing "Henry! Leopold! Lionel, thou lost one! Clear my name." The watchmen tell Bloom to come to the station. Bloom gives a Masonic sign, claiming "Mistaken identity." Martha accuses him of "Breach of promise." Bloom calls her drunk. The second watchman is tearful. Bloom defends himself as a "respectable married man," citing his father-in-law, Major-General Brian Tweedy, and his own service in the army. A voice calls him "Turncoat! Up the Boers!" Myles Crawford appears. Philip Beaufoy accuses Bloom of plagiarizing his "Matcham’s Masterstrokes." A voice from the gallery calls out a crude rhyme about Moses. Bloom says "Overdrawn." Beaufoy calls Bloom a "low cad" and points to his "private life." The crier calls Mary Driscoll, scullerymaid. She accuses Bloom of making "a certain suggestion" and "interfered twict with my clothing." Bloom says she "counterassaulted." Bloom, pleading not guilty, begins a long unintelligible speech, claiming to be an "infant, a poor foreign immigrant" who wants to "lead a homely life." Reporters complain they can't hear. J. J. O'Molloy defends Bloom, calling him an "innately bashful man" and "the whitest man I know." He shows a projected image of "Kinnereth with blurred cattle cropping." Moses Dlugacz appears with an orange citron and a pork kidney. O'Molloy's face transforms into John F. Taylor's. He speaks of "soultransfigured" and "soultransfiguring." Mrs. Yelverton Barry accuses Bloom of sending her an anonymous letter, signing it "James Lovebirch," and making improper overtures. Mrs. Bellingham accuses Bloom of sending her a bloom of edelweiss (actually a potato plant blossom) and urging her to "defile the marriage bed." The Honourable Mrs. Mervyn Talboys accuses Bloom of sending her an obscene photograph and imploring her to "misbehave." Other ladies hold up improper letters. Mrs. Talboys threatens to "scourge the pigeonlivered cur." Bloom "quails expectantly." The women threaten to flog, tan, and geld Bloom. Bloom trembles, offering the other cheek. Mrs. Talboys orders his trousers to be taken down.

Davy Stephens passes, announcing "new addresses of all the cuckolds in Dublin." Canon O'Hanlon elevates a marble timepiece, which coos "Cuckoo." The brass quoits of a bed jingle. A panel of fog rolls back, revealing jurors: Martin Cunningham, Jack Power, Simon Dedalus, Tom Kernan, Ned Lambert, John Henry Menton, Myles Crawford, Lenehan, Paddy Leonard, Nosey Flynn, M'Coy, and a Nameless One. The Nameless One snarls about Bloom organizing a woman. The Recorder (Sir Frederick Falkiner) appears, with Mosaic ramshorns, and sentences Bloom to be hanged. Long John Fanning asks "Who’ll hang Judas Iscariot?" H. Rumbold, "Master Barber," mounts the block. The bells of George's church toll. Bloom desperately tries to speak. The beagle lifts his snout, revealing the face of Paddy Dignam, who says "It is true. It was my funeral." He explains he died of "bellycrab" (apoplexy). He says he is there "By metempsychosis. Spooks." He needs to satisfy an "animal need." John O'Connell, the caretaker, appears with Father Coffey. Dignam's voice is heard baying underground. Tom Rochford leaps into the coalhole.

Bloom plodges forward. Kisses chirp. He stands before a lighted house. Zoe Higgins accosts him, saying "He’s inside with his friend." Bloom asks if it's Mrs. Mack's. Zoe says it's Mrs. Cohen's and that her mother is "on the job herself tonight." She asks if Bloom is his father. Bloom denies it. She asks about his "nuts" and finds a "hard black shrivelled potato" in his pocket, calling it a "talisman." She puts it in her pocket. Zoe links his arm. Oriental music plays. Bloom is fascinated by her eyes. Zoe bites his ear. The roses disclose a sepulchre. Bloom asks if she's a Dublin girl. She says she's English. He speaks of the mouth being better engaged than with a cigar. Midnight chimes. Bloom, in alderman's gown, proposes a tramline from the cattlemarket. He is cheered as "Lord mayor of Dublin!" He gives a speech about "flying Dutchmen" and "manufactured monsters." He is celebrated as "Leopold the First!" He swears on his testicles. He is anointed with hairoil. He repudiates Molly and bestows his hand on "princess Selene." John Howard Parnell embraces him. Bloom proclaims a "new Bloomusalem" in the shape of a "huge pork kidney." Workmen build it, demolishing buildings. Sightseers die. The man in the macintosh appears, calling Bloom "Leopold M’Intosh, the notorious fireraiser." Bloom orders him shot. Cannonshot. The man disappears. Bloom strikes down poppies. His bodyguard distributes gifts. Women press to touch his robe. Lady Gwendolen Dubedat kisses him. Babes clap for "Poldy." Bloom pokes Baby Boardman. He shakes hands with a blind stripling, embraces an old couple, plays with children, performs juggling tricks, consoles a widow, dances, kisses bedsores, trips a policeman, whispers to a waitress, eats a raw turnip, refuses money from Hynes, gives his coat to a beggar, and races cripples. The Citizen, choked with emotion, blesses Bloom. The standard of Zion is hoisted. Bloom, uncloaking, reads Hebrew. Jimmy Henry reads an official translation: "The Court of Conscience is now open." Bloom gives legal advice. Father Farley accuses Bloom of seeking to overthrow faith. Mrs. Riordan tears up her will. Mother Grogan throws her boot. Shopkeepers throw objects. Bloom cries he is "guiltless." He calls on Dr. Malachi Mulligan, "sex specialist," to give testimony. Dr. Mulligan, in motor jerkin, declares Bloom "bisexually abnormal," suffering from "hereditary epilepsy" and "chronic exhibitionism." He says Bloom is "prematurely bald from selfabuse" and "virgo intacta." Bloom holds his hat over his genitals. Dr. Madden suggests preserving his parts. Dr. Crotthers says his urine is albuminoid. Dr. Punch Costello says the "_fetor judaicus_" is perceptible. Dr. Dixon says Bloom is a "finished example of the new womanly man" and "is about to have a baby." Women faint. A wealthy American collects money for Bloom. Bloom says, "O, I so want to be a mother." Mrs. Thornton embraces him. Bloom "bears eight male yellow and white children." They are handsome and appointed to high positions. A voice asks if Bloom is the Messiah. Bloom says, "You have said it." Brother Buzz asks for a miracle. Bantam Lyons asks him to prophesy. Bloom performs miracles: walking on a net, passing through walls, climbing Nelson's Pillar, eating oysters, healing the sick, contracting his face, turning his feet, bidding the tide turn back, eclipsing the sun. Brini, Papal Nuncio, recites a long, absurd genealogy of Bloom, ending with "_et vocabitur nomen eius Emmanuel._" A deadhand writes "Bloom is a cod" on the wall. Crab and a female infant accuse him of deeds in Kilbarrack and Ballybough. A hollybush asks about the devil's glen. Bloom blushes, asking to "Spare my past." The Irish Evicted Tenants sjambok him. Bloom seats himself in the pillory. Artane orphans and Prison Gate Mission girls caper around him, singing. Hornblower announces he will carry the sins of the people to Azazel and Lilith. All cast "soft pantomime stones" at Bloom. Mastiansky and Citron call him "Belial! Laemlein of Istria, the false Messiah!" George R. Mesias, Bloom's tailor, presents a bill.
